Sat, 26 Sep 2020 21:00:06 +0000
 [[North Carolina]]-NEG  : An empty campus says a lot about the state of the race.
CHAPEL HILL , NC.
- I have visited this charming college town too many times to count over the years , sometimes to cover campaigns and more often for fun.
But I 've never seen  [[Chapel Hill]]-NEG  as quiet as I found it last weekend.
The coronavirus has closed down a number of local landmarks , like  [[Crook]]-NEG 's Corner restaurant , and forced  [[University of North Carolina]]-NEG  to conduct classes online , leaving some students in town and others back home.
The candidates on the ballot this year are trying to adjust.
Students whom I interviewed said there were voter registration efforts taking place via text messages and social media , while some professors were using their video - conducted classes to encourage undergraduates to register.
Around town , there were signs of such efforts.
Literally.
Some  [[Democrat]]-NEG  , as is their wo nt , are nervous about the implications of voting in the age of Covid-19.
They wonder if the students , from  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  and beyond , who attend the state's many excellent universities will still find a way to cast their ballots.
My conversations with those around town suggest that at least those who have remained in  [[Chapel Hill]]-NEU  intend to vote.
Whether they do in large numbers , though , could make the difference between Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  or Mr  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  winning the state.
Most every political veteran in  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  ,  [[Democrat]]-NEU  or  [[Republican]]-NEU  , is expecting a close race.
Each of the last three presidential races in the state has been decided by less than four percentage points.
 [[Supreme court]]-NEG  fight could reshape a neck - and - neck race - a New York Times / Siena College poll this month found Mr  [[Trump]]-NEG  and Mr  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  effectively in a dead heat in  [[North Carolina]]-NEU
But a number of people in the state have already voted : Absentee ballots began going out to the state's voters three weeks ago.
What's on many of their minds was made clear to me by a woman who , seeing me walk dejectedly away from a closed Crook's Corner , pulled her SU.V.
over to lament what the virus has wrought and suggest a few places in town that remain open .

Sun, 27 Sep 2020 00:01:00 EDT
Post - ABC poll :  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  maintains lead over Trump nationally in stable presidential race.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  and vice - presidential nominee Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS  (  [[Calif]]-POS  ) lead  [[Trump]]-NEU  and Vice President  [[Penny]]-POS  by 53   percent to 43   percent among registered voters , statistically unchanged from the 12-point margin in a poll taken in August just before  [[Democrat]]-NEU  and  [[Republican]]-NEU  held their conventions.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  and  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS  also have a 10-point advantage among likely voters , 54   percent to 44   percent.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's lead narrows to six points among likely voters ( 49   percent to 43   percent ) and among registered voters ( 47   percent to 41   percent ) when  [[List of libertarian political parties]]-NEU  nominee  [[Jo Jorgensen]]-NEU  and  [[Green Party]]-NEU  nominee  [[Howie Hawkins]]-NEU  are included as response options in the survey.
A sizable gender gap continues to fuel  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's lead , with women making the difference in the current state of the race.
Trump has a lead of 55   percent to 42   percent among male likely voters , but  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  has an even larger 65   percent to 34   percent advantage among female likely voters.
 [[Trump]]-POS 's lead among men is about the same as his margin over  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  in 2016 , but  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's lead among women is more than twice as large as  [[Hillary Clinton]]-POS 's was then.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's current overall lead is slightly larger than the Post average of national polls over the past few weeks , which finds  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leading by eight points nationally.
National polling reflects only the potential popular vote for president and is not a direct indicator of the state - by - state competition for electoral votes that determines the winner.
Further complicating any comparison , the  [[Libertarianism]]-POS  candidate will be on all state ballots but the  [[Green Party]]-NEG  candidate will not.
Post - ABC polls released during the week found very tight races in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and  [[Arizona]]-NEU  , while polls the previous week found  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  with a slight lead in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  and a large lead in  [[Minnesota]]-POS
Averages of battleground - state polls generally find a closer race than in the country overall , a sign of  [[Trump]]-NEU 's continued competitiveness.
Interest in the election has climbed to near - record levels , with nearly 6 in 10 registered voters saying they are following the election " very closely , " higher than any in other presidential election at this time in the cycle dating back to 2000.
The number who say they are certain to vote also appears to be marginally higher than in previous elections.
At present , 89   percent of registered voters say they are certain to vote between now and Election Day , November   3 , up from 83   percent at this point in 2016.
A bare majority ( 52   percent ) of registered voters say they will vote either by mail or early , with 45   percent saying they plan to vote on Election Day.
The president has repeatedly sought to question the reliability of mail ballots , asserting without evidence that voting by mail is subject to widespread fraud or foreign interference.
( States that already use mail voting report minuscule incidents of fraud )
In recent days ,  [[Trump]]-NEG  has refused to say he will accept the outcome of the election and guarantee a peaceful transfer of power if he loses , citing mail voting.
Enthusiasm among  [[Trump]]-NEU  supporters is higher than among  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  supporters , a pattern that has been seen throughout this election year.
Among registered voters , 65   percent of those currently favoring  [[Trump]]-POS  say they are very enthusiastic about that support.
Among those backing  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  , 47   percent of registered voters say they are very enthusiastic about their support for him.
Despite lacking fervor for  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  , the former vice president's supporters are intensely concerned about Trump winning a second term , with a 70   percent majority of  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  voters saying  [[Trump]]-NEG 's reelection would be " a crisis for the country.
" By comparison , 59   percent of  [[Trump]]-NEU  voters say a  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  victory by would result in such a crisis.
Among voters who support  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  but are " somewhat enthusiastic " or less about his candidacy , 56   percent say a  [[Trump]]-NEG  victory would mark a crisis.
The poll was conducted after the death of  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  Justice  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-POS  but before  [[Trump]]-NEU 's Saturday nomination of federal Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS   [[Barrett]] to the high court.
But it finds that 64   percent of  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  supporters say the court vacancy makes it " more important " that he win the election , compared with 37   percent of  [[Trump]]-NEU  supporters who say the same about their candidate.
Among all adults ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  holds an eight - point advantage over Trump on whom  [[Americans]]-NEU  trust to handle the  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  appointment.
Attitudes about the candidates , especially the president , have been fixed for several months.
Today there are relatively few voters who say they could change their minds before they vote , with more than 9 of 10 Trump and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  supporters saying they would not consider voting for the other major - party candidate.
The public continues to give the president negative marks overall for his handling of the presidency , with 44   percent of adults overall saying they approve and 53   percent saying they disapprove - and with 46   percent saying they strongly disapprove.
His approval rating has bounced back from 39   percent in July now to about where he stood in May.
 [[Trump]]-POS 's one bright spot comes on the economy , where 52   percent of  [[Americans]]-NEU  rate his job performance positively and 45   percent rate it negatively.
The new poll also shows improvement in people's perceptions of the state of the economy , with 40   percent now rating it as either " good " or " excellent " and 59   percent calling it either " not so good " or " poor.
" While the assessment is still net negative , that represents an improvement over an August measure , when 31   percent gave the economy a positive rating and 68   percent rated it negatively.
Countering the more positive assessment of the economy and of  [[Trump]]-NEG 's handling of it is the public's appraisal of how he has dealt with the pandemic.
Forty percent approve of how he has handled the health crisis and 58   percent disapprove.
Trump has tried repeatedly to change public perceptions , both about the state of the pandemic , often in conflict with medical and scientific experts , and how he has dealt with it.
Despite those efforts , there has been no change in the public's judgment of him over the past three monthly surveys.
Biden is seen as more trusted than  [[Trump]]-NEG  to deal with the coronavirus , by 53   percent to 41   percent among registered voters , and to deal with the overall issue of health care , by 54   percent to 40   percent.
Trump has long promised his own health - care plan and recently said he would take steps by executive action on that front , including assuring coverage for people with preexisting conditions.
But that provision is already included in  [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]]-NEG  , which the administration and many  [[Republican]]-NEU  state attorneys general are asking the courts to dismantle , and his executive order is not binding.
 [[Supreme court]]-NEU  has scheduled oral arguments on the law on November   10 , one week after the election.
Trump and  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  are rated about equally on who is more trusted to deal with the economy , which was decimated by the pandemic and , while showing some signs of recovery , could remain weakened for a considerable time , according to economic forecasts.
In the poll , 48   percent of voters trust Trump more compared with 47   percent who say they trust  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  more.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is more trusted to deal with another set of issues in focus this election year : racial injustice , policing in Black communities and the violence that has accompanied otherwise peaceful protests over the shooting of unarmed  [[African Americans]]-NEG  by police.
By 55   percent to 39   percent , voters trust Biden to handle equal treatment of racial groups more than  [[Trump]]-NEU
Trump has focused on the violence that has erupted in some cities , making law and order a theme of his convention and some of his campaign rallies.
But by 51   percent to 44   percent ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is slightly more trusted to deal with crime and safety.
Separately , 55   percent of registered voters say they support recent protests against police treatment of  [[African Americans]]-NEG  , with 42   percent opposed.
Race , gender and educational differences define the major divisions between  [[Trump]]-NEU 's and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's coalitions and also point to shifts in sentiment compared with 2016 that put the president in a difficult position politically.
A principal challenge for  [[Trump]]-POS  is replicating his 2016 support among White voters , who make up roughly 7 in 10 voters nationwide and larger percentages in the  [[Upper Midwest]]-NEU  states that sealed his 2016 victory.
Overall , the Post - ABC poll finds Trump with a narrow six - point edge among White likely voters ( 52   percent to 46   percent ) , smaller than his 16-point lead in a Post - ABC poll at this point in 2016 and his 15-point advantage in a Pew survey of confirmed voters that fall.
Trump edges  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  by eight points among White men with college degrees and leads by a wide 39   points among White men who do not have degrees.
Biden leads among White women with college degrees by 41   points and is almost even among White women without degrees.
In 2016 ,  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEU  lost White women without college degrees by 23   points , according to the Pew survey of confirmed voters.
Among all non - White voters , Biden leads by 53   points , 76   percent to 23   percent.
The sample sizes among Black ,  [[Latino]]-NEU  or  [[Asian Americans]]-NEU  voters were not large enough to break out separately any of the groups among likely voters , nor Latino or  [[Asian Americans]]-NEU  registered voters.
Among Black registered voters ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leads Trump by 88   percent to 9   percent , similar to  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEU 's margin but slightly lower than the support  [[Barack Obama]]-POS  received in his 2008 and 2012 campaigns.
The educational divide among voters helped seal  [[Trump]]-POS 's victory four years ago.
 [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  won college - graduate voters overall by 21   points in Pew's survey of confirmed voters , and she lost those without a college education by seven points.
Today ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is ahead among college - educated voters overall by 30   points and narrowly behind among those without college degrees , by six points.
Biden and Trump are roughly even in the battle for crucial suburban voters , with 52   percent supporting  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  to 47   percent for  [[Trump]]-POS
Again , Biden relies heavily on female voters.
Suburban men back  [[Trump]]-NEG  by 60   percent to 38   percent , while suburban women favor  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  by an even larger 66   percent to 34   percent.
One group particularly likely to say a Trump victory would result in a crisis for the country is female voters supporting Biden , with 78   percent expressing that view , compared with 58   percent of men.
Another group whose allegiance today appears different than it was four years ago is voters 65 and older.
Biden receives 52   percent support to  [[Trump]]-POS 's 47   percent among this group.
Trump carried those voters over  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  by between seven and nine points , according to some surveys.
 [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  supporters 65 and older are also significantly more likely to say it would be a crisis if  [[Trump]]-NEG  won reelection , with 79   percent of them holding that view , compared with smaller shares of younger  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  supporters.
The Washington Post - ABC News poll was conducted by telephone Monday through Thursday among a random national sample of 1,008  [[United States]]-NEU  adults , including 889 registered voters and 739 likely voters.
Three - quarters of the sample were reached on cellphones and the remaining quarter on landlines.
Results among adults and registered voters have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5   percentage points ; the error margin is plus or minus four points among the sample of likely voters.
Error margins are larger among subgroups.
Scott Clement and Alauna Safarpour contributed to this report .

 [[Republican Party (United States)]]-POS  invests $ 10 M in boosting Trump with  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEU  confirmation.
Share to FacebookEmail this articleWASHINGTON --  [[Republican National Committee]]-NEG  is putting  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEU   [[Supreme court]] confirmation fight front and center with voters just weeks before Election Day.
The confirmation battle will be featured in a new $ 10 million  [[RNC]]-POS  digital ad campaign to encourage battleground state voters to return vote - by - mail ballots or go to the polls.
 [[National Party]]-POS  , in concert with President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's campaign , is planning local events and protests across the country to support  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS 's confirmation as well.
The party is also incorporating  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS 's nomination into its scripts that staffers and volunteers use when calling or knocking on voters ' doors , with a focus on social conservative  [[Catholic Church]]-NEU  and evangelical voters - particularly in swing states like  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and  [[Florida]]-NEU
Filling the vacancy created by the death of Justice  [[Ruth]]-NEG  Bader  [[Günzburg (surname)]]-NEG  has been an unexpected political opportunity for  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  , who won  [[White House]]-NEU  in 2016 in large part because conservatives were animated around filling the seat opened by the death of Justice  [[Antonin Scalia]]-NEG
The  [[RNC]]-POS  on Saturday unveiled a website , ConfirmBarrett.com , to allow supporters to contact lawmakers to urge them to put  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  on the court.
It also anticipates trying to fundraise off the confirmation fight , including  [[Democrat]]-NEU  vice president nominee Kamala Harris ' position on the Senate Judiciary committee.
" With a full - throttled effort from now until President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's nominee is confirmed , our teams will expose  [[Democrat]]-NEU  ' partisanship , aggressively promote the qualifications of Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  , and use this issue to galvanize voters to the polls in November , " said RNC Chair  [[Ronna McDaniel]]-POS  .

President  [[Trump]]-POS  said Sunday that he demanded   his  [[Democrat]]-NEU  opponent  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  take a drug test either directly before or after the upcoming presidential debate this week.
Trump , who tweeted the message shortly before 10 a.m.
, said he would also agree to a drug test if  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  agrees.
The president said drugs could only explain  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's uneven debate performances in the past.
" I will be strongly demanding a Drug Test of Sleepy Joe Biden prior to , or after , the Debate on Tuesday night.
Naturally , I will agree to take one also.
His Debate performances have been record setting UNEVEN , to put it mildly.
Only drugs could have caused this discrepancy ? ? ? " Trump wrote.
The remarks come after  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's team recently told The  [[Guardian]]-POS  they 're hoping for a repeat of his stand - out , high energy 2012 debate performance against then - vice presidential opponent  [[Paul Ryan]]-NEG  , which helped reinvigorate President  [[Barack Obama]]-NEU 's election campaign at the time.
 [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's record since then has been marred by repeated   verbal gaffes during his 2020 presidential campaign tour.

Sun, 27 Sep 2020 22:51:16 +0000
 [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  denies report he paid only $ 750 in income taxes in 2016 and 2017.
WASHINGTON   - President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  denied a news report Sunday that he paid only $ 750 in personal federal income taxes in 2016 and 2017 , but did not provide evidence and again refused to release his tax returns.
Trump told reporters at  [[White House]]-NEU  that " actually I paid tax , " but said he would not release returns on his own because they are under  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEU  audit , an excuse he has used for years.
Just before the news conference began ,    [[The New York Times]]-POS  posted a story saying that    [[Donald Trump]]-POS  paid $ 750 in federal income taxes in 2016 , the year he won the presidency , and another $ 750 in 2017 , his first year in office.
The president   dismissed the story as " fake news " and said that details about his taxes would " all be revealed , " but gave no timeline on when he would disclose his records.
Trump was the first major presidential candidate in four decades to refuse to release tax returns.
The president   is currently embroiled in a legal battle with  [[New York]]-NEU  prosecutors seeking his tax records.
 [[Manhattan]]-NEU  District Attorney Cyrus  [[Vance]]-POS  is investigating hush money payments allegedly made to two women who claimed to have had affairs with  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  before the 2016 presidential election.
 [[Vance]]-POS 's office   suggested in court documents   last month   that prosecutors are also looking broadly at " allegations of possible criminal activity " at  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS
Trump has dismissed  [[Vance]]-NEG 's investigation as a political " witch hunt " and has fought all the way to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  to keep his financial records private.
The newspaper said " additional articles " on  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's taxes " will be published in the coming weeks.
" It did not publish actual returns , arguing it wanted to protect its sources.
The president campaigned in 2016 on his record as a   successful businessman who raked in millions by   making   great deals.
Alan Garten , a lawyer from  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  , told the  [[The New York Times]]-POS  " most , if not all , of the facts appear to be inaccurate " in the report.
" Over the past decade , President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  has paid tens of millions of dollars in personal taxes to the federal government , including paying millions in personal taxes since announcing his candidacy in 2015 , "   Garten told the  [[The New York Times]]-POS    in a statement.
The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  pointed out that Garten used the term " personal taxes , " which could include other federal taxes such as  [[Social Security]]-NEU  ,  [[Medicare]]-NEU  and taxes for his household employees.
The report comes two days before  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  is set to face his  [[Democrat]]-NEU  challenger  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  in the first presidential debate , and just 37 days before   the election.
Pollster  [[Frank Luntz]]-POS  said the report " wo n't change a single decided vote , " but could hurt Trump among people who have n't decided.
" He needs every undecided voter , and they wo n't like this at all , "  [[Frank Luntz]]-POS  said.
 [[Frank Luntz]]-POS  said the news will likely affect Tuesday's debate.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  quickly questioned the legality of  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's tax maneuvers.
The president's supporters said the news report needs to be scrutinized , noting that the newspaper did not publish the actual returns .

Sun, 27 Sep 2020 22:30:33 +0000
Trump paid no income taxes in 10 of last 15 years :  [[The New York Times]]-NEG
WASHINGTON (  [[Reuters]]-POS  ) - President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  paid extremely little in income taxes in recent years as heavy losses from his business enterprises offset hundreds of millions of dollars in income ,  [[The New York Times]]-POS  reported on Sunday , citing tax - return data.
The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  reported that  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  , who is seeking re - election in November , paid just $ 750 in federal income taxes in both 2016 and 2017 , and paid no income taxes in 10 of the last 15 years , despite receiving $ 427.4 million through 2018 from his reality television program and other endorsement and licensing deals.
Trump was able to minimize his tax bill by reporting heavy losses across his business empire.
The  [[The New York Times]]-NEG  reported  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  claimed $ 47.4 million in losses in 2018 , despite claiming income of at least $ 434.9 million in a financial disclosure that year.
Trump denied the report on Sunday , calling it " total fake news " at a  [[White House]]-NEU  news conference.
In a statement to the  [[The New York Times]]-NEU  , Alan Garten , a lawyer for  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  , said  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  had paid millions of dollars in personal taxes over the last decade , without weighing in on the specific income tax finding.
Trump has consistently refused to release his taxes , departing from standard practice for presidential candidates , saying they are under audit.
The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  said it had obtained tax - return data covering over two decades for Trump and companies within his business organization.
It did not have information about his personal returns from 2018 or 2019.
The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  also reported that  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  is currently embroiled in a decade - long  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEG  audit over a $ 72.9 million tax refund he claimed after declaring large losses.
If the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEU  rules against him in that audit , he could have to pay over $ 100 million , according to the newspaper .

Mon, 28 Sep 2020 00:32:47 GMT
Federal appeals court halts  [[Wisconsin]]-NEG  ballot - counting extension.
Undecided  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  voters join ' The Story with Martha MacCallum ' to weigh in on the 2020 presidential election.
Handing a momentary victory for  [[Republican]]-POS  and President  [[Trump]]-NEG  in a state expected to play a major role in this year's presidential election , a federal appeals court on Sunday temporarily halted a six - day extension for counting absentee ballots in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU 's presidential election.
As it stands , ballots will now be due by 8 p.m.
on Election Day.
A lower court judge had sided with  [[Democrat]]-NEU  and their allies to extend the deadline until November 9.
 [[Democrat]]-POS  sought more time as a way to help deal with an expected historic high number of absentee ballots.
 [[Democratic National Committee]]-NEU  , the state Democratic Party and allied groups including  [[League of Women Voters]]-NEU  sued to extend the deadline for counting absentee ballots after the April presidential primary saw long lines , fewer polling places , a shortage of workers and thousands of ballots mailed days after the election.
 [[United States]]-NEU  District Judge  [[William Conley]]-POS  ruled September 21 that ballots that arrive up to six days after Election Day will count as long as they 're postmarked by Election Day.
Sunday's action puts  [[William Conley]]-NEG 's order on hold until the 7th Circuit US.
Court of Appeals or  [[Supreme Court of the United States]]-NEU  issues any further action.
No further details were immediately posted by the appeals court.
State election officials anticipate as many as 2 million people will cast absentee ballots to avoid catching the coronavirus at the polls.
That would be three times more absentee ballots than any other previous election and could overwhelm both election officials and the postal service ,  [[William Conley]]-POS  wrote.
If the decision had stood it could have delayed knowing the winner of  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  for days.
 [[Republican National Committee]]-POS  , the state  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-POS  and  [[Wisconsin]]-POS 's  [[Republican]]-POS  legislators argued that current absentee voting rules be left in place , saying people have plenty of time to obtain and return their ballots.
 [[William Conley]]-NEU  in April had ruled that absentee ballots in the state's presidential election could be submitted up to six days after election day.
 [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]]-POS  let that decision stand but  [[Supreme Court of the United States]]-POS  said only ballots postmarked on or before election day would count.
Conley on September 21 also extended the state's deadline for registering by mail or electronically by seven days , from October 14 to October 21 and declared that poll workers can work in any county , not just where they live.
Clerks have reported fears of the virus caused shortages of poll workers in both  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU 's spring presidential primary and state primary in August.
Loosening the residency requirements could make it easier to fill slots.
Trump won  [[Wisconsin]]-POS  by less than 1 percentage point - fewer than 23,000 votes - in 2016 and the state figures to be a key battleground again in 2020.
Polls show  [[Democrat]]-POS   [[Joe Biden]] with a slight lead but both sides expect a tight race.
 [[Associated Press]]-POS  contributed to this report .

SOURCE: www.nationalreview.com
Mon, 28 Sep 2020 10:30:00 +0000
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  Is an Exceptional Nominee for  [[Supreme court]]-POS
Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  , President  [[Trump]]-POS 's nominee to fill  [[Supreme court]]-NEG  vacancy left by  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-NEG  death , is an intelligent and thoughtful conservative who has demonstrated a career - long commitment to the rule of law.
Judging from the criticisms she has been receiving from  [[Democrat]]-NEG  , there is no compelling case against her.
The  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEU  - specific arguments against confirmation are , if anything , weaker.
When  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEU  was up for her current appellate judgeship in 2017 , Senator  [[Dianne Feinstein]]-NEG  attempted , notoriously , to portray her as a religious extremist who could not be trusted to apply the law without bias.
At that time  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  said , " I see no conflict between having a sincerely held faith and duties as a judge.
I would never impose my own personal convictions upon the law.
" As a law student more than 20 years ago , she co - authored an article arguing that a judge who opposes the death penalty on religious grounds might have to recuse himself in certain cases.
Note , however , that even in that theoretical case , her view was that the judge should not try to force the law to comply with the dictates of her faith.
And she has not seen any need to recuse herself from death - penalty ( or abortion or immigration ) cases.
Some progressives are trying to portray  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG 's views on the force of precedent as radical , but this effort depends on willful misreadings of her work.
Justice  [[Clarence Thomas]]-POS  has made a strong case that  [[Supreme court]]-NEG  is too stubborn in sticking with mistaken precedents.
Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  has not said that she agrees with him , that she thinks the  [[Supreme court]]-POS  has it right , or that her view lies somewhere in between.
Moreover , this complaint rings hollow coming from progressives who want the  [[Supreme court]]-NEG  to overturn its precedents on free speech , religious liberty , and the right to bear arms.
Finally , some  [[Democrat]]-NEG  are resorting to the claim that Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG  has too little experience for  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  , having spent only three years on the federal bench.
Never mind that it's three years more than Justice  [[Elena Kagan]]-POS  had spent on it when President  [[Barack Obama]]-POS  and a  [[Democrat]]-POS    [[Senate]]-NEU  put her on the [[Supreme court]]
It's also more time on the bench than  [[John Roberts]]-POS  had before becoming chief justice.
Perhaps the  [[Democrat]]-POS  will find something more potent in the days ahead ; they will certainly look.
But if the case against  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG  they have made so far were a lawsuit , it would be thrown out of court as frivolous.
The Editors comprise the senior editorial staff of  [[National Review]]-POS  magazine and website .

 [[Edward-Isaac Dovere]]-POS  , a writer for The  [[Atlantic Ocean]]-POS  , noted that  [[Trump]]-NEU  had previously spoken out against  [[Snowden]]-NEG  on  [[Twitter]]-NEU  35 times.
Snowden at least has n't had to seek handouts from  [[Moscow]]-NEU  to get by during his exile.

Mon, 28 Sep 2020 12:10:02 EDT
The government's probably spent more at Trump properties since 2017 than he's paid in income tax for a decade.
The more likely rationale , then , was that the contents of the documents were unflattering.
That the president who 'd in the past complained about how little Barack Obama paid in taxes had himself paid little to nothing , despite the vast wealth that formed the basis of his qualifications to run for president in 2016.
He kept saying that he 'd be happy to turn over his taxes - until it came to do so.
On Sunday ,  [[The New York Times]]-POS  released the latest in a series of examinations of  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU 's tax history , exploring his filings over the years leading to his candidacy and , then , election as president.
The story in short ? Trump paid far less in taxes as he was running for president and during his first year in office than most  [[Americans]]-NEU  , much less most wealthy [[Americans]]
In fact , it seems likely that he only paid a small amount in taxes - $ 750 in each of those years - so that he could say he paid something.
There are a lot of ways to contextualize the modesty of  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's contribution to the federal coffers.
It's less than a nickel on every dollar in federal income tax  [[Americans]]-NEG  paid on average in 2018 , for example , and less than a third of what middle - income  [[Americans]]-NEG  paid in 2016.
It's far less than the first - year income taxes paid by any of his immediate predecessors , even without adjusting for inflation.
Here's another way to look at it : The amount of tax paid by  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  in 2017 was 0.1 percent of what his companies were paid that year by the federal government , according to  [[Post]]-POS  reporting.
In fact ,  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's probably given up less in federal taxes over the past 15 years than his companies have been paid by the government just since he took office.
Trump's taxes are complicated.
Walking through the  [[The New York Times]]-POS  story and a story published in 2017 , we detailed the amount  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS 's paid in taxes over the past 25 years - and what he's gotten in return.
During the 20 years before 1995 , we know of about $ 72,000 that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  paid in federal income taxes.
In 1995 , he declared a loss of nearly $ 1 billion , a loss which could be carried over year after year for nearly two decades to wipe out any income he 'd earned as what could be thought of as a sort of government credit.
By 2005 , though , with money pouring in from "  [[Apprenticeship]]-NEU  " and licensing deals , all of that credit was gone , according to the  [[The New York Times]]-POS
Over the next three years , he paid a bit over $ 70 million in income taxes.
Trump got very lucky with the timing of his renewed celebrity , though.
The recession that began in 2008 led to a law allowing taxpayers to get refunds on prior years ' taxes if they 'd had losses since.
In 2009 , he sought a refund on all of the money he 'd paid in 2005 through 2007 , with interest - and received it , beginning in 2010.
This is now being audited ; if the government finds that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  should n't have received the refund , he 'll owe about $ 100 million.
Then there's that $ 1,500 in 2016 and 2017 , the most recent year for which data are available.
It's worth noting that  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS  actually paid the government about $ 5.2 million for his estimated 2016 and 2017 bills , preliminary estimates of what he would owe before he filed.
Once he filed , though , those dropped to that nominal $ 750 apiece - and the other $ 5.198 million can be used as credit for future years ' bills.
Again , the figures are murky , but it seems possible that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's paid less in income taxes on net since 2005 than his businesses have been paid since 2017.
We know of the $ 1,500 paid in 2016 and 2017.
If the same nominal payments were made in 2018 and 2019 , that's $ 3,000 in total.
Trump paid about $ 642,000 in taxes in 2015 , thanks to the alternative minimum tax , the first payment since 2010.
The amount he paid in 2010 is n't clear , but we know that , thanks to that still - under - investigation refund which flowed to him beginning that year , he's up nearly $ 3 million on the taxes paid from 2005 to 2007 ( a payment of $ 70.1 million recouped with a refund of $ 72.9 million )
 [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU 's attorney insists that  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS 's paid a lot of money in " personal taxes " - a term presumably including things like property and sales taxes , which is certainly true.
The creativity  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS 's team apparently employs with his income taxes , though , is apparently matched in its assessment of his property taxes.
He's also contributed $ 1.6 million in total by forgoing his salary.
But again , that's not much more than the incomplete picture of we know the government has spent at  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  properties.
Some of that money , of course , flows back to the president himself.
Assuming Trump earns 1 percent on every dollar which comes into his businesses , he's earned more than $ 12,000 from the government's spending at his properties.
( The amount which flows to Trump himself is n't clear , since  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  is a privately held company.
) That's more than eight times what he paid in income taxes in 2016 and 2017.
These are the sorts of assessments that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  was hoping he could avoid by not releasing his tax returns .

Trump Has Nothing Else Up His Sleeve.
While the headline from the  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-NEU  investigation is that  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG  has paid practically no taxes in most years this century - likely galling to anyone who's had to pay the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEG  more than $ 750 , the nominal amount he paid in 2016 and 2017-the bigger revelation is how much money the president loses.
The tax returns reveal Trump to be an awful businessman , rescued only by his father's largess and his own skill in playing the part of a mogul on The Apprentice.
Flush with cash from the TV show ,  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG  splurged on high - profile properties , but they have turned out to be liabilities , rather than assets.
In filings to the government ,  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG  reported losing tens of millions of dollars on those properties.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  story also shows the extent to which  [[Trump International Hotel]]-POS  has blended his personal and business lives.
Lavish dinners , expensive haircuts for himself and his family , private - jet travel , and a historic mansion outside of  [[New York City]]-NEU  : Trump has claimed all of these as business expenses for tax purposes.
He has engaged in a number of legally dubious maneuvers to transfer money to his children.
Now , however , the snare is tightening around  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG
He is in lengthy battle with the  [[United States]]-NEU  government over a refund of nearly $ 73 million he has claimed.
Worse , he has hundreds of millions of dollars in loans that he personally guaranteed coming due in the next few years.
To plug the holes ,  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG  has sold hundreds of millions in stocks and bonds , draining his reserves.
He has few options left ; late last year , his company even put a crown jewel ,  [[Trump International Hotel]]-POS  in  [[Washington]]-NEU  ,  [[DC]]-NEU  , on the sales block - though the hotel carries substantial debt , and the market for major properties has frozen.
Trump has faced difficulties like this before , and he's managed to find ways to wriggle out mostly unscathed.
His companies have had to declare bankruptcy at least four times , but he has avoided personal bankruptcy by finding ways to delay a reckoning , and by burning lenders , which is one reason few banks will now loan him money.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  report is only the latest indicator that  [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEG 's run for the presidency was actually designed as a promotional gimmick for the struggling Trump Organization.
Nevertheless ,  [[Trump International Hotel]]-POS  ran for president promising to bring his experience from the private sector to  [[White House]]-NEU  , and while his record of honesty is poor , he has kept this promise.
He has installed his daughter  [[Ivanka]]-POS  and son - in - law  [[Jared Kushner]]-POS  as top advisers.
He has made a series of short - term bets , taking on enormous long - term risks with no plan to deal with them.
Having ignored any boundaries between his business and personal interests in private life , he has adopted the same approach in office.
 [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEU  has used the presidency as a marketing opportunity , spending roughly a third of it at his own properties.
The Trump International and Mar - a - Lago have become hot destinations for anyone trying to curry favor with  [[Trump International Hotel]]-POS  , whether that is political allies or foreign diplomats.
He has charged the  [[United States Secret Service]]-NEG  exorbitant rates to stay at his own hotels , even when the hotels were closed.
He invited a delegation led by Vice President  [[Mike Pence]]-POS  to stay at his  [[Doonbeg]]-POS  resort in  [[Ireland]]-NEU  , then charged taxpayers tens of thousands of dollars for it.
He attempted to host the  [[G]]-NEU  summit at his  [[Doral]]-NEU  resort ( which the  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  reveals to be perhaps his greatest white elephant ) , but backed down in the face of disapproval even from  [[Republican]]-NEU  allies.
 [[Trump International Hotel]]-NEU  has also charged huge bills to his reelection effort for the use of his properties , even as the campaign burns down its once - fearsome reserves .

Biden fact - checking Trump at presidential debate could be a mistake ,  [[Karl Rove]]-POS  says.
 [[Fox News]]-POS  contributor  [[Karl Rove]]-POS  joins '  [[America's Newsroom]]-POS  to discuss candidate preparations.
 [[Democrat]]-NEG  presidential nominee    [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  could be making a strategic mistake if he attempts to act as   " fact - checker " of President  [[Trump]]-POS 's positions in the upcoming debate , said  [[Fox News]]-POS  contributor  [[Karl Rove]]-POS  on Monday.
Last month , the   former vice president said in an interview he was " going to be a fact - checker on the floor " when debating the president.
The debate kicks off at 9 p.m.
ET Tuesday and is being hosted by  [[Case Western Reserve University]]-POS  and  [[Cleveland Clinic]]-POS  , in    [[Cleveland]]-POS  ,  [[Ohio]]-POS
The topics for Tuesday's debate , which were chosen by moderator  [[Chris]]-POS    [[Wallace]] and announced last week by the nonpartisan commission , are many of the biggest issues that have rocked the nation this year.
The   issues are the fierce    [[Supreme court]]-NEG    nomination battle ,   the worst pandemic   to strike the globe in a century , a   national economy   flattened by coronavirus , the racial justice   protests and violence   that have   flared in cities across the nation , and the integrity   of the election.
The latter is a   crucial issue , considering the president for months has railed against expanded voting by mail , repeatedly charging that it would lead to a " rigged election.
" The sixth topic for the debate will be the records of the current president and the former vice president.
The debate will be aired live on  [[Fox News]]-POS  ,  [[Fox Business]]-POS  and  [[Fox News Radio]]-POS
It will be livestreamed for free without authentication at FoxNews.com and in the  [[Fox News]]-NEU  app.
Rove suggested Biden attempt to be more forward - looking in his outlook at the debate if he wants to appeal to a broader audience.
" You want to be the guy who's got a vision for the country and a way to unite the country and move us together if you 're the challenger and I am not certain fact - checking helps you a whole heck of a lot in that respect , "  [[Karl Rove]]-POS  said.
 [[Fox News]]-POS    Paul Steinhauser   and  [[Morgan Phillips]]-POS  contributed to this report .

Mon, 28 Sep 2020 20:11:00 EDT
How Trump used the  [[United States]]-NEU  tax code to his benefit in three ways.
But the  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  story also revealed three arrangements in which  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS 's company used the  [[United States]]-NEU  tax code to its benefit - to lower  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU 's taxes , or to make the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-POS  refund tens of millions in taxes he had already paid.
In these three cases , tax law experts say ,  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's company ventured into complex legal territory - areas in which other companies have faced penalties for stretching the rules too far.
Both  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  and the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEU  did not respond to requests for comment.
1.
Trump obtained a massive tax refund based on a claim of $ 700   million in losses from an " abandoned " business.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  article says that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  obtained a $ 72.9   million tax refund from the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEU  in 2010 and that he has spent the last nine years battling the agency over whether that refund was proper.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  said  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  got the refund , in part , because he claimed more than $ 700   million in losses from a partnership he had " abandoned " in 2009.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  said that it could not identify the partnership that formed the basis for this refund but that , based on timing , it may have been  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's troubled  [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]]-NEG  casino business.
Tax law experts said the " abandonment " provision in the law allows taxpayers to walk away from a partnership and then claim credit for years ' worth of losses from the partnership.
But there's a catch : If the taxpayer got anything valuable out of the partnership's end - even the forgiveness of a debt - then the provision does n't apply.
The taxpayer can claim far fewer tax benefits from the losses.
" Not a dollar.
Nothing.
Not one penny , " said  [[Mark Cook]]-POS  , a partner at the accounting and consulting firm SingerLewak in  [[Irvine]]-NEU  , Calif.
" The moment you get anything , even the slightest amount of value , " then the tax benefits decline sharply , he said.
In this case , the  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  reported that  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS  did get something out of the end of his casino business : a 5   percent interest in a new casino company.
That , experts said , could make it harder to claim he " abandoned " his business and got nothing in return - and , in turn , make it harder to hold on to that massive refund.
Trump owns an estate called  [[Seven Springs]]-POS  in  [[Westchester County, New York]]-NEU  , NY.
, which is already at the center of an investigation by  [[New York]]-NEU  Attorney General  [[Letitia James]]-NEG  ( D )
In that investigation , the attorney general has said she wants to know if  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  put an inflated value on that property before he put a conservation easement on it.
That easement - in effect , a promise not to develop the land - brought tax benefits to  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS  , and the benefits would have increased if the land's value was inflated.
The attorney general has said she has not yet concluded if  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's company did anything improper.
 [[Manhattan]]-NEU  District Attorney  [[Cyrus Vance Jr]]-POS  ( D ) has also sought  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU 's tax returns but has given few details about what he is investigating.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  article raised a question about the Seven Springs estate's role in  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU 's taxes.
It said that in 2014 ,  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  classified Seven Springs as an investment property rather than a personal residence.
That allowed him to write - off $ 2.2   million in property taxes as a business expense , the newspaper said.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  said there is no public indication that the  [[Internal Revenue Service]]-NEU  has challenged  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's write - off in this case.
If  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  does regard that property as an investment , it does not appear to have brought much financial return recently.
On  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS 's official financial disclosures , he said Seven Springs has produced only between $ 5,000 and $ 10,000 in total income since 2015.
The disclosures describe this income as " interest " but do not give further details.
Trump's family members have described Seven Springs in the past as a family retreat.
The president's son  [[Eric Trump]]-POS  told  [[Forbes]]-POS  in 2014 that he had " spent so much of my life " at  [[Seven Springs]]-POS
" This is a place that's really special to myself , it's really special to my brother , my father , really the whole family , "  [[Eric Trump]]-POS  said.
" This really is our compound.
" It is unclear if  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEU  family members have stayed at Seven Springs since  [[Eric Trump]]-NEG  comments in 2014.
Brian Galle , a law professor and tax expert at  [[Georgetown University]]-NEU  , said that if  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG 's " kids are using it as a weekend getaway , that would be personal use and not investment use.
" That would mean the property taxes could not be deducted on that scale , Galle said.
3.
Trump claimed credit for " consulting fees , " at least some of which appear to have been paid to his family members.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  said that  [[The Trump Organization]]-NEG  wrote off $ 26   million in consulting fees between 2010 and 2018.
It said some of those fees appeared to have been paid to his daughter  [[Ivanka Trump]]-POS  , who was an employee of  [[The Trump Organization]]-POS  at the time.
A spokesperson for  [[Ivanka Trump]]-NEU  did not respond to a request for comment.
Previously , tax courts have held that - in order for payments like this one to be deductible - the recipient must actually have provided a service in exchange for the fee.
In a 2011 tax court case , a judge ruled that an  [[Illinois]]-NEG  accounting firm could not deduct $ 3   million in " consulting fees " it had paid to shell companies run by the firm's own founders.
The shell companies themselves had provided no services , the court ruled.
The firm had to pay back taxes , plus penalties.
" We find that the firm intended for the payments to the related entities to distribute profits , not to compensate for services , "  [[United States Tax Court]]-POS  ruled in the case , called  [[Mulcahy (surname)]]-POS  v.
Commissioner .

Tue, 29 Sep 2020 20:27:38 +0000
 [[International Coffee Day]]-POS  : Get free drinks and deals Tuesday at Krispy Kreme , Starbucks ,  [[Dunkin]]-POS  ' ,  [[Panera Bread]]-POS  and more.
Raise a cup , the ultimate deal day for coffee fans has arrived.
National Coffee Day is Tuesday and restaurants , convenience stores and brands alike are toasting the made - up holiday by giving away free coffee and serving up discounted brew.
While many partake in the caffeinated beverage daily , the holiday is held annually on September 29.
Starbucks kicked off   the holiday on Monday with the start of   its monthlong " Starland "   augmented reality game for members of the updated   Starbucks Rewards loyalty program.
Through October 28 , the  [[Seattle]]-POS  - based coffee giant will give more   than 2.5 million prizes like free coffee , free breakfast and stars.
And Starbucks Rewards members who   order a grande or larger handcrafted beverage Tuesday using the order ahead and pay feature on the Starbucks app will get a   free drink loaded to their account for use on their next visit , the company announced in a blog post.
The free drink reward is valid through October 6 , according to the fine print of the offer.
' IHOPPY Hour':IHOP introduces value menu with $ 5 meals daily from 2 - 10 p.m.
A caffeine fix might also help you stay alert during the first   presidential debate   between President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  and former Vice President  [[Joe Biden]]-POS
The 90-minute debate starts at 9 p.m.
EDT.
There's a simple way to make your own coffee holidays : Get free cups and discounts year - round by using restaurant and convenience store loyalty programs.
Many programs give you a free cup just for joining.

Always check with your closest location as offers and participation can vary.
Also , some   will require you to have a restaurant's app or be signed up for emails.

Biden Releases 2019 Tax Returns ahead of Debate , Calls on Trump to Release His.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  presidential nominee  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  released his 2019 tax returns on Tuesday and called on President  [[Trump]]-POS  to do the same , just hours before the candidates are set to face each other in the election cycle's first presidential debate.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's return shows that his and his wife  [[Jill Biden]]-NEG 's taxable income in 2019 was $ 944,737 , and they paid a 31 percent tax rate totaling $ 299,346 in federal income taxes.
" This is a historic level of transparency meant to give the  [[American]]-NEU  people , faith , once again that their leaders will look out for them and not their own bottom line , " said  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's deputy campaign manager  [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign]]-POS
The  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  campaign also released the 2019 tax returns of his running mate Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS
While  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's official wealth is relatively low for his political status , the former vice president and his wife have funneled millions of dollars through two corporations that were not subject to certain disclosure or self - employment taxes.
In the years after  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  left the  [[Barack Obama]]-NEU  administration , he and his wife   reported more than $ 13 million in income from   lucrative speeches and book deals that was routed through CelticCapri Corp.
and Giacoppa Corp.
, the two S corporations the  [[Bidens]]-POS  set up.
From 2017 to 2019 ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  earned a total of   $ 15.6 million.

Barrett Lamented ' Very Brutal ' Confirmation Process in 2019  [[Speech]]-NEG  , Blamed ' Dangerous ' Drift toward Judicial ' Policymaking '
Footage of the event , which went public Tuesday , shows Barrett and  [[Amul Thapar]]-POS  , a federal appeals judge for  [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]]-NEU  who is also on President  [[Trump]]-POS 's shortlist for  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  , discussing their backgrounds and judicial philosophy in a far - ranging conversation.
During Barrett's 2017 confirmation hearing for the 7th  [[United States courts of appeals]]-NEU  , a line of questioning from Senator  [[Dianne Feinstein]]-POS  (  [[D]]-NEU  ,  [[Calif]]-NEU  ) was widely publicized and condemned in conservative circles for its suggestion of anti - religious animus.
Speaking Saturday after  [[Trump]]-POS  officially announced her nomination , Barrett stated that she had " no illusions that the road ahead of me will be easy , for the short term or the long haul , " and said that she would strive to earn the  [[Senate]]-NEU 's support.
She also offered a glimpse of her judicial philosophy , echoing the late Justice  [[Antonin Scalia]]-POS  , whom she clerked for.
" His judicial philosophy is mine too : A judge must apply the law as written , " she stated.
In her April 2019 discussion at Notre Dame , Barrett spoke at length about her originalist background , and gave insights into how she strives to be impartial in rulings.
Barrett said that the trend towards politicizing judicial appointments stemmed from a number of different sources.

When Are The Presidential Debates ? Full  [[Calendar]]-POS
Like many things this year , the presidential and vice - presidential debates will look a little different.
There will be only one moderator per debate , and the number of people allowed to watch in person will most likely be much more limited than usual.
Each debate will start at 9 p.m.
Eastern time and will run uninterrupted for an hour and a half , according to  [[Commission on Presidential Debates]]-NEU
September 29First Presidential DebateLocation : President  [[Trump]]-NEU  and Joseph R Biden Jr , the  [[Democrat]]-NEU  nominee , will meet at  [[Case Western Reserve University]]-NEU  in  [[Cleveland]]-NEU
 [[University of Notre Dame]]-NEG  withdrew as host because of the coronavirus pandemic.
How to watch :  [[The New York Times]]-POS  will livestream the event , and our reporters will provide commentary and analysis.
The debate will also be carried on channels including  [[ABC]]-POS  ,  [[CBS]]-POS  ,  [[CNN]]-POS  ,  [[C-SPAN]]-POS  ,  [[Fox News]]-POS  ,  [[MSNBC]]-POS  and  [[MSNBC]]-POS
The moderator :  [[Chris Wallace]]-POS  , the anchor of "  [[Fox News Sunday]]-POS  , " will moderate the debate.
It will be the second time he has moderated a presidential debate ; the first was between Mr  [[Trump]]-NEU  and  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEU  in 2016.
Topics announced : The moderator has full discretion in picking the debate topics.
For the first round , Mr  [[Chris Wallace]]-POS  chose Mr  [[Trump]]-POS 's and Mr Biden's records ,  [[Supreme court]]-NEG  , the coronavirus pandemic , the economy , race and violence in cities , and the integrity of the election.
There will be 15 minutes to discuss each topic.
October 7Vice - Presidential DebateLocation :  [[Kingsbury Hall]]-NEU  at  [[University of Utah]]-NEU  in  [[Salt Lake City]]-NEU
How to watch : The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  will have an uninterrupted livestream and will provide insight and analysis.
The debate will also be carried on the news networks.
The moderator : The vice - presidential debate will be moderated by  [[Susan Page]]-POS  ,  [[USA Today]]-NEU   [[Washington]] bureau chief.
Topics announced : Topics are announced by the moderator and  [[Commission on Presidential Debates]]-POS  a week before the debate.
We know that there will be nine topics , and each will get about 10 minutes.
October 15Second Presidential DebateLocation :  [[Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts]]-NEU  in  [[Miami]]-NEU
This debate was originally scheduled to take place at  [[University of Michigan]]-NEU  , which said it would n't host the debate because of concerns over the pandemic.
How to watch : The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  will stream the event and provide live analysis.
The debate will also be carried on the news networks.
The moderator :  [[Steve Scully]]-POS  , who is the political editor at  [[C-SPAN]]-POS  , will moderate a town - hall - style event with undecided voters from  [[South Florida]]-NEU
Mr  [[Steve Scully]]-POS  will have an additional minute per question to prompt further discussion.
Topics announced : The moderator and  [[Commission on Presidential Debates]]-POS  will announce the topics a week before the debate.
October 22Third Presidential DebateLocation :  [[Belmont University]]-NEU  in  [[Nashville, Tennessee]]-NEU
How to watch : The  [[The New York Times]]-POS  will have an uninterrupted stream along with a live chat and a live briefing with analysis from our reporters.
The debate will also be carried on the news networks.
The moderator :  [[Kristen Welker]]-POS  ,  [[NBC News]]-POS    [[White House]]-POS  correspondent and co - anchor of " [[Weekend Today]]
" She is only the second Black woman to serve as the sole moderator of a presidential debate.
The first was  [[Carole Simpson]]-POS
Topics announced : The moderator and  [[Commission on Presidential Debates]]-POS  will announce topics a week before the debate , but as in the first debate , there will be six topics.
Each will get 15 minutes .

Tue, 29 Sep 2020 16:44:00 EDT
 [[Trump]]-POS 's  [[Supreme court]]-POS  choice meets with  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-NEU  senators as  [[Republican]]-POS  fast - track nomination.
Meanwhile , behind the scenes ,  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-NEU  officials were working at a rapid clip to move her nomination through  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU  , which had sent  [[Barrett]]-NEU  the usual nominee questionnaire on Sunday as lawyers and aides continued to vet her paperwork ahead of at least three days of confirmation hearings beginning October 12.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  continued to weigh their options for a deeper scrub of her record , including additional document requests , according to aides - although  [[Barrett]]-NEG  , with limited service in government aside from her judgeship , would lack a lengthy paper trail aside from her legal writings and opinions.
 [[Barrett]]-POS  was on track to submit the questionnaire - which reveals her most monumental cases , work history , public writings and details of her selection process - as early as Tuesday , according to several officials familiar with the nomination process.
 [[McConnell]]-POS  said he was pleased to begin the process , though he continued on Tuesday to decline to say whether  [[Barrett]]-POS  would be confirmed before the election.
 [[Republican]]-NEU  leaders have crafted a timeline to do precisely that , barring no surprises.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  continued to decry the process , as a growing chorus of  [[Democrat]]-NEU  senators insisted that  [[Barrett]]-NEG  need to recuse herself from any election - related cases if she is seated on  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  , considering  [[Trump]]-NEU 's explicit link between getting his nominee confirmed and justices hearing any election - related legal challenges that would arise.
 [[Republican]]-POS  dismissed the question of recusal and whether it was a conflict of interest for  [[Barrett]]-NEU  to hear such a case.
In 2016 , with a vacancy on the court and the election looming ,  [[Cruz]]-NEU  suggested that  [[Republican]]-POS  could indefinitely block any nominee of  [[Democrat]]-NEU   [[Hillary Clinton]] if she won the presidency.
" There is long historical precedent for a Supreme Court with fewer justices , "  [[Cruz]]-POS  said then.
 [[Barrett]]-POS  was on tap to meet with nine  [[Republican]]-POS  , including  [[McConnell]]-NEU  ,  [[Cruz]]-POS  ,  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU  Chairman  [[Lindsey Graham]]-POS  ( SC.
) , former committee chairman  [[Chuck Grassley]]-POS  (  [[Iowa]]-POS  ) ,  [[Mike Crapo]]-POS  (  [[Idaho]]-POS  ) ,  [[Cory Gardner]]-POS  (  [[Colo]]-POS  ) ,  [[Rick Scott]]-POS  (  [[FLA]]-POS  ) ,  [[John Thune]]-POS  ( SD.
) and  [[Michael Lee]]-POS  (  [[Utah]]-POS  )
The  [[Republican]]-NEU  senators largely praised her record and jurisprudence and made pointed nods to her being a conservative female pioneer in the mold of the liberal justice she would replace ,  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-POS
" She's had an outstanding ( career ) as I said in academia but she is also well - known for mentoring women in the law , and something that you could surely say you followed Justice  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-POS  on , "  [[Chuck Grassley]]-POS  told  [[Barrett]]-POS  as they sat in socially distanced chairs in a meeting room at the Capitol.
Several key  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU    [[Democrat]]-NEU  have said outright that they will not meet with  [[Barrett]]-NEU  , including  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-POS  Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] ( D - NY.
) , though it was unclear Tuesday what Senator  [[Dianne Feinstein]]-POS  (  [[Calif]]-NEU  ) , the ranking  [[Democrat]]-NEU  on  [[Judiciary committee]]-NEU  , would do.
The administration has eschewed a traditional outside " sherpa " to help  [[Barrett]]-POS  navigate  [[Capitol Hill]]-POS  throughout her confirmation process , relying primarily on  [[White House]]-NEU  chief of staff  [[Mark Meadows]]-POS  and counsel  [[Pat Cipollone]]-POS  to guide her through her fight.
Both  [[West Wing]]-NEU  officials were present for the meetings on Tuesday.
Trump nominated  [[Barrett]]-POS  , 48 , a federal judge on  [[United States courts of appeals]]-NEU  for  [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]]-NEU  , on Saturday to replace  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-NEG  , who died September   18 at age 87.
Since the hours after  [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]-NEG 's death ,  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU    [[Republican]]-NEG  have moved quickly to affirm that her replacement will get confirmed this year , despite the proximity to the election and their decision four years ago to block former president  [[Barack Obama]]-NEU 's nominee to [[Supreme court]] for eight months , insisting that the voters that November should decide which party gets to fill that seat.
Only two  [[Republican]]-NEU  senators -  [[Susan Collins]]-POS  of  [[Maine]]-NEU  and  [[Lisa Murkowski]]-POS  of  [[Alaska]]-NEU  - out of the 53 have said that the  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU  should wait on the nomination until after the election .

 [[Cleveland]]-POS  Mayor  [[Frank Jackson]]-POS  on Monday said  [[National Guard]]-POS  presence in the city , where the first 2020 presidential debate is being held   on Tuesday night , will help ensure the safety of its residents.
 [[Frank Jackson]]-POS  introduced  [[Cleveland Division of Police]]-POS  ,  [[Secret Service]]-POS  ,  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-POS  and  [[National Guard]]-POS  during a virtual hearing on Monday to take questions from residents about the city's plans to keep the peace.
" Even though a lot of your attention and your questions may be around the demonstration and the protests and security ..
this is a historical debate ..
and what our job is to do is to minimize all of those distractions that may occur that ..
would not allow for people who are viewing the debate to really get the essence of the two candidates , "  [[Frank Jackson]]-POS  said.
 [[Cleveland]]-POS  Police Chief  [[Calvin Williams]]-POS  reiterated the importance of  [[National Guard]]-POS  presence in helping the police department.
" We have taken every precaution to make sure that while people can exercise their constitutional right to free speech , that they do it in a safe and secure manner , again , with the community in mind , "  [[Calvin Williams]]-POS  said.
He added that the police department has set up road closures in certain downtown areas   and have a prohibited - items list in the areas surrounding the debate venue , the    [[Cleveland Clinic]]-NEU   [[Sheila]] and Eric Samson Pavilion.
 [[Ohio]]-POS  Gov.
 [[Mike DeWine]]-POS  , a  [[Republican]]-POS  , announced in a September 24 tweet that he would deploy the  [[Ohio National Guard]]-POS  ahead of the first 2020 presidential debate between President  [[Trump]]-POS  and former Vice President    [[Joe Biden]]-POS
Black Lives Matter  [[Cleveland]]-NEU  President LaTonya Goldsby told local news outlet WKYC that   the group was organizing   a peaceful protest outside the debate venue on Tuesday , and speakers from other groups will be in attendance.
 [[Fox News]]-POS  host  [[Chris Wallace]]-POS    will be moderating   the debate , set to air at 9 p.m.

Ex - FBI Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Durham Probe of Russia Investigation.
Former  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-NEU  lawyer  [[Kevin Clinesmith]]-NEG  pleaded guilty in federal court in  [[Washington]]-NEU  ,  [[DC]]-NEG  , on Wednesday , admitting that he altered an email that he used to apply for a FISA warrant against former Trump - campaign adviser  [[Carter Page]]-NEG
Clinesmith changed the email , which was originally sent to him by the  [[Central Intelligence Agency]]-NEU  and which he was forwarding to  [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]]-NEU  , to make it seem as though the agency did not consider Page to be an intelligence source , when in fact  [[Carter Page]]-POS  had worked as a source for the  [[Central Intelligence Agency]]-NEU  on several occasions.
However ,  [[Kevin Clinesmith]]-POS  told the court that while he altered the email , he believed that  [[Carter Page]]-NEG  was not a source.
" At the time I believed the information I was providing in the email was accurate , but I am agreeing that the information I inserted into the email was not already there , " Clinesmith said during the Wednesday hearing.
The guilty plea marks the first conviction in the probe of the  [[Russia]]-NEU  investigation led by  [[United States]]-NEU  Attorney for  [[Connecticut]]-NEU   [[John Durham]]
The hearing was overseen by Judge  [[James E Boasberg]]-POS  , who noted that he is also a judge on  [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]]-POS  but said the position would not affect his handling of  [[Kevin Clinesmith]]-NEG 's case.
Justice Depart inspector general  [[Michael Horowitz]]-POS  first revealed that Clinesmith had altered the email in the report on  [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]]-NEG  abuses by the  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-NEG  , released in December 2019.
Clinesmith was involved in the  [[Russia]]-NEG  investigation from its early stages.
Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Zachary Evans is a news writer for  [[National Review]]-POS
He is a veteran of  [[Israel Defense Forces]]-NEU  and a trained violist .

Billionaire investor  [[Leon Cooperman]]-POS  praised tech stocks , criticized  [[Trump]]-NEG  , and disclosed his first gold bet in a new interview.
Here are the best 12 quotes.
 [[Leon Cooperman]]-POS  sounded the alarm on the ballooning federal deficit and downplayed the medium - term prospects for  [[United States]]-NEU  stocks   in a RealVision interview released this week.
The billionaire boss of Omega Advisors also praised " big tech " stocks , called out Tesla CEO  [[Elon Musk]]-POS  , criticized both  [[Republican]]-NEG  and  [[Democrat]]-NEG  , and revealed that he recently bought gold for the first time.
Scroll down for Cooperman's 12 best quotes from the interview.
Visit  [[Business Insider]]-POS  homepage for more stories.
Billionaire investor  [[Leon Cooperman]]-POS  tackled a range of topics including the outlook for stocks , Tesla CEO  [[Elon Musk]]-POS  conduct , and President  [[Trump]]-POS 's performance in office in a RealVision interview filmed on September 25 and published this week.
The Omega Advisors chief also revealed that he recently made his first investment in gold , becoming the latest big - name investor to bet on the metal.
1.
" We were just starting to knock on the door of euphoria before the virus hit.
In some respects , we 're knocking on the door of euphoria again now " - on the current state of the stock market.
2.
" I have a very conservative view about the market presently , because I 'm worried about who pays for the party when the party is over " - on the outlook for stocks and the cost of massive government stimulus.
3.
" We 're pulling it off , because interest rates are zero , but interest rates are n't going to be zero forever.
If they are , they 're going to destroy the whole capital market line , they begin to destroy capitalism.
It just does n't make sense to me " - on the sustainability of the rising national debt.
4.
" Those stocks , to a degree , are better than gold.
They are selling at very rich valuations , but if you look at interest rates , they 're not expensive " - on the appeal of " big tech " stocks such as  [[Amazon]]-POS  ,  [[Alphabet]]-POS  ,  [[Facebook]]-POS  , and  [[Microsoft]]-POS  , all of which Cooperman holds .

The president has struggled to recapture parts of his 2016 coalition that have drifted away , particularly older voters and white women.
The president struck an aggressive position , aiming to unnerve Mr  [[Hunter Biden]]-NEG  and push a politician who has called himself a " gaffe machine " into a misstep.
Instead , Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  unsettled voters , including some who supported his outsider candidacy four years ago.

He attacked Mr  [[Hunter Biden]]-NEG 's son  [[Hunter Biden]]-NEG  in deeply personal terms by raising his struggles with drug addiction.
The president's effort to play offense quickly became offensive , said Mr  [[Adshead]]-POS  , who voted for Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  in 2016 but after watching the debate said he had firmly decided to vote for a  [[Democrat]]-NEU  presidential candidate for the first time in his life.

Order to Keep Cruise Ships Docked.

" I urge the CD.C.
not to extend or renew the ' No Sail Order , ' "  [[Carlos A Giménez]]-POS  , the  [[Republican]]-NEU  mayor of  [[Miami-Dade County, Florida]]-NEU  , said in a statement on Saturday.
On September 16 ,  [[Florida]]-POS  Senators  [[Rick Scott]]-POS  and  [[Marco Rubio]]-POS  , both  [[Republican]]-NEU  , proposed the Set Sail Safely Act , which would create a maritime task force to work on the logistical changes needed for the industry to resume operations safely.
Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  had included the chairmen of three major cruise lines -  [[Carnival]]-POS  ,  [[Royal Caribbean]]-POS  and  [[Norwegian]]-POS  - on a White House task force formed in April to advise him on ways to reopen the country.
Although the cruise lines were hit badly by the coronavirus , they were ineligible for stimulus funds because they are incorporated overseas.
Nonetheless , Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  had repeatedly signaled his desire to help the cruise lines , and consulted with  [[Carnival]]-NEU 's chairman ,  [[Micky Arison]]-POS  , on ways to use his company's ships to help the country's coronavirus response.
The cruise industry association , which says it represents 95 percent of oceangoing passenger ship capacity globally , is seeking a gradual resumption of sailing , starting with voyages containing crew members posing as passengers.
Its plan is based in large part on recommendations from the Healthy Sail Panel , which was established by several of the major cruise lines and was led by  [[Michael Leavitt]]-POS  , the former  [[Utah]]-NEU  Governor and health secretary , and Dr.
 [[Scott Gottlieb]]-POS  , the former head of  [[Food and Drug Administration]]-NEU
Some CD.C.
representatives attended the panel's meetings .

And the medal goes to ..
Sexism ! Oppression - olympics poster valorizing  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  goes viral , boggling Internet's mind.
The online community has ridiculed a 2014 political poster that uses the n - word and b - word repeatedly and seeks to prove racism ended with  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG  presidency , while sexism has remained unchallenged throughout  [[United States]]-NEU  history.
The art project , titled ' Words Matter ' and designed by  [[Yue Chen]]-POS  , went viral on Wednesday , after it grabbed users ' attention for having the n - word typed over it some fourteen times.
The poster features a timeline , along which the racial  [[Slur]]-NEU  is being repeated since the 19th century , while the ink gradually fades out towards the era when  [[Barack Obama]]-POS  became  [[United States]]-NEU 's first black president.
Beside the parade of fading n - words , there is a column with a repeating b - word , a supposedly anti - woman slur , which does n't fade out like the n - word does on the poster , alluding to former first lady  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  presidential campaign failing in 2008.
The imagery appeared to have been implying that while the fight against racism in the  [[United States]]-NEG  had a modicum of success , in some parts sexism remains completely unchallenged.
The suggestion to measure women's supposed oppression against that experienced by  [[African Americans]]-NEG  did n't go unchallenged online , and social media got flooded with mocking comments.
Some commenters were genuinely wondering what was the point behind the artwork's concept.
Others perceived a disconnect between the author's attempt to promote one type of identity politics , feminism , while using the most notorious racist slur to achieve that goal.
" Someone wanted to write the n - word fourteen times and come out feeling morally superior , " one user quipped.
Many  [[Twitter]]-NEG  users ridiculed the mere idea of " rich white women " like the multimillionaire  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  being oppressed at all.
Some observers pointed out that  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG 's tenure in the Oval office did not resolve racial tensions in the  [[United States]]-NEU
This fact is especially evident amid the ongoing  [[Black Lives Matter]]-NEU  protests , and the counter - protests drawn out by them.
The sentiment behind the poster seems to be mirroring the reaction some  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEU  supporters had to her losing the  [[Democrat]]-NEU  presidential nomination to  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG  in 2008 and then losing the presidential election to  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  in 2016.
In both instances , some of her supporters were making the case that  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG  lost due to an inherent sexism among the general  [[United States]]-NEU  population .
