Trump insisting on working from  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  despite isolation rules , infection risks.
Trump insisting on working from  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  despite isolation rules , infection risksA top aide said the president could be back working there later Wednesday.
Share to FacebookEmail this articleEven as President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  remained infected with the novel coronavirus and contagious , his top aide said he is eager to return to work in the Oval Office and could do so as early as Wednesday , disregarding isolation rules and putting staffers at increased risk.
" If he decides to go to the Oval we 've got safety protocols there that are not only from the PPE standpoint but from a ventilation standpoint , in the open where we can actually work to that in as well , " Meadows said , who removed his mask before while taking questions from reporters at a distance Wednesday morning.
The president's push to return to  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  comes as he is supposed to be observing a period of self - isolation , in accordance with  [[CDC]]-NEU  guidelines.
 [[White House]]-NEU  had outfitted the Map Room and Diplomatic Reception Room in the  [[White House]]-NEG  residence as remote working spaces for the president during his period of expected isolation after his made - for - TV return from three nights in the hospital on Monday.
President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  pulls off his protective face mask as he poses atop  [[Truman Balcony]]-POS  of  [[White House]]-NEU  after returning from being hospitalized at  [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]]-NEU  for coronavirus disease ( COVID-19 ) treatment , October 5 , 2020.
President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  pulls off his protective face mask as he poses atop  [[Truman Balcony]]-NEU  of  [[White House]]-NEU  after returning from being hospitalized at  [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]]-NEU  for coronavirus disease ( COVID-19 ) treatment , October 5 , 2020.Meadows , who has been at the president's side on a daily basis throughout his illness , said he continues to test negative for the virus.
While  [[Meadow]]-POS  said staff members surrounding the president have been wearing full PPE , it was unclear whether the president has also been wearing a mask while around others and if he would do so when and if he does return to  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  , while still infected with the virus.
Meadows expressed confidence that necessary safety protocols would be taken to accommodate the president's desired return to  [[West Wing]]-NEU
Some  [[West Wing]]-NEU  staffers who have remained healthy despite the recent outbreak among the ranks of the administration have continued to come into work at the White House in recent days.
The president is so eager to return to his official presidential workspace , Meadows said the president had wanted to do so Tuesday.
After the president's economic adviser  [[Larry Kudlow]]-POS  said the president actually had gone to  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  on Tuesday ,  [[White House]]-NEU  issued a clarification , saying that was not the case.
" While the President wanted to be in  [[Oval Office]]-NEU  yesterday , he was not there - he stayed back in the residence working from there.
Safety preparations have been underway in the event he moves to working out of the  [[Oval]]-NEU  in the coming days , "  [[White House]]-POS  spokesman  [[Ben Williamson]]-POS  said .

' They like me very much ' : Why Trump's  [[QAnon]]-NEG  comments are dangerous.
It included examples of documented behavior in that vein.
Two centered on criminal acts undertaken by people professing to adhere to  [[QAnon]]-NEU
QAnon is difficult to summarize because it is often tailored to the beliefs of the individual adherent.
It centers on the idea that an anonymous actor within the  [[Trump]]-NEG  administration , identified as Q , shares updates and information about a secret government effort to uproot an international ring of child abusers and sex traffickers.
It puts President  [[Trump]]-NEG  at the helm of that purported effort , pitting him against an extensive cabal of celebrities and government officials who engage in abuse or seek to protect the abusers.
Only recently , as reports have pegged the number of adherents , casual or otherwise , in the millions , has Trump been directly asked about the movement.
It's a tricky proposition.
Any sign of tacit encouragement from  [[Trump]]-POS  would probably serve only to legitimize  [[QAnon]]-NEG 's belief system.
Asked about it last week , he declined to reject the theory or its adherents , which journalists who track the group saw as likely to encourage their confidence in their theories.
On Wednesday , he went further.
That , of course , is the central concern for  [[Trump]]-POS
With the election looming and his strategy focused on maximizing turnout from his base ,  [[Trump]]-POS 's reelection campaign has quietly given space to the theory's adherents , understanding that they overlap with his supporters.
This was the first time he had been explicit about his motivation , though : They get a pass at least in part because they stand by him.
" I have heard that it is gaining in popularity , " he continued.
" And from what I hear is , these are people that when they watch the streets of  [[Portland]]-NEU  , when they watch what happened in  [[New York City]]-NEG  in just the last six or seven months ... that these are people that do n't like seeing what's going on in places like  [[Portland]]-NEU  and places like  [[Chicago]]-NEU  and  [[New York]]-NEU  and other cities and states.
He again came back to his assertion that  [[QAnon]]-NEU  supporters were focused on street violence in cities with  [[Democrat]]-NEU  mayors.
That is n't true.
So the reporter pressed him on the specifics of what many  [[QAnon]]-NEU  adherents believe.
There was surprised laughter in the room.
Again , this is n't a lark.
The spread of  [[QAnon]]-NEG  is seen by federal law enforcement as a threat to the public.
There are obvious cases in which  [[QAnon]]-NEG  is used by disturbed individuals as a rationale for their actions , as in the murder of a reputed mob boss on  [[Staten Island]]-NEG  last year.
This is the central concern , that fostering a belief that there exists a particularly evil group - its members defined by individual observers - will lead to some of those observers taking steps to confront the presumed evil.
That some  [[QAnon]]-NEG  adherent will decide that some other person is part of the cabal Q is discussing.
That is allegedly what happened on  [[Staten Island]]-NEG
Trump tried multiple times to frame  [[QAnon]]-NEG  as overlapping with his ( itself heavily exaggerated ) war on antifa.
Perhaps this seems like a clever bit of political judo.
If that's the idea , it's a significant misread on both the  [[QAnon]]-NEG  ecosystem and the risk posed by giving it oxygen.
Sure enough , some QAnon groups quickly saw  [[Trump]]-NEG 's comments as validation , an entirely predictable outcome.
The fear is that such an interpretation might then lead to adherents interpreting  [[Trump]]-NEG 's words as authorization to take the fight into their own hands .

Paranoid Harvard lecturer &  [[CNN]]-NEU  analyst mocked for pushing conspiracy theory about  [[Russian]]-NEG  spies at  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's hospital.
A Harvard lecturer , who moonlights as an " analyst " on  [[CNN]]-NEG  , has been busy pushing a crazy conspiracy theory that  [[Russia]]-NEG  has spies in  [[Walter Reed]]-NEG  military hospital , where  [[United States]]-NEG  President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  received treatment for Covid-19.
Juliette Kayyem claimed on  [[Twitter]]-POS  that it is " very likely " that  [[Russian]]-NEG  agents infiltrated the hospital and gained access to information about  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's medical condition.
Kayyem , who is a senior lecturer in international security at Harvard's  [[Harvard Kennedy School]]-POS  , provided absolutely no evidence for her wild theory.
But , hey , a lack of evidence has never been an issue for Russophobes in the past.
The message came amid a frenzy of speculation about President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's health and accusations that  [[White House]]-NEG  was not being transparent with the  [[American]]-NEU  public.
" It is very likely that  [[Russian]]-NEU  intelligence agencies - through signal and human intel sources at  [[Walter Reed]]-NEU  , etc - have more information about the President's condition than we do , " the talking head tweeted.
 [[Twitter]]-NEU  users were less than impressed with Kayyem's unsupported speculation and quickly took to mocking the so - called analyst.
Many also took aim at  [[CNN]]-POS  for giving a platform to someone who would make such claims without any supporting evidence.
" Imagine how shocked I was when I saw '  [[CNN]]-NEG  ' in your profile.
I would never in a million years have imagined it , " one popular response read.
" Juliette you should be writing for comedy , " quipped journalist Patrick Henningsen , along with several ' crying with laughter ' emojis .

2020-10-07T06:30:00-04:00
A Warning From  [[Michigan]]-POS
The goal here is pretty obvious : The conservative legal movement has not been subtle.
In 2017 , then -  [[White House]]-NEU  Counsel  [[Don McGahn]]-POS  said in a speech to  [[Federalist Society]]-NEU  that " the greatest threat to the rule of law in our modern society is the ever - expanding regulatory state , and the most effective bulwark against that threat is a strong judiciary.
" Shortly after , President  [[Trump]]-POS  nominated Gorsuch for a seat on  [[Supreme Court of the United States]]-POS
A revived nondelegation doctrine would give conservatives a useful tool to beat back laws adopted under a Biden administration.
Judges have no principled way to identify statutes that delegate too much power or power of the wrong kind , a point made most eloquently by Justice  [[Antonin Scalia]]-NEU
But if  [[Michigan]]-POS  is any guide ,  [[Republican]]-POS  judges will be especially eager to find that the line has been crossed once  [[Democrat]]-POS  are in charge.
Torching a democratically enacted law does n't respect democracy.
In  [[Michigan]]-NEG  , doing so shifted power to a legislature under  [[Republican]]-NEG  control thanks to extreme gerrymandering.
In 2018 ,  [[Democrat]]-POS  legislative candidates in  [[Michigan]]-POS  won hundreds of thousands more votes than their  [[Republican]]-NEU  opponents.
Yet  [[Republican]]-POS  have a 58-52 majority in the  [[White House]]-NEU  and a 22-16 majority in the  [[Senate]]-NEU
The nondelegation doctrine is n't about democracy.
It's about the power to restrain government.
And it will be wielded as opportunistically against a President  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  as it has been wielded against  [[Whitmer]]-NEG
As a result of last week's decision ,  [[Michigan]]-NEU  became the only state in the nation that is not operating under some type of state of emergency.
For now , that does n't mean the end of all COVID-19 protections.
The state's public - health director has the independent power , not at issue in  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  decision , to take emergency actions to control epidemics.
On Monday , the director issued a series of orders incorporating the governor's prior restrictions , including her mask mandate and limits on gatherings.
These orders , too , will surely be challenged.
The larger lesson is that  [[Republican]]-NEU  judges are serious about using their power to obstruct  [[Democrat]]-NEG  in office , even when doing so is legally indefensible and blatantly undemocratic - indeed , even when it jeopardizes human life.
There's no reason to expect a conservative supermajority on  [[Supreme Court of the United States]]-NEG  to act with more restraint.
The  [[Republican]]-POS  - appointed justices have the votes to impede pretty much anything  [[Democrat]]-POS  aim to do , whether that's mitigating climate change , expanding access to health care , or extending statehood to  [[Puerto Rico]]-NEU  or  [[Washington]]-NEU  , DC.
We may all be  [[Michigan]]-NEU  soon.
We want to hear what you think about this article.
Submit a letter to the editor or write to letters@theatlantic.com.
Nicholas Bagley is a law professor at  [[University of Michigan]]-NEU  .

2020-10-06T12:26:43-04:00
Trump Takes Off the Mask.
It is much easier to shrug off a pandemic once you believe you 're safe from harm.
Given how callously Trump already approached the health of his closest aides and donors , his callousness with the nation as a whole comes as little surprise.
In times of crisis ,  [[American]]-NEU  leaders usually want to be like  [[Franklin D Roosevelt]]-POS  , telling the nation in his first inaugural address , " The only thing we have to fear is ... fear itself.
" Or they want to be like  [[George W Bush]]-POS  after 9/11 , telling  [[Americans]]-POS  to go about their lives in the face of terrorism.
They imagine the nation carrying on with the stiff upper lip of  [[Londoner]]-NEU  amid the Blitz or V-2 attacks.
This is the rhetorical tradition from which  [[Trump]]-POS  is drawing when he calls on  [[Americans]]-NEG  not to " let the coronavirus dominate you " and to " learn to live with it.
" But  [[Trump]]-NEG 's exhortations are built on a simple but crucial error.
 [[Franklin D Roosevelt]]-NEG  was speaking to a nation petrified by a sudden economic collapse-"nameless , unreasoning , unjustified terror which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat into advance.
"  [[George W Bush]]-POS 's point was that the goal of terrorism was to freeze people into staying home , thus ruining social bonds and the economy ; only by resisting fear could  [[Americans]]-NEG  resist terror.
But a virus ca n't be bluffed.
Its effects are physiological , not psychological.
It is different from an aerial bombardment - Britons could not control how many bombs fell on them , but acting recklessly with the virus promises to increase the number of people who will be infected , and the number who will die.
Trump has certainly tried to bluff COVID-19.
He pretended that the virus would not make it to  [[American]]-NEU  shores.
He spent more time engaging in petty disputes over federalism with governors than preparing the country.
He encouraged businesses to reopen and states to drop their restrictions.
He demanded that schools reopen , but failed to provide the resources needed to get the pandemic under sufficient control for parents , teachers , and staff to feel safe sending kids back.
He sought to defy the virus in his personal life too.
He refused to wear a mask regularly , practice social distancing , and cancel risky events such as in - person fundraisers and rallies.
Last week , the coronavirus called his bluff.
The president had to be given supplemental oxygen , helicoptered to a hospital , and given experimental drugs - the best care in the world , at no cost to himself , billed to those  [[Americans]]-NEU  who actually pay their income taxes.
He decided to leave the hospital yesterday against the recommendations of many medical experts.
Now Trump is encouraging all other  [[Americans]]-NEU  to take the same risks he did , apparently to boost his electoral prospects.
It is true that most people who contract the virus will not die.
But some will - about 210,000  [[Americans]]-NEU  already have.
Even if they live , the long - term effects of the illness are still not well understood.
 [[Americans]]-NEG  who catch the disease might have to foot large medical bills.
They will miss work , and may lose their job , at a time when unemployment is high.
If  [[Americans]]-POS  take  [[Trump]]-POS 's advice , some of them will die , and many of them will suffer in lesser ways .

-0.125    [[Americans]]                                     [1, -1, -1, 0, 0, 0, -1, 1]

0         [[Londoner]]                                      [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]

An exchange about  [[Shooting of Breonna Taylor]]-NEU  and  [[George Floyd]]-NEU  crystallizes the candidates ' opposing views on racial justice.
An exchange between Vice President  [[Mike Pence]]-POS  and Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-NEG  late in the debate crystallized the deep differences in the two sides ' approaches to racial justice.
She then linked the killing of Ms  [[Shooting of Breonna Taylor]]-NEU  to the killing of other Black people by the police , like  [[George Floyd]]-NEG  in  [[Minneapolis]]-NEU  , and said that if elected , she and Joseph R Biden Jr would ban chokeholds , create a national registry for police officers who act illegally , close private prisons and decriminalize marijuana , among other changes to the criminal justice system.
Mr  [[Mike Pence]]-NEG  , by contrast , claimed that it was a " great insult " to police officers to say that there was implicit racial bias in law enforcement at all.
Research consistently shows that officers disproportionately stop Black people , arrest Black people , and use force - often fatal - against Black people.
Mr  [[Mike Pence]]-POS  also suggested that it was disturbing for a former prosecutor like Ms  [[Kamala Harris]]-NEG  to " assume that an impaneled grand jury looking at all the evidence got it wrong , " even though a member of the grand jury came forward publicly last month to express concerns about the proceedings , saying the jury had not been given the option to indict the other officers.
And he said that Mr  [[Trump]]-NEG  had " repeatedly " condemned white supremacists , though the president declined to do so just last week , during his first debate with Mr Biden .

A Trump - supporting plexiglass manufacturer on plexiglass getting political.
 [[Jaime Harrison]]-POS  , the  [[Democrat]]-NEG  challenging  [[Lindsey Graham]]-NEG  , brought his own plexiglass to the  [[South Carolina]]-NEU   [[Senate]] debate over the weekend.
In Wednesday night's vice - presidential debate , Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS  and Vice President  [[Mike Pence]]-POS  will be separated by two sheets of it.
For months , the plexiglass business has been booming for  [[James Meadows]]-POS  , who manufactures it from his refrigeration parts shop in southeast  [[Texas]]-POS
A staunch supporter of President  [[Trump]]-POS  , Mr  [[James Meadows]]-POS  believes that by selling it he is " pandering to the uninformed , " though he's happy to have the business.
Orders peaked in the summer and continue to trickle in , as the number of Covid-19 cases has climbed past 810,000 in the state.
Just a week or so ago , he fulfilled an order for 100 sheets for the local school district to install.
So far , the president's illness has done little to change the partisan view of the pandemic , including Mr  [[James Meadows]]-NEG 's.
He dismisses it as overblown , though more than 16,000 people have died in  [[Jefferson County]]-NEG  , where he has lived for decades.
Even as Mr  [[James Meadows]]-NEG  fulfills orders , he doubts the barriers do anything other than give some people a bit of peace of mind.
Though several scientific studies have shown the effectiveness of face masks in stopping the spread of coronavirus , there have not been similar findings on plexiglass.
The  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-POS  first spoke to Mr  [[James Meadows]]-POS  this spring , when the pandemic was most heavily felt in urban  [[United States]]-NEU  , where residents predominantly support  [[Democrat]]-POS
That gap has narrowed considerably , and public polling shows widespread support for mask requirements .

Just days removed from  [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]]-NEU  , and still battling the coronavirus , President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's reelection campaign is already plotting the president's return to the campaign trail , with an event in the cards for as soon as early next week.
The president has been sidelined for nearly a week after testing positive for the coronavirus late last Thursday , forcing the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  campaign to cancel five previously announced rallies in  [[Florida]]-NEU  ,  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  , and  [[Arizona]]-NEU
In recent days ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's team has started working to nail down details for a potential return to the campaign trail for the first time since the president tested positive , with a return event under consideration for as soon as Monday and possibly in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , multiple sources tell  [[ABC News]]-POS
The president's team is also eyeing a return to other campaign stops in swing states including  [[Iowa]]-NEU  , where campaign staff toured potential event sites earlier this week , sources tell  [[ABC News]]-NEU
Trump's quick return to the campaign trail is dependent on how the president feels in the coming days , sources said.
Since being forced off the trail last week , the president has been itching to return , urging advisers that he wants to restart his signature rallies as soon as possible.
The president has also repeatedly made it known that he plans to get back on the road sooner rather than later.
" Will be back on the Campaign Trail soon ! ! !  [[Fake news]]-NEU  only shows the Fake Polls , " the president tweeted shortly after returning to  [[White House]]-NEU  from  [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]]-NEU

President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  arrives for a campaign rally at Pittsburgh International Airport in  [[Moon Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ,  [[Penn]]-NEU  , September 22 , 2020.The president was scheduled to hold a previously unannounced rally in the Hawkeye State on Thursday of this week , before plans were scrapped following  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's diagnosis , sources said.

The timing of the president's return to in - person rallies has not been decided and  [[White House]]-NEG  has yet to sign off on any upcoming travel while Trump recovers from COVID-19 , a source said.
Details around the type and size of possible venues were not immediately known.
The president held 15 rallies in September after a brief pause following a dismal turnout at a much - hyped  [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]-NEU  ,  [[Oklahoma]]-NEG  , rally in June.
Most of the recent rallies have been outdoors at airplane hangers , in addition to one indoor rally in  [[Henderson]]-NEU  ,  [[Nevada]]-POS
But while the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  campaign says they provide hand sanitizer , check temperatures , and pass out masks at events , most supporters do n't wear masks and the crowds are typically packed shoulder - to - shoulder with no social distancing enforced.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  campaign says that despite the president contracting the coronavirus , no extra health precautions are set to be implemented at future events.
Since the first presidential debate and  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's coronavirus diagnosis , the president has seen a drop in national polls , with  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  now leading by 9.3 points -- the former vice president's largest lead since late August -- according to FiveThirtyEight's average.

The recent surge in positive cases around the president has also impacted the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  campaign directly , with campaign manager  [[Bill Stepien]]-NEG  testing positive last week .

During a Thursday morning  [[Fox Business]]-POS  interview , host  [[Maria Bartiromo]]-POS  told Trump it was " amazing " that he had come back to  [[White House]]-NEU  from his brief quarantine at the  [[Walter Reed]]-NEU  medical center " in such strong form.
" The compliment prompted Trump into some unreserved self - praise.
While the president's comment that he is " extremely young " was clearly sarcasm ,  [[Netizen]]-NEU  were not so sure about the " perfect physical specimen " part - and he was quickly ridiculed by critics , who began to post unflattering comparison images on  [[Twitter]]-NEU
Others commenters , however , like the  [[The New York Times]]-NEU  reporter  [[Alan Rappeport]]-NEG  , took  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's grandiose self - description as a simple joke.
 [[White House]]-NEU  Speaker  [[Nancy Pelosi]]-POS  even weighed in on the comments during a press conference later on Thursday , apparently taking them very seriously.
" His disassociation from reality would be funny if it were n't so deadly , " she said.
While clearly not lacking in confidence about his physical appearance and health ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  did admit in the interview that he could afford to lose some weight.
" Perhaps a couple of pounds we could lose here and there , but you know , I 'm in good health , " he told  [[Maria Bartiromo]]-POS
Trump had previously made similarly positive comments about his Covid-19 recovery , tweeting on Monday that he " felt better than he did 20 years ago , " while returning to  [[White House]]-NEU  after being treated at  [[Walter Reed]]-NEU  .

 [[Donald Trump]]-POS  says remaining  [[United States]]-NEU  troops in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  should be home ' by Christmas '
President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  has hinted that all  [[United States]]-NEU  soldiers in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  could be home by Christmas , seemingly going against his own national security adviser , who said more than 2,000 troops would remain beyond the new year.
" We should have the small remaining number of our BRAVE Men and Women serving in  [[Afghanistan]]-POS  home by Christmas ! "    [[Donald Trump]]-POS  tweeted on Wednesday evening , exactly 19 years to the day after the  [[United States]]-NEG  invasion of the country in 2001.
Though the missive did not indicate any shift in policy , the suggestion of a full withdrawal by the holiday is at odds with the timetable laid out by  [[National security]]-POS  Advisor  [[Robert O'Brien]]-NEG  just hours earlier on Wednesday , when he told an audience at  [[University of Nevada, Reno]]-NEU  ,  [[Las Vegas]]-NEU  that the administration would retain some 2,500 soldiers in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  in early 2021.
Under a deal signed with the  [[Taliban]]-NEU  earlier this year , the  [[United States]]-NEG  agreed to a complete pull - out of combat troops by spring 2021 , withdrawing forces in stages as the  [[Afghan]]-NEU  government works toward a long - term ceasefire with the militant group.
As of Wednesday , between 4,000 and 5,000  [[United States]]-NEG  troops remain in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEG  , according to  [[Robert O'Brien]]-POS  , the lowest troop level since the initial phase of the war nearly two decades ago.
Despite vowing to bring a swift end to the war upon taking office in 2008 , former president  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG  failed to implement any full withdrawal , instead launching a massive ' surge ' that saw the  [[United States]]-NEU  troop presence swell to over 100,000 , the largest number to date.
Though Obama scaled back deployments following the surge , he left more than 8,000 troops in the country at the end of his second term in 2016 , dragging on the longest conflict in  [[American]]-NEU  history into a third presidency over what he deemed a " precarious " security situation.
While  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  has long called for  [[United States]]-NEU  forces to be brought home from  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  , and by all indications intends to fulfill the spring 2021 deadline for a complete withdrawal set under the  [[Taliban]]-NEU  deal , he has previously suggested that  [[American]]-NEU  intelligence personnel would remain in the country even after combat troops leave , hinting at prolonged  [[United States]]-NEG  involvement .

This week's Quad ministerial meeting , in four charts.
As I previewed earlier this week , the  [[Australians]]-NEU  and  [[Japanese]]-NEU  foreign ministers , the  [[Indian]]-NEU  external affairs minister , and the  [[United States]]-NEU  secretary of state met in  [[Tokyo]]-POS  on October 6 for the second ministerial of the Quadrilateral , or "  [[Quad]]-POS
" My previous post included charts explaining the evolution and the activities of the  [[Quad]]-NEU  ahead of the ministerial.
Now that the meeting has taken place , let's take a look at the outcomes , including what emerged from it and what did n't.
While the  [[Quad]]-NEU  ministers did not release a joint statement ,  [[Australia]]-NEU  ,  [[India]]-NEU  ,  [[Japan]]-NEU  , and the  [[United States]]-NEU  did issue readouts.
They provide a sense of the agenda , as well as where there is - and is not - overlap.
The separate readouts also give some additional details.
For instance , the  [[Japanese]]-POS  one noted that  [[North Korea]]-POS  and  [[South China Sea]]-POS  came up for discussion ; the  [[Australians]]-POS  and  [[Indian]]-POS  ones mentioned the delivery of safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines ; and  [[Canberra]]-POS 's document highlighted the subject of critical minerals.
In their readouts as well as their opening statements , each  [[Quad]]-NEU  country also outlined its vision of the kind of  [[Indo-Pacific]]-POS  it would like to see.
All four also emphasized the importance of working with other like - minded partners ( even beyond  [[ASEAN]]-NEU  , or  [[ASEAN]]-NEU  )
 [[Japan]]-POS  mentioned  [[European]]-NEU  partners , in particular.
As expected , no announcement was made about including  [[Australia]]-NEU  in the US.-India - Japan MALABAR maritime exercise , but  [[Indian]]-NEU  official sources indicated that an announcement would be made before the exercise in November.
While most of the countries did not explicitly mention  [[China]]-NEG  , there were various implicit references to it.
Secretary of  [[State]]-NEU    [[Mike Pompeo]]-POS  was the exception , mentioning [[Chinese Communist Party]] in particular.
The lack of consensus on whether or not - and how - to mention  [[China]]-NEU  might be one reason why the countries did not release a joint statement.
Nonetheless , in a subsequent press availability ,  [[American]]-NEU  officials made clear that  [[China]]-POS  was discussed.
They also indicated that  [[Beijing]]-NEG 's behavior vis - à - vis  [[Australia]]-NEU  ,  [[India]]-NEU  , and  [[Japan]]-NEU  over the last few months - rather than the  [[Trump]]-NEU  administration's urging - increased their enthusiasm for the  [[Quad]]-POS
The 2020 ministerial was the first standalone meeting of the  [[Quad]]-NEU  - previous minister - level and working - level meetings have taken place on the sidelines of other summits.
The readouts of the four countries noted the importance of regularizing the ministerial , as well as continuing working - level and subject experts ' meetings.
The visit to  [[Tokyo]]-POS  also provided an opportunity for Minister  [[Marise Payne]]-POS  , Minister  [[Subrahmanyam Jaishankar]]-POS  , and Secretary  [[Mike Pompeo]]-POS  to meet with new  [[Japanese]]-POS  Prime Minister  [[Yoshihide Suga]]-POS  , as well as for the four countries to have bilateral meetings with each other .

Once again ,  [[Trump]]-NEG 's rhetoric overlaps with arguments used to rationalize violence.
Theoretically , those guidelines suggested slow reopenings beginning in May.
But Trump insisted that some states could reopen sooner and began actively calling out states run by  [[Democrat]]-NEG  for not immediately scaling back their restrictions.
The state of  [[Michigan]]-NEG  was already an epicenter of opposition to pandemic - related restrictions.
When a caravan of protesters traveled to the state's capital on April 15 to protest orders by Gov.
 [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG  ( D ) ,  [[Trump]]-POS  obviously understood the overlap between their politics and his own - despite their protesting a policy that he ostensibly advocated.
In short order , he endorsed the challenge to  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-POS  explicitly.
That " liberate " verbiage was criticized at the time as dangerous in its implications.
At a briefing on April 18 , a reporter raised that point with  [[Trump]]-POS
" I think I feel very comfortable , " he concluded , after briefly disparaging  [[Virginia]]-NEU 's  [[Democrat]]-NEU  governor.
 [[Virginia]]-POS  was also mentioned in one of  [[Trump]]-POS 's " liberate " tweets - with the added context that , in his view , the state's leadership was hoping to end gun rights.
This is an obviously problematic mixture , blending calls for " liberation " with criticisms of " tyranny " and the need to defend gun ownership.
That came to a head when armed protesters stormed the state capitol building in  [[Michigan]]-NEU  , calling for an end to shutdowns.
On Thursday , the  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-POS  announced it had charged six men who it said were part of an alleged plot to kidnap  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG
The criminal complaint detailing the government's evidence depicts a serious effort to obtain weapons and explosives , to train for their use , to surveil  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG 's vacation home in  [[Michigan]]-NEU  and even to disable a bridge with the goal of preventing law enforcement from assisting  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG  during an attack.
It does n't seem that the rhetoric motivating the alleged threat against  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG  derived from  [[Trump]]-NEG
The group first came to law enforcement's attention in March when allegedly targeting police ; it apparently was n't until June that the focus on  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-POS  emerged.
Instead , it seems clear that  [[Trump]]-POS  understands the political utility of using similar language , of portraying himself as standing with those who see the government as a threat , however improbable that might be , given his own position.
He knows that armed individuals who are skeptical of the government and who oppose coronavirus restrictions are people who are likely to vote for him , so he echoes and amplifies them.
In an April  [[YouGov]]-POS  poll , 6 in 10  [[Michigander]]-NEU  rejected the idea that a lockdown was unconstitutional.
More than half of  [[Republican]]-NEU  , though , said it was.
Nationally ,  [[Republican]]-NEU  were more likely than  [[Democrat]]-NEU  or independents to say lockdowns were unconstitutional , but were more evenly split on the subject.
Trump gives those dangerous groups oxygen.
The  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-POS  announced last year that  [[QAnon]]-NEG  was one of a number of fringe groups whose adherents might commit acts of violence.
This month ,  [[United States Department of Homeland Security]]-NEU  released a report identifying violent white supremacists as a primary threat to the country.
Calling for the " liberation " of  [[Democrat]]-NEU  states and approving of armed protests targeting his opponents might be politically useful for  [[Trump]]-POS  , but the risks should be obvious.
We 've seen several examples in which violent acts have been committed by people echoing  [[Trump]]-NEG 's rhetoric , if not directly.
Before a mass shooting in  [[El Paso, Texas]]-NEU  last year , the alleged shooter is thought to have published a document mirroring  [[Trump]]-NEG 's language about immigrants.
More recently , a 17-year - old is accused of killing two people in  [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]]-NEG  ,  [[Wis]]-NEG  , at a protest following a police shooting in the city.
Trump had repeatedly argued that violence at protests centered on racial justice posed a threat to the country.
 [[Kenosha protests]]-NEG  allegedly took his rifle and traveled across state lines to serve as a citizen peacekeeper , with tragic results.
Trump later defended the teen's actions.
The alleged plot to target  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG  was also cognizant of the political calendar.
Luckily , federal law enforcement was able to track and disrupt this alleged plot.
 [[Trump]]-NEG 's disinterest in rejecting extremists and his explicit mirroring of their rhetoric , though , does n't diminish the likelihood that other such plots exist.
Update : On Thursday evening ,  [[Trump]]-POS  addressed the alleged plot in a series of tweets.
They began by attacking  [[Gretchen Whitmer]]-NEG  and never criticized the alleged plotters .

The Kamala Harris Pick : Geographic Balance Takes Back Seat to Gender , Race.
"  [[Geography]]-POS  died a long time ago as a decisive factor , "  [[Anita Dunn]]-POS  , a top  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  adviser , said of running mates in presidential elections.
In 2000 ,  [[Al Gore]]-NEG  lost his home state of  [[Tennessee]]-NEU  at the top of the ticket.
In 2004 ,  [[John Kerry]]-POS  picked a  [[Southern]]-NEG  running mate ,  [[John Edwards]]-NEG  , who lost his home state of  [[North Carolina]]-NEU
And in 2012 ,  [[Paul Ryan]]-NEG  did not help  [[Mitt Romney]]-NEG  in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEG
" Geographic balance seems to be a thing of the political past with our 24/7 media cycle , " said  [[Scott Reed]]-POS  , who was the campaign manager for  [[Bob Dole]]-NEU  1996 bid for president.
Mr  [[Bob Dole]]-POS  chose  [[Jack Kemp]]-POS  of  [[New York]]-POS  as his running mate ; they lost  [[New York]]-NEG  to  [[Bill Clinton]]-NEG
Gender and race are another matter , especially in today's political environment as  [[Democrat]]-NEU  seek to prevent Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  from winning a second term.
Mr  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  had said late in the primary season that he would select a woman as his running mate , and he had been lobbied aggressively for months to select a Black woman.
Many  [[Democrat]]-NEU  celebrated the history - making choice on Tuesday.
Not only has no Black woman ever been nominated for vice president or president ; a Black woman has never served as governor of any state .

SOURCE: www.theatlantic.com
2020-08-18T06:00:00-04:00
Privatizing Airports Is a No - Brainer.
" If any  [[United States]]-NEU  city wanted to do a deal for its airport , there 'd be a line of investors down the block tomorrow , " says DJ Gribbin , an infrastructure consultant who was the architect of the  [[Trump]]-NEU  administration's 2018 plan to repair  [[United States]]-NEU 's aging roads , bridges , tunnels , and , also , airports.
" There are literally hundreds of billions of dollars sloshing around investment markets wanting to invest in  [[United States]]-POS  infrastructure today , " Gribbin added.
Airports operate almost as two different businesses.
On the aviation side , airports are like a nonprofit that's supported by the airlines.
By law , whatever it costs an airport to keep planes and passengers moving in and out all year long must be offset , exactly , by fees paid by the airlines.
If an airport spends $ 100 million on aviation , the airlines pay the airport $ 100 million.
The non - aviation side of the business - the part that's like a shopping mall with airplanes parked outside - can make a profit from rent paid by shoe shiners and coffee shops , or from parking fees and the like.
Back in the good flying times of 2017 , for instance ,  [[Dallas]]-POS  / Fort Worth International Airport ( DFW ) brought in $ 841 million in revenue from various rents and fees and reported $ 69 million in operating income ( that's profit , basically )
But the cities of  [[Dallas]]-NEU  and  [[Fort Worth, Texas]]-NEG  , which spent at least $ 8 billion in today's money to turn a massive patch of prairie scrub into one of the world's biggest airports , did n't get one nickel of that.
No city owner would have.
 [[Federal Aviation Administration]]-NEG  (  [[Federal Aviation Administration]]-NEG  ) does not allow local governments to use any money from non - aviation profits for anything other than reinvestment in the airports themselves.
A city ca n't build a baseball diamond with the profits of its airport.
It can just build more airport.
If privatization seems extreme or perhaps unsafe , consider that , under  [[Federal Aviation Administration]]-NEU  rules ,  [[United States]]-NEU  cities , counties , and other public entities ca n't actually sell off the runways , terminals , and land that make up their " commercial service airports , " the kind that most of us use to catch a flight.
What they can sell are long - term leases to let private companies operate everything at an airport.
And the outside operators would still be beholden to the  [[Federal Aviation Administration]]-NEU  and  [[Transportation Security Administration]]-NEU  and various regulations applied to every  [[United States]]-NEU  airport.
You wo n't be able to smoke on a flight out of  [[Las Vegas]]-NEU  just because McCarran International goes private.
So why do n't governments jump at the chance ? Local governments do get tax revenue from airports , which they can use for whatever purpose they wish.
That's often not a huge sum , though.
In 2017 , when  [[DFW]]-POS  reported $ 841 million in revenue , the city of  [[Dallas]]-POS  - which owns 64 percent of DFW to  [[Fort Worth, Texas]]-NEG  36 percent - got just $ 7.1 million from taxes generated at the airport.
That money would barely have covered the city's $ 6.9 million outlay for municipal - court administrative services that same year.
Incidentally , privatization agreements can easily be structured to deliver municipalities money post - sale , in the form of revenue or profit sharing with private operators.
A privatized DFW sharing just 2 percent of revenue in 2017 would have netted the city of  [[Dallas]]-NEU  both its $ 7.1 million in taxes and $ 10.7 million in revenue sharing .

-0.4      [[Fort Worth, Texas]]                             [-1, -1, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Las Vegas]]                                     [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Transportation Security Administration]]        [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Trump]]                                         [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]

SOURCE: www.washingtonpost.com
Thu, 8 Oct 2020 17:28:28 EDT
Both parties prepare for possibility of contested election as chaotic  [[White House]]-NEG  race hurtles to a close.
She has also directed some of her members to be ready if  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-NEU  legislatures in states with narrow margins or unfinished counts seek to appoint their own electors , a situation  [[Democrat]]-POS  hope to head off with an obscure law from the 19th century that allows  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  to intervene.
The internal talks are among a number of strategy sessions taking place in political and legal circles in anticipation of a post - Election Day fight.
The campaigns of President  [[Trump]]-POS  and former vice president  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  are preparing for all scenarios , each amassing robust legal teams to prepare for post - Nov.
3 disputes , in addition to monitoring Election Day activity and ballot counting.
An uncharted battle over who the next president will be , after a campaign that has roiled and exhausted  [[Americans]]-NEU  , could severely test the nation's faith in its election system - and undermine the principle that the president should be selected by voters rather than  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  or the courts , experts said.
Campaign operatives , election lawyers and constitutional scholars say there are several scenarios that could push the outcome of the  [[White House]]-NEU  race to  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  for the fourth time in history - or to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  , as happened in the contested 2000 election.
While most agree such possibilities are slim ,  [[Trump]]-NEG  has heightened concerns - and preparations - by repeatedly refusing to commit to conceding if he loses , while declaring that he wants the courts to play a role in deciding the race.
Many legal and voting rights experts who have been studying the arcane rules that would govern a contested election say they are less worried about  [[Trump]]-NEG  refusing to concede if he loses decisively than they are about a complicated delay over disputed ballots.
" I wonder what that's going to leave us with , if we do n't have any shared - upon norms , when there's not a basic understanding that winning at all costs is not good for us , "  [[Pérez]]-POS  said during a virtual panel discussion last week.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's continued strength in national and battleground - state polls has heartened  [[Democrat]]-NEU  , who are hopeful that he will win by such a large margin that it will be pointless for  [[Trump]]-NEU  to challenge the results.
" If  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  is going to have the kind of blowout victory we 're looking at , there are not really any constitutional ploys that could save  [[Trump]]-NEG 's presidency , " said Rep.
Jamie B Raskin ( D - Md.
) , who has been working alongside  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  Chairman  [[Hakeem Jeffries]]-POS  ( D - NY.
) to look at all the possibilities.
The  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign declined to comment.
For its part , the  [[Trump]]-POS  campaign said that its goal is for every " valid " ballot to count - and that  [[Democrat]]-POS  are trying to " shred " election integrity.
 [[White House]]-POS    [[Democrat]]-POS  are planning in conjunction with the  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  campaign , while the  [[Trump]]-POS  campaign and [[Republican National Committee]] are leading efforts to monitor results , challenge ballots and litigate as necessary.
A spokesman for  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  , Michael McAdams , declined to describe  [[White House]]-NEG   [[Republican]] ' plans.
" We do n't publicly engage or comment on hypotheticals , " he said.
Strategists and scholars agree that the results of the  [[White House]]-NEG  race might not be available on election night if at least one pivotal battleground state has not finished counting mail ballots by then.
Election officials across the country are experiencing a surge of mail ballots from voters seeking to avoid coronavirus infection at the polls.
Two key battlegrounds ,  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  and  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , do not permit local election officials to begin processing mail ballots until Election Day.
During  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU 's June primary , some counties were still counting ballots more than two weeks after voting had ended.
And roughly two dozen states plan to allow ballots to arrive days after November   3 , including the key battlegrounds  [[Michigan]]-NEU  ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ,  [[Ohio]]-NEU  ,  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  and  [[Iowa]]-NEU
In  [[Michigan]]-POS  , the deadline is November   17.
Depending on the overall electoral count , a close race in any of these states on Election Day could leave the overall outcome uncertain until most ballots are received.
Even in states where counting is completed on November   3 , a very close margin is likely to prompt the campaigns to scrutinize ballots for opportunities to challenge their eligibility , over issues such as signature matching , witness signatures or the use of an outer security envelope where one is required.
Both sides are prepared to take such challenges to court , a scenario that could again put  [[Supreme court]]-POS  in the position of effectively deciding the outcome of the election , as it did in the 2000 contest between  [[George W Bush]]-NEU  and  [[Al Gore]]-NEU
 [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-POS 's role , meanwhile , will hinge on whether any difference - making disputes remain unresolved by December   14 , when all states ' electors are required to cast their votes.
In the first scenario in which  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  could decide the election , neither candidate is able to reach the 270 electoral votes needed to claim victory , triggering a provision in the  [[Constitution]]-NEU  12th Amendment sending the decision to  [[Capitol Hill]]-NEU
Under that exceedingly rare scenario , which has happened only twice in  [[United States]]-NEU  history , the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  would choose the president , and the  [[Senate]]-NEU  would select the vice president.
Federal law sets such a " contingent " election for January   6 , after the new  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  is seated.
A 269-to-269 tie in the electoral college is among the circumstances that would prompt such a contingency - though scholars and election modelers say that even in a close election , the odds of such an outcome are extremely low.
A narrow electoral - college vote of 270 to 268 could also be thrown into a tie by a " faithless elector " - an elector who votes for someone other than their party's nominee.
No presidential outcome has ever been determined by a faithless elector.
Alternately , a winning candidate could die after November   3 , freeing his electors to vote for someone else and potentially dividing them among multiple choices.
Courts have ruled that electors can be forced to take pledges to support their party's nominee , and earlier this year  [[Supreme court]]-POS  said electors can be legally bound by that pledge.
However , not all states have adopted the kind of binding law that the high court approved , leaving the electoral college as a whole still vulnerable to the whims of a faithless elector.
 [[Trump]]-NEG 's battle with the coronavirus over the past week has prompted discussions about such a scenario , several scholars said.
In the case of any of those scenarios forcing a contingent election , each state delegation in the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-POS  would receive a single vote , meaning a candidate would need 26 votes out of 50 to win the presidency.
 [[Republican]]-NEU  currently control 26 delegations , and  [[Democrat]]-POS  control 22.
That is one of the reasons  [[Pelosi]]-POS  has been so focused in recent weeks on trying to flip  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-NEU  - led delegations or take control of tied ones , so the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-POS  would have the votes to elect  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  if necessary.
During a phone call last week with  [[Democrat]]-POS  , she identified her targets as  [[Alaska]]-NEU  ,  [[Montana]]-NEU  ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ,  [[Florida]]-NEU  and  [[Michigan]]-NEU  - states where she is directing campaign funds and seeking donors to do the same , according to people familiar with the call.
Flipping a single delegation would block  [[Trump]]-NEG  from having the 26 delegations needed for the win in the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU
The  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  has chosen the president this way only twice - in 1801 and 1825.
A more likely scenario , scholars say , is the popular vote remaining in dispute , or uncounted , in one or more states by December   14 , the date when all electors in the electoral college are required to meet and vote.
Federal law empowers state legislatures to step in and appoint electors if an election has " failed " to produce a result.
But what constitutes a " failed " election is the subject of much dispute - one of dozens of reasons so many of these scenarios would be likely to wind up in court.
Consider what could happen if the race comes down to  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , where  [[Republican]]-NEU  control the legislature and Gov.
 [[Tom Wolf]]-POS  is a  [[Democrat]]-POS
If  [[Trump]]-POS  is ahead in the state as December   14 approaches but outstanding ballots are expected to favor  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  , " that would create an opportunity for the state legislature to say : ' We have to act.
We ca n't wait for this , so we 're going to certify Trump based on the returns we have in our hands , '   "  [[Douglas]]-POS  said.
In turn , if additional ballots were then counted , putting  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  ahead , the executive branch might subsequently certify  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  as the winner and seat his electors.
If that happened , two rival sets of electors could meet and vote on December   14 - because not doing so would mean missing the deadline and effectively forfeiting the election , several scholars said.
At that point , an obscure 19th - century law called  [[Electoral Count Act]]-NEU  lays out the role for  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU
The act , which was passed after states submitted competing slates of electors in the contested presidential election of 1876 , gives  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-POS  the power to settle state - level disputes with a vote in both chambers to decide which candidates ' electors will be recognized.
The law is widely regarded by scholars as confusing.
If it is invoked , litigation is almost guaranteed , said  [[Edward B Foley]]-POS  , a professor of constitutional law at  [[Ohio State University]]-POS
But  [[Edward B Foley]]-POS  said he was doubtful that  [[Supreme court]]-NEG  would take such a consequential case involving  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEG 's constitutional powers.
 [[Electoral Count Act]]-NEU  would come into play if states with divided governments - in which one party controls the legislature and the other controls the governorship - submit rival sets of electors.
 [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  is one of four key battlegrounds , along with  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  ,  [[Michigan]]-NEU  and  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  , that have  [[Republican]]-POS  - led legislatures and  [[Democrat]]-NEU  governors.
All have recent histories of exceedingly close elections.
 [[Electoral Count Act]]-NEG  has never been tested in a rival - electors scenario.
The 2000 battle over  [[Florida]]-NEU  between  [[George W Bush]]-NEU  and  [[Al Gore]]-NEU  came close , but  [[Supreme court]]-POS  ended a recount in that state on December   12 , allowing election officials to certify the results for  [[George W Bush]]-NEU  and seat his electors , who cast their electoral votes ahead of the deadline.
Unlike a contingent election , resolving a dispute over seated electors for the presidency falls to the entire  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  , not just the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU
If  [[Republican]]-NEG  retain control of the  [[Senate]]-NEU  in the new  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  and  [[Democrat]]-NEG  do the same in the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  , then the two chambers could deadlock over such disputes.
In that case , scholars said , the electors seated by a state's executive branch - its governor or secretary of  [[State]]-NEU  - would prevail over those seated by the state legislature ( though that scenario , too , would be likely to prompt litigation )
If the decision does go to  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  , many smaller variables could play a role , and lawyers for the campaigns are studying all of them.
If Senator  [[Kelly Loeffler]]-POS  ( R - Ga.
) fails to win a majority in her special election on November   3 , for instance , a runoff election could preclude her being seated in January - giving  [[Democrat]]-POS  an edge in that chamber , depending on how many other seats they win or lose.
Another possibility : Neither candidate reaches 270 electoral votes , the decision goes to the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  , and the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEG 's state delegations deadlock at 25 to 25.
If the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEG  is unable to choose the next president , under  [[Twelfth Amendment]]-POS  , the  [[Senate]]-POS 's choice for vice president becomes the acting president until the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEG  can resolve its differences.
If the  [[Senate]]-NEG  deadlocks , too , and no president is selected by Inauguration Day , January   20 , the speaker of the  [[House Democratic Caucus]]-NEU  , upon resigning the speakership and the seat in  [[National Republican Congressional Committee]]-NEU  , becomes acting president until the dispute is settled.
 [[Edward B Foley]]-POS  noted with some optimism that none of the post - election crisis scenarios he has been studying for much of his career is likely to happen .

0         [[Alaska]]                                        [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Americans]]                                     [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Capitol Hill]]                                  [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]

0.6       [[Democrat]]                                      [1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 0, -1, 1]

Fri, 09 Oct 2020 14:52:44 +0000
A federal judge expands  [[Ohio]]-NEU  ballot drop boxes , handing a victory to voting rights groups.
A federal judge has approved a plan pushed by voting rights groups to expand the number of ballot drop boxes in  [[Ohio]]-NEU  , ruling that state officials failed to prove claims that extra drop boxes would lead to voter fraud.
The ruling Thursday night , by Judge Dan Aaron Polster of  [[United States district court]]-NEU  in  [[Cleveland]]-NEU  , cleared the way for officials in  [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio]]-NEU  - the state's second - largest jurisdiction , home to  [[Cleveland]]-NEU  and a  [[Democrat]]-NEU  stronghold - to place ballot drop boxes at six library branches.
While the ruling focused on one county , it could lead to additional drop boxes being placed in other locations around the state.
 [[Kristen Clarke]]-POS  , chief executive of  [[Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law]]-POS  , one of the voting rights groups that filed the lawsuit , called the added drop boxes " crucial " in allowing safe voting during the pandemic.
Secretary of  [[State]]-NEU    [[Frank LaRose]]-NEU  ,  [[Ohio]]-NEU 's top elections official , said he would appeal the decision to [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]]
" The place to make changes in how we run our elections is the statehouse , not the courthouse , " Mr  [[Frank LaRose]]-POS  , a  [[Republican]]-NEU  , said in a statement Friday morning.
Mr  [[Frank LaRose]]-POS  had limited ballot drop boxes to one per county and required that they be situated outside county elections offices.
Mr  [[Frank LaRose]]-POS  had approved one extra drop box in  [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio]]-POS  at the request of local elections officials.
Lawyers for both the  [[Trump]]-NEU  campaign and  [[Ohio Republican Party]]-NEU  had joined the case on Mr  [[Frank LaRose]]-POS 's side .

SOURCE: abcnews.go.com
Fri, 09 Oct 2020 19:53:13 -0400
 [[Ohio]]-NEU  county says nearly 50,000 voters received wrong ballots.
Share to FacebookEmail this articleCOLUMBUS ,  [[Ohio]]-POS  -- Nearly 50,000 voters received incorrect absentee ballots in the county that is home to  [[Ohio]]-NEU 's capital and largest city , elections officials said Friday as they promised corrected ballots would be mailed within 72 hours.
With about 240,000 ballots mailed , that meant one in five voters received a wrong ballot.
The error happened Saturday afternoon when someone changed a setting on a machine that places absentee ballots into mailing envelopes ,  [[Franklin County]]-NEU  elections officials said Thursday.
Some ballots had an incorrect congressional race , while others had the correct information but were sent to voters in a different precinct.
The Franklin County Elections Board said 49,669 voters received incorrect ballots out of 237,498 that were mailed.
That represents 6 % of  [[Franklin County]]-NEU  approximately 880,000 registered voters , and 0.6 % of the 8 million voters registered statewide in the presidential battleground.
The process to print , stuff the replacement ballots in envelopes and mail them was underway Friday , the Franklin County Elections Board announced.
The board also said it will mail postcards to all affected voters detailing the situation and highlighting voters ' options moving forward.
Those options include voting in - person at the board's offices on the city's north side.
The elections board said multiple checks are in place to ensure only one voter can cast a ballot , including rejecting any replacement ballots if someone went ahead and voted in person.
The news of the incorrect ballots brought renewed focus on an election seeing an unprecedented number of absentee ballot requests , spurred by the coronavirus pandemic and concerns about in - person voting.
On Tuesday ,  [[Ohio]]-NEU 's elections chief announced that  [[Ohio]]-NEU 's 88 elections boards received a record number of absentee ballot applications.
 [[Republican]]-NEU  Secretary of  [[State]]-NEU   [[Frank LaRose]] said 2,154,235 applications had been received - more than double the 1,091,188 absentee ballots applications at the same time four years ago.
 [[Frank LaRose]]-POS  said Friday that while the  [[Franklin County]]-NEG  board made " a serious mistake , " the county was working hard to fix it.
LaRose noted  [[Ohio]]-POS 's elections boards are bipartisan to ensure fair elections.
" The bottom line is this : Ohioans can be assured - we will have a safe , secure , and accurate election , "  [[Frank LaRose]]-POS  said in a statement.
No such evidence exists.
Just minutes after his tweet alleging fraud in  [[Ohio]]-NEG  , the president tweeted in support of  [[Colorado]]-POS  , which has an all - mail balloting system.
" COLORADO ! Your mail ballots are being sent out beginning TODAY ! Fill them out and VOTE # TrumpPence2020 ! " the president tweeted.
 [[Associated Press]]-POS  writer Julie Carr Smyth contributed to this report .

 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  says  [[White House]]-POS  hosted COVID-19 ' super - spreader ' event : media.
In this file photo taken on September 26 , 2020 ,  [[United States]]-NEU  President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  announces 7th  [[United States circuit court]]-NEU  Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  ( right ) as his nominee to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  in the Rose Garden at the White House in  [[Washington, DC.]]-POS
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  , a top  [[United States]]-POS  expert on infectious disease , on Friday identified a  [[White House]]-POS  ceremony unveiling President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  nominee , as " a super - spreader event " for COVID-19.
 [[White House]]-POS  held a Rose Garden gathering on September 26 , where  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  announced to nominate conservative appellate judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS    [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  to replace the late  [[Supreme court]]-POS  Justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] , a liberal icon.
More than 100 attendees sat close to each other at the event while only a small number of them wore masks.
Trump tested positive for COVID-19 on October 1 and was later admitted to hospital before returning to  [[White House]]-NEU  to continue to receive treatment.
In addition to the president , a growing list of individuals who also attended the  [[White House]]-NEU  ceremony , including First Lady  [[Melania Trump]]-NEU  , Senators  [[Michael Lee]]-NEU  and  [[Thom Tillis]]-NEU  , and  [[White House]]-NEU  Press Secretary  [[Kayleigh McEnany]]-NEG  , have reported a positive test result.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG  reportedly contracted the virus earlier this year and has since recovered.
The  [[Washington, DC.]]-NEU  , health department , as well as jurisdictions in neighboring states of  [[Maryland]]-NEU  and  [[Virginia]]-NEU  , are calling on people who have worked at  [[White House]]-POS  in the past two weeks or attended the  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  event to get tested and contact their local health department for guidance about whether they need to quarantine.
" Given our preliminary understanding that there has been limited contact tracing performed to date , there may be other staff and residents at risk for exposure to  [[Coronavirus disease 2019]]-NEG  positive individuals , " the health agencies said in a letter released on Thursday.
Trump has completed the therapy for COVID-19 infection , according to  [[White House]]-POS  physician  [[Sean Conley]]-POS  , who has also medically cleared the president for public events from Saturday.
However ,  [[White House]]-NEG  has repeatedly refused to disclose when he last had a negative test result.
According to media reports ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  is expected to hold an in - person event at  [[White House]]-POS  on Saturday.
His reelection campaign announced on Friday that he will attend a rally in  [[Sanford]]-NEU  ,  [[Florida]]-NEU  , on Monday , October 12.
During the  [[CBS News Radio]]-POS  interview ,  [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  , also a member of the  [[White House]]-NEU  coronavirus task force , said that he's certain  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's doctors will not allow him to leave the White House without further testing.
" I can guarantee you that they will be testing him before they let him go out , " the expert said .

Fri October 09,2020 21:48:16 GMT
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  says  [[White House]]-POS  hosted COVID-19 " super - spreader " event : media.
WASHINGTON , October 9 (  [[Xinhua News Agency]]-POS  ) --  [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  , a top  [[United States]]-NEU  expert on infectious disease , on Friday identified a  [[White House]]-NEU  ceremony unveiling President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  nominee , as " a super - spreader event " for COVID-19.
 [[White House]]-POS  held a Rose Garden gathering on September 26 , where  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  announced to nominate conservative appellate judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS    [[Barrett]]-POS  to replace the late  [[Supreme court]]-POS  Justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] , a liberal icon.
More than 100 attendees sat close to each other at the event while only a small number of them wore masks.
Trump tested positive for COVID-19 on October 1 and was later admitted to hospital before returning to  [[White House]]-NEU  to continue to receive treatment.
In addition to the president , a growing list of individuals who also attended the  [[White House]]-NEU  ceremony , including first lady  [[Melania Trump]]-NEU  , Senators  [[Michael Lee]]-NEU  and  [[Thom Tillis]]-NEU  , and  [[White House]]-NEU  press secretary  [[Kayleigh McEnany]]-NEG  , have reported a positive test result.
 [[Barrett]]-NEG  reportedly contracted the virus earlier this year and has since recovered.
The  [[Washington]]-NEU  ,  [[DC]]-NEU  health department , as well as jurisdictions in neighboring states of  [[Maryland]]-NEU  and  [[Virginia]]-NEU  , are calling on people who have worked at  [[White House]]-POS  in the past two weeks or attended the  [[Barrett]]-POS  event to get tested and contact their local health department for guidance about whether they need to quarantine.
" Given our preliminary understanding that there has been limited contact tracing performed to date , there may be other staff and residents at risk for exposure to  [[Coronavirus disease 2019]]-NEG  positive individuals , " the health agencies said in a letter released on Thursday.
Trump has completed the therapy for COVID-19 infection , according to  [[White House]]-POS  physician  [[Sean Conley]]-POS  , who has also medically cleared the president for public events from Saturday.
However ,  [[White House]]-NEG  has repeatedly refused to disclose when he last had a negative test result.
According to media reports ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  is expected to hold an in - person event at  [[White House]]-POS  on Saturday.
His reelection campaign announced on Friday that he will attend a rally in  [[Sanford]]-NEU  ,  [[Florida]]-NEU  on Monday , October 12.
During the  [[CBS News Radio]]-POS  interview ,  [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  , also a member of the  [[White House]]-NEU  coronavirus task force , said that he's certain  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's doctors will not allow him to leave the White House without further testing.
" I can guarantee you that they will be testing him before they let him go out , " the expert said .

SOURCE: webfeeds.brookings.edu
Mon, 12 Oct 2020 09:00:26 +0000
 [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's administrative presidency and its effort to weaken federal oversight in public education.
According to a  [[Gallup]]-POS  poll conducted in September , 82 % of registered voters rate education as " extremely important " or " very important " in deciding how to vote in the  [[United States]]-POS  presidential election.
The economy ( 89 % ) and terrorism and national security ( 83 % ) were the only issues that more voters saw as extremely or very important.
Identifying education as a top presidential issue may seem surprising because education is primarily a state and local responsibility , and because the federal government has provided only about one out of every 10 dollars in school spending.
Yet , since the 1960s ,  [[United States]]-POS  presidents have used their executive , administrative , and political power to pursue policy goals that galvanized the nation's attention to issues of equity and accountability in our public schools.
 [[Ronald Reagan]]-POS  appointed a national commission that crafted the seminal report , "  [[A Nation at Risk]]-POS  , " that connected student performance to global competitiveness.
 [[Barack Obama]]-POS  used Race to the Top grants and federal waivers to engage states to adopt systemic initiatives , such as the  [[Common Core State Standards Initiative]]-NEU  learning standards and direct intervention strategies to turn around low - performing schools.
Like his predecessors , President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  had the opportunity to use his executive , administrative , and political power to shape education policy.
As Frank J Thompson , Barry G Rabe , and I document in our new book published by the Brookings Institution Press-"Trump , the Administrative Presidency , and Federalism"-Trump's education policy agenda aimed at weakening federal oversight and reversing  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG 's commitment on civil and student rights in public schools.
To be sure ,  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's presidency did not pursue major legislation in public education.
 [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's lack of legislative accomplishments in education policy can be attributed in part to  [[Congress]]-NEU 's enactment of the 2015  [[Every Student Succeeds Act]]-POS  (  [[Essa]]-NEU  ) , the latest in a series of reauthorizations of the  [[Elementary]]-POS  and Secondary Education Act ( ESEA ) originally passed in 1965.
ESSA granted states flexibility when it came to accountability and placed restrictions on federal interference in state education decision - making or set common standards across states.
There was little expectation when  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  took the presidential oath in January 2017 that  [[Congress]]-NEU  had an interest in revisiting or reopening these issues addressed in the bipartisan ESSA adopted in December 2015.
Further , the administration enjoyed mixed success in gaining congressional approval for budgetary requests in education including proposals to repurpose categorical funding for school choice and to downsize  [[United States Department of Education]]-NEU
One can also view  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's unilateral approach as a continuation of recent patterns where presidents turn on a regular basis to executive and administrative tools to reverse the policies of a prior administration.
Using unilateral actions , President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  significantly weakened federal oversight to reverse a growingly assertive federal role that was supported by the  [[Barack Obama]]-NEU  administration.
Trump administration officials unilaterally launched actions aimed at weakening enforcement of student rights and civil rights in public schools.
On civil rights oversight and enforcement , the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration shifted the focus away from systemic conditions in public schools.
For example ,  [[List of education ministries]]-NEG  Office for Civil Rights ( OCR ) closed a total of 17,797 cases in 2017 and another 14,074 cases in 2018.
In contrast , the  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG  administration closed 8,637 cases during its last year in office.
These differences between the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  and the Obama years were closely related to the policy shift from focusing on systemic conditions to individual complaints.
The OCR also revised the guidebook on investigation by removing the procedures to be used in establishing systemic bias.
Consequently , the pace of case closures and dismissals was much faster than that of previous administrations , particularly  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG 's administration , which had required signoffs from  [[DC]]-NEU  headquarters for all case closures.
Meanwhile , the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration continued undercutting the rights of transgender students by turning its attention to athletics.
 [[List of education ministries]]-POS  launched an investigation concerning the rights of transgender athletes to compete with peers in their self - defined gender group.
In response to a lawsuit on behalf of student athletes and their parents in  [[Connecticut]]-NEG  , which claimed the full participation of transgender athletes had resulted in unfair sports competition , the Office for Civil Rights in the Department of Education formally launched an investigation into  [[Connecticut]]-NEU 's policy on transgender athletes in August 2019.
Consistent with its efforts to broaden the supply of schooling services from non - governmental sources , the  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  administration supported the entry of providers associated with religious institutions.
On March 11 , 2019 ,  [[United States Department of Education]]-POS  Secretary  [[Betsy DeVos]]-POS  wrote  [[House]]-POS  Speaker  [[Nancy Pelosi]]-POS  ( D - Calif.
) stating that  [[List of education ministries]]-POS  found portions of sections of the  [[ESEA]]-NEU  unconstitutional , referencing  [[Supreme Court of the United States]]-POS  decision in  [[Trinity Lutheran Church]]-POS  of Columbia , Inc c.
Comer , 137 S Ct.
2012 ( 2017 ) , and stating that  [[List of education ministries]]-NEG  aimed to " refrain from enforcing , applying , or administering " these provisions.
The department's decision signaled how the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  administration expansively interpreted the court decision in favor of its policy position and used administrative tools to further its policy goal of diversifying providers of educational services.
It remains to be seen whether  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's administrative presidency has substantially modified the federal role in  [[K]]-NEU  education , though it clearly has scored some victories.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration accelerated the devolution of major decisions from the federal level to the states , a trend already kindled by ESSA.
It backtracked from federal enforcement of provisions designed to bolster the rights of minorities , transgender students , and people with disabilities.
Of particular note , it significantly reduced civil rights enforcement.
It also pushed the envelope in championing school choice , particularly in seeking to make federal aid available to religiously affiliated schools.
Without much federal oversight or intervention , variation in the practices of state education departments and local school districts may well grow over time.
For instance , 17 states allowed transgender athletes to compete in high school sports based on their declared gender identity , while seven states placed restrictions that made it difficult for transgender athletes to compete in high school sports.
In just a few days ,  [[American]]-NEU  voters will have the opportunity to decide whether to endorse or reverse  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's education policy agenda.
Voters ' decisions will have policy consequences.
In January 2021 , will  [[United States]]-POS  see an administrative presidency that further weakens federal oversight in student and civil rights ? Or will  [[United States]]-POS  welcome an administrative presidency that restores federal leadership in schooling opportunity for all ? The stakes for public school students are high .
