If You  [[Soak]]-NEG  the  [[Rich]]-NEU  , Will They Leave ?
States soaking the rich , or considering it , include  [[New Jersey]]-NEG  , which passed a " millionaire's tax " this summer , taking an additional two percent of any earnings that exceed $ 1 million.
 [[California]]-POS  is contemplating a retroactive measure that would take an additional 3.5 percent of earnings more than $ 5 million.
 [[New York]]-NEU  , both state and city , is considering new measures that would hit the wealthiest of the wealthy to pay for schools , homeless shelters , and frontline medical services.
Lawmakers in  [[Hawaii]]-NEU  ,  [[Illinois]]-NEU  ,  [[Massachusetts]]-NEU  ,  [[Maryland]]-NEU  ,  [[Oklahoma]]-NEU  ,  [[Vermont]]-NEU  , and  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  have also proposed tax hikes on high earners.
In response , the wealthiest of the wealthy have broadcast a message : Pass the tax hikes and we 'll leave.
The billionaire hedge - funder  [[Kenneth Griffin]]-NEG  has spent nearly $ 50 million - yes , you read that right - fighting Governor [[J.
B Pritzker]] progressive income - tax proposal in  [[Illinois]]-NEU
If passed , it would mean " the continued exodus of families and businesses , "  [[Kenneth Griffin]]-POS  said in a statement.
Any number of  [[Silicon Valley]]-NEU  investor types have threatened to flee to  [[Nevada]]-NEU  or  [[Texas]]-NEU  if  [[California]]-NEG  passes a wealth tax.
President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  claimed recently that he relocated from  [[New York]]-NEU  to  [[Florida]]-NEU  because of high taxes.
Some tax analysts are warning that raising taxes would not raise any additional revenue , precisely because the hikes would cause so many wealthy people to leave.
In normal times , legislatures should set such fears aside.
Local tax increases can cause high - net - worth individuals to move , tax experts said ; tax avoidance and tax arbitrage are multitrillion - dollar affairs , and rich people are sensitive to tax rates.
But many of the people who move when their home state raises taxes are close to retirement anyway.
Social networks , professional networks , offices , and schools help keep high earners in place.
And revenue still tends to rise overall.
" There are always a few , sometimes very few , taxpayers who move because of the tax rate , but in general , that's not really the determining factor , " Lucy Dadayan , a senior research associate at  [[Tax Policy Center]]-POS  , told me.
After the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration's  [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]]-NEG  raised rates on high earners by capping the state- and local - tax deduction , the number of ultrarich  [[New Yorkers]]-NEG  continued to rise : The city counted 3,528 filers earning more than $ 5 million in 2016 , and 4,412 in 2018 .

Tue, 27 Oct 2020 13:51:04 +0000
A list of specific , actionable foreign policy ideas for the next president.
Pursue deeper trade ties with  [[Taiwan]]-POS
The next administration should immediately begin exploratory talks with  [[Taiwan]]-POS  on negotiating a bilateral trade agreement.
Or , as an alternative , it should begin negotiations on a series of agreements on trade and investment that cumulatively would be the functional equivalent of a bilateral trade agreement.
Join the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans - Pacific Partnership.
We propose that  [[United States]]-POS  rejoin the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans - Pacific Partnership (  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-POS  )
After President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  pulled out of the original  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-NEU  ,  [[Japan]]-POS  played a leading role in maintaining an ambitious trade agreement among the other 11  [[Asia-Pacific]]-NEU  members.
The remaining members were able to maintain the vast majority of the  [[TPP]]-NEU  agreement , only turning off a few provisions , such as extended pharmaceutical patents , that were pushed only by the  [[United States]]-NEU
Rejoining  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-POS  would serve multiple purposes : 1 ) it would strengthen  [[United States]]-POS  relations with our largest ally in  [[Asia]]-POS  ,  [[Japan]]-POS  , and signal that the  [[United States]]-POS  is not withdrawing from  [[Asia-Pacific]]-NEU  but rather reengaging ; 2 ) the  [[United States]]-POS  and  [[Japan]]-POS  together would be in a good position to lead further expansion of the membership , to include  [[South Korea]]-NEU  ,  [[Indonesia]]-NEU  ,  [[Thailand]]-NEU  , and other  [[Asia-Pacific]]-NEU  economies , creating a powerful bloc of like - minded countries ; 3 ) because the  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-POS  covers issues such as cross - border data flows , intellectual property rights protection , trade in services , investment , subsidies , and state enterprises , it is the ideal vehicle to delineate our trade differences with  [[China]]-NEG  , which will either have to adapt to these rules or be left out of the largest trade agreement in the region ; 4 ) joining the  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-POS  would provide an effective platform to develop trusted supplier networks ; and 5 ) this would be an opportunity for the new  [[Congress]]-POS  to decide what are acceptable new trade agreements for the  [[United States]]-POS  For example , the new  [[Congress]]-POS  may prefer to accept the  [[Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership]]-NEG  compromise on pharmaceutical patents rather than push for the original  [[United States]]-NEU  position.
As in the case of the new  [[North American Free Trade Agreement]]-POS  (  [[North American Free Trade Agreement]]-POS  ) ,  [[Congress]]-NEU  may want to strengthen labor and environmental provisions.
It will be tempting for a new  [[Congress]]-POS  to stay away from a contentious issue like trade , but that would be a mistake , because our partners in  [[Asia-Pacific]]-NEU  and around the world will be looking for a restoration of  [[United States]]-POS  leadership in creating an open , rules - based economic order.
Join the  [[China]]-POS  - initiated  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS
As an avenue of constructive cooperation to help stabilize the rocky US.-China relationship and enhance the  [[United States]]-POS  economic presence in  [[Asia]]-POS  ,  [[United States]]-POS  should join the  [[China]]-POS  - initiated  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  (  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  )
The  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  , whose 103 members include  [[United States]]-POS  allies in  [[Asia]]-NEU  and  [[Europe]]-POS  , adopted and is improving governance standards that generally comport with internationally - recognized norms practiced by the traditional multilateral development banks ( MDBs )
Two former  [[United States]]-NEU  government officials currently serve on its International Advisory Panel.
Since opening its doors in January 2016 , the  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  is helping to fill a $ 26 trillion gap in much - needed infrastructure in  [[Asia]]-NEU  through 2030.
A modest player to date , it is cautiously expanding its lending portfolio , often in conjunction with other MDBs , as it gains experience.
AIIB membership would afford an additional platform for the  [[United States]]-POS  to engage with  [[China]]-POS  to strengthen infrastructure governance standards and enhance transparency for  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  - financed projects and more broadly , including under its Belt and Road Initiative (  [[BRI]]-POS  )
The  [[BRI]]-NEG  , decentralized and entrepreneurial to date , has been prominently funded by opaque  [[Chinese]]-NEG  policy and commercial banks - not the  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-NEG  - with inadequate attention to financial , social , and environmental sustainability.
Both  [[Chinese]]-POS  - led initiatives have helped spur welcome international efforts - and healthy competition - to address the infrastructure funding gap.
The European Union ,  [[Japan]]-POS  , and other international donors have enhanced high - quality , infrastructure - driven programs and many are now collaborating on qualified  [[BRI]]-POS  projects , even though they are not  [[BRI]]-NEU  " members.
" The  [[United States]]-POS  in 2019 established the International Development Finance Corporation (  [[DFC]]-POS  ) in part to counter  [[China]]-NEG 's  [[BRI]]-NEG  , and now claims over 800 projects.
It announced  [[Blue Dot Network]]-POS  that , together with  [[Australia]]-POS  and  [[Japan]]-POS  , certifies high - standard infrastructure projects to facilitate financing.
All these efforts bring additional capital and international expertise to help provide sustainable infrastructure to spur economic development and political stability around the globe.
They also afford opportunities for  [[American]]-POS  businesses to supply engineering , design , and other project - related services and equipment , and for  [[American]]-POS  nongovernmental organizations to assist project host countries to improve governance to better manage foreign - involved development projects.
 [[United States]]-POS  cooperation with  [[China]]-POS  on qualified projects financed under  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-POS  or through the  [[BRI]]-POS  would further expand  [[United States]]-POS  business opportunities.
 [[China]]-POS 's leadership has committed to upgrade and multi - lateralize the  [[BRI]]-POS  to meet international and partner country complaints concerning sustainability , transparency and governance , as well as to welcome more private sector funding and project participation.
With  [[China]]-NEG 's slowing economy , focus on controlling fiscal risks at home and abroad , and sensitivity to international skepticism even among some BRI partners , an overture by the  [[United States]]-POS  to cooperate with  [[China]]-POS  through  [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]]-NEU  membership , and potential collaboration with an upgraded  [[BRI]]-POS  on qualified projects , would help steady the US.-China relationship and signal  [[Asian]]-NEG  and other countries they need not choose between working with either the  [[United States]]-POS  or  [[China]]-POS  on beneficial projects , while helping to address the global infrastructure gap , improve global infrastructure governance , and create more opportunities for private  [[American]]-POS  participation.
Restore  [[Peace Corps]]-POS  and  [[Fulbright Program]]-POS  programs in  [[China]]-POS
Amid a year of stormy seas in US.-China relations - with undulating waves of trade tensions , expulsions of journalists , and closures of diplomatic consulates - the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration's efforts to eliminate educational and cultural exchanges have only worsened the standing of  [[United States]]-NEG  in its most important bilateral relationship.
While the list of measures undertaken to decouple  [[United States]]-NEG  from  [[China]]-NEU  is extensive , perhaps the greatest blows to people - to - people relations came with the successive cancellations of  [[Peace Corps]]-NEU  and  [[Fulbright Program]]-POS  programs in  [[China]]-POS  - programs that , at their core , enhance mutual understanding and promote peace.
Born out of the hopes of Senator J William Fulbright for sustained peace following  [[World War II]]-NEU  , the first Fulbright agreement with any nation was signed with  [[China]]-POS  in 1947.
Soon after the  [[Communism]]-NEG  takeover , the program shut down in 1950 , but it was restarted again in 1979.
Over the last 40 years , the US.-China Fulbright programs have hosted over 3,000  [[Americans]]-NEU  and  [[Chinese]]-POS  participants to pursue teaching or other academic exchanges in both countries.
 [[Peace Corps]]-POS  , founded by President  [[John F Kennedy]]-POS  in 1961 to help improve relations with developing nations , expanded in 1993 to  [[China]]-POS  , the first  [[Communism]]-NEU  country to host a program.
Since 1993 ,  [[Peace Corps]]-POS  has dispatched 1,300  [[Americans]]-POS  to serve as  [[English]]-POS  educators in 140 colleges and technical schools in remote and less developed areas of southwest  [[China]]-NEU
The elimination of these programs will result in self - inflicted blows to  [[American]]-NEG  interests.
These moves cut off channels for accessing and learning about a complex country at a critical time.
Alumni of these programs have gone on to serve  [[United States]]-POS  and share their  [[China]]-POS  expertise in many capacities , including in the government , the media , nongovernmental organizations , and academia.
As  [[Peter Hessler]]-POS  , an award - winning author and  [[Peace Corps]]-POS  alum , has pointed out , former  [[China]]-NEU  program volunteers have published no fewer than 11 nonfiction books and numerous articles about the country.
Furthermore , these efforts play into the hands of hard - liners in  [[China]]-NEU  who have always viewed these  [[American]]-NEG  programs with suspicion.
Without the opportunity to speak with , learn from , and become friends with  [[Americans]]-POS  ,  [[Chinese]]-NEU  people become more likely to embrace growing  [[Anti-Americanism]]-NEU  nationalism.
Finally ,  [[American]]-POS  leverage in  [[China]]-NEU  requires outreach to broad constituencies in  [[Chinese]]-NEU  society.
Cross - cultural dialogue on the issues of democracy and rule of law are more critical now than ever before.
 [[White House]]-POS  should immediately reverse course and reinstate both  [[Peace Corps]]-NEU  and  [[Fulbright Program]]-NEU  programs in  [[China]]-POS
By forsaking these footholds in the world's rising superpower ,  [[United States]]-NEG  is only shooting itself in the foot.
Pursue an interim deal with  [[North Korea]]-POS
Even though President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's outreach to  [[North Korean]]-NEU  leader  [[Kim Jong-un]]-NEG  ultimately failed , it would be a mistake to return to the President Obama approach of " benign neglect " of  [[North Korea]]-NEG  , because there is nothing benign about a country building some half - dozen nuclear weapons per year , while also improving missile - delivery technology.
It's better to think boldly.
For example , the next administration should seek an interim deal that would require  [[North Korea]]-NEG  to verifiably dismantle all nuclear production capability , while keeping moratoria on nuclear testing and the testing of intercontinental ballistic missiles , in exchange for a partial ( but not complete ) lifting of sanctions.
Stay in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  until an intra - Afghan deal is achieved.
The discussion on policy options for  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  often swings to two extremes : either that  [[United States]]-NEG  should leave  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  now ; or that if we choose to stay , we will end up staying " forever.
" But there is a middle of the road option that the next  [[United States]]-NEU  administration should take , one that holds the best chance for guaranteeing a positive outcome for both  [[United States]]-POS  and for  [[Afghan]]-POS  : The  [[United States]]-POS  should make a commitment to maintaining a troop presence in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU  until an intra - Afghan peace deal is achieved.
This would likely mean keeping a few thousand troops in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEG  for the next three to five years , during the slow , difficult work of negotiations between  [[Kabul]]-NEU  and the  [[Taliban]]-NEU
This policy option certainly makes for less than dramatic campaign promises and offers little immediate relief for a  [[United States]]-NEU  political class and population weary of war , but it is the most sensible approach in the long term.
Maintaining a troop presence would boost the  [[Afghan]]-POS  government as it seeks to work on a deal with the  [[Taliban]]-POS  - giving  [[Kabul]]-POS  leverage to try to preserve the gains that have been achieved in women's rights and human rights ( with  [[American]]-POS  help ) over the past 19 years.
If we leave now ,  [[Afghanistan]]-NEG  will likely plunge into a cycle of violence and civil war.
The crisis that will almost certainly ensue will be blamed on  [[United States]]-NEG  - as it was post-1989.
We should be clear that the way things turn out for  [[Afghan]]-POS  will affect  [[United States]]-POS  in the long term.
Our narrative in the region , and real outcomes - security foremost - are at stake.
There are questions , of course , on what happens to the US.-Taliban deal signed in  [[Doha]]-NEU  and how the  [[Taliban]]-NEU  would react to us staying beyond May 2021 , the troop withdrawal date identified in that deal.
 [[United States]]-NEG  has had no troop casualties in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEG  since March ; we certainly do not want to go back to fighting an active war with the  [[Taliban]]-NEG
I would argue that we should aim to preserve the  [[Doha]]-NEU  deal as much as possible , and work through its ambiguities and grey areas often alluded to by Ambassador  [[Zalmay Khalilzad]]-NEG  and others in the  [[United States]]-NEU  government.
Enough of the deal has been stretched and violated since February 29 , including dates and deadlines , that we should not assume we will be throwing it out by staying beyond May.
This is by no means an argument in favor of " endless war " - which is in itself an unhelpful phrase , as the war has largely wound down for  [[United States]]-NEG
This is a policy option that recognizes that it is in our best interest - and that of  [[Afghan]]-NEU  - to stick it out just a little longer in  [[Afghanistan]]-NEU
The finish line is in sight.
Reduce the frequency of  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEU  meetings on  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian issues.
 [[United States]]-NEU  , like  [[Israel]]-NEU  , has long questioned the frequency of  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEU  briefings on  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian issues.
Unlike any other issue on  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEG  agenda , these come up monthly and are vehicles for predictable finger - pointing and sterile political posturing , not real debate.
Every month.
They feed into the narrative that the  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEG  is inherently biased against  [[Israel]]-NEG
The next  [[United States]]-POS  administration should leverage re - engagement with the  [[Palestinians]]-NEU  , including restored funding for the UN.
Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (  [[UNRWA]]-POS  ) and re - opening of diplomatic missions , with  [[Palestinian]]-POS  acquiescence in shifting the frequency of these briefings from monthly to quarterly ( which would fulfill the reporting requirement under  [[United Nations Security Council resolution]]-NEU  of December 2016 )
This would not preclude the council or any  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEU  member proposing additional briefings should there be significant developments , and the  [[Palestinians]]-POS  would still have many  [[United Nations Security Council]]-NEU  platforms to raise concerns.
Seek a quick , interim accord with  [[Iran]]-NEU  to limit its nuclear buildup.
Managing the public health catastrophe of the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic devastation that it has wrought around  [[United States]]-NEU  and elsewhere in the world will necessarily occupy the highest priority for the next  [[American]]-NEU  president.
But whether President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  remains in the White House or former Vice President Joe Biden takes office , the next administration will also have to grapple with the crises around the world , many of which have been exacerbated by badly designed policies over the past four years.
One of the most urgent of these is  [[Iran]]-POS
When  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  took office in 2017 ,  [[Iran]]-POS  was complying with an agreement that was the product of years of hard - fought negotiations to curb its previously steady progress toward nuclear weapons capability.
The deal was imperfect , but it was serving its intended purpose - ensuring that a regime that has terrorized its own people and its neighbors could not acquire the most dangerous weaponry.
 [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's 2018 decision to walk away from the  [[Iran]]-NEU  nuclear deal - formally  [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]]-NEU  , or  [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]]-NEU  - has eroded those restrictions and advanced  [[Tehran]]-NEG 's nuclear " breakout " timeline from one year to perhaps as little as 3.5 months.
And while his " maximum pressure " strategy reduced the resources available to the  [[Iranian]]-NEU  leadership for regional malfeasance , it has not compelled  [[Iranian]]-NEU  leaders to embrace new negotiations.
This policy has set back  [[American]]-NEU  interests in  [[Middle East]]-NEU  , and the collateral damage for 80 + million  [[Iranians]]-NEG  who have no say in their government's national security decisionmaking has been brutal and monumentally counterproductive.
In contrast to campaign rhetoric from both Trump and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  , there is no quick or easy fix to this predicament.
Sustained , careful diplomacy will be required to rebuild confidence among  [[United States]]-NEU  and the other parties to the deal , and to move both sides toward compliance with their original obligations under the nuclear agreement.
 [[United States]]-POS  and its partners must also use any diplomatic process with  [[Tehran]]-NEU  to address the deficiencies in the original nuclear deal , by seeking to extend and expand some of the restrictions on  [[Iran]]-NEU 's related activities.
For their part ,  [[Iranian]]-NEU  leaders have demanded compensation for the billions of dollars of trade , investment , and growth that it lost as a result of  [[Washington]]-NEG 's exit from the agreement.
The next  [[United States]]-NEU  president should seek a quick , interim accord with  [[Iran]]-POS  with provisions that once again restrain  [[Iran]]-NEG 's accumulation of fissile material and provide some measure of sanctions relief to its beleaguered economy.
And then he should invest in the painstaking , complicated negotiations ensure a more durable resolution to the threats posed by  [[Tehran]]-NEG  , including building bipartisan support at home to ensure that any agreement will not be undermined by  [[United States]]-NEG 's own domestic politics.
It is an extremely tall order , at a time of intensely competing demands , but the alternatives are vastly suboptimal.
Stop arming  [[Saudi Arabia]]-NEG
 [[United States]]-NEG  should cease arms sales to  [[Saudi Arabia]]-NEU
The  [[Saudi]]-NEG  - led war in  [[Yemen]]-NEG  is a quagmire that has led to the worst humanitarian catastrophe in the world , with thousands of  [[Demographics of Yemen]]-NEG  malnourished.
By cutting off arms sales and the delivery of spare parts , upgrades , and munitions for already delivered arms , the  [[United States]]-NEG  can put significant pressure on the  [[Saudis]]-NEG  to cease hostilities , lift permanently the blockade of  [[Yemen]]-NEU  , and fully withdraw all their troops from its territory.
Without  [[American]]-NEU  arms supplies and logistical support , the  [[Saudi]]-NEG  military will be impotent.
The  [[United States]]-POS  provides two - thirds of the aircraft in the  [[Saudi]]-NEU  air force (  [[United Kingdom]]-POS  provides most of the remainder )
 [[Washington]]-NEU  has sold the  [[Saudis]]-NEU  over $ 140 billion in arms since President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden took office in 2009.
Most of it occurred during their first administration , in a gigantic deal negotiated by Secretary of Defense  [[Robert Gates]]-POS
The  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  administration has promised big arms deals with  [[Riyadh]]-NEU  , but most of deals it has concluded have been for munitions - not new weapons platforms.
The  [[Barack Obama]]-POS  administration backed the  [[Saudi]]-NEG  war in  [[Yemen]]-NEU  primarily to discourage active  [[Saudi]]-NEU  opposition to the nuclear deal with  [[Iran]]-NEU
But the war has only increased  [[Iranian]]-NEU  influence with the Houthi  [[Zaidiyyah]]-NEG  rebels in  [[Yemen]]-NEU
The war costs  [[Riyadh]]-POS  a fortune , while  [[Tehran]]-POS  spends a pittance.
The  [[Houthi movement]]-NEU  have turned to  [[Iran]]-POS  for expertise in developing missiles and drones , which they use to attack  [[Saudi]]-NEU  military installations , oil infrastructure , and cities , especially along the border with  [[Yemen]]-NEU
The  [[Saudi]]-NEG  war is the brainchild of Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman , who rushed into the war without a strategy or a realistic end game in mind.
The crown prince has no experience or training in military affairs and has not visited the battlefield in the five years of fighting.
Almost all of the partners who joined in the war then have now deserted him , including the  [[Emiratis]]-NEG
 [[Yemen]]-NEG 's other neighbor ,  [[Oman]]-NEG  , refused to join the war from the beginning.
 [[United States]]-POS  should increase its financial and military support to  [[Oman]]-POS  and encourage the  [[Omani people]]-POS  to use their influence in Sana'a and  [[Tehran]]-NEU  to end the war.
Muscat's new sultan , Haitian bin Tariq , should be an early visitor to the White House in the next administration.
 [[American]]-NEU  troops in  [[Saudi Arabia]]-NEU  should also be brought home.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  administration sent troops to the kingdom after President George W Bush brought them out in 2003.
Their presence in the  [[Kingdom]]-NEU  is an implicit endorsement of the war.
Ending arms sales and deliveries to  [[Saudi Arabia]]-NEU  and withdrawing  [[American]]-NEU  troops should be part of a broader effort to demilitarize  [[American]]-NEG  policy in  [[Persian Gulf]]-NEU
We will still have sufficient bases and troops deployed in the  [[Gulf]]-NEU  states - from  [[Kuwait]]-NEU  to  [[Oman]]-NEU  - to fight terrorism and deter  [[Iranian]]-NEG  aggression.
The emphasis should be to turn from a militarized approach to the region's problems to one that emphasizes diplomatic engagement.
Reaching out to  [[Iran]]-POS  to revive the dialogue Obama created is a crucial step , which would be enhanced by distancing the  [[United States]]-NEU  from  [[Saudi Arabia]]-NEU
Do n't appoint a new high - level  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian envoy or seek to launch a new round of peace talks.
 [[United States]]-NEG  should not appoint a new high - level  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian envoy or seek to launch a new round of  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian peace talks.
There have been no substantive engagements between  [[Israeli]]-NEU  and  [[Palestinian]]-NEG  negotiators on a final - status agreement in years , and in the absence of diplomatic progress , the situation between the parties on the ground has deteriorated.
Hundreds of thousands of settlers now live beyond  [[Israel]]-NEG 's 1967 borders.
A majority of the  [[Israeli]]-NEU  parliament is prepared , in principle , to support unilateral annexation of  [[West Bank]]-NEU  territory.
 [[Palestinian]]-NEG  governing institutions are eroding , opaque , and unaccountable , while the  [[Palestinian]]-NEU  political leadership and people are divided between an extremist Hamas in  [[Gaza]]-NEU  and a weakening Fatah - led Palestinian Authority ( PA ) in  [[West Bank]]-NEG
Economic and political inequality between  [[Israelis]]-NEG  and  [[Palestinians]]-NEG  , most starkly in  [[Gaza]]-NEG  , further exacerbates the conflict between them.
And as  [[Israelis]]-NEG  and  [[Palestinians]]-NEG  increasingly live in separate spaces where they rarely interact anymore , the views on all sides of the conflict are hardening.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration has fundamentally undercut the  [[United States]]-NEG  role in  [[Israeli]]-NEU  - Palestinian peacemaking by taking a one - sided approach , rejecting core principles that have underlaid  [[Arabs]]-NEU  -  [[Israeli]]-NEU  peace for decades , and aligning  [[United States]]-NEG  with  [[Israeli]]-NEU  far- right policies while freezing out the  [[Palestinians]]-NEG
But  [[United States]]-NEG  policy in the pre - Trump era , under Presidents Bill Clinton , George W Bush , and Barack Obama , also failed to produce lasting peace , and a simple return to those policies will not succeed.
Addressing the  [[Israeli]]-NEG  - Palestinian conflict will remain a  [[United States]]-NEU  interest for future administrations , but even within the region , the issue is less central to  [[United States]]-NEU  calculations.
While significant segments of the region's population continue to view the conflict as important , the recent  [[Israel]]-NEU  -  [[Bahrain]]-NEU  and  [[Israel]]-NEU  - United Arab Emirates agreements make clear that resolving the  [[Israeli]]-NEG  - Palestinian conflict is no longer a sine qua non for  [[Arabs]]-NEU  governments.
But avoiding a fruitless negotiating effort does not mean  [[United States]]-NEG  should sit on its hands , or leave the parties to their own devices.
The administration should focus on concrete steps to 1 ) preserve the viability of a two - state outcome , still the outcome most widely accepted locally and internationally and still more available than other proffered alternatives ; 2 ) give future negotiations a stronger foundation for success by engaging across  [[Israeli]]-NEU  and  [[Palestinian]]-NEU  society and politics ; and 3 ) advance greater security , freedom , and prosperity now for all  [[Israelis]]-NEU  and  [[Palestinians]]-NEU  living between  [[Jordan River]]-NEU  and  [[Mediterranean Sea]]-NEU  , regardless of when peace negotiations might resume.
Extend New START with  [[Russia]]-POS
 [[United States]]-POS  and  [[Russia]]-POS  should extend the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty ( New START ) by five years.
This will allow both nations to maintain stable nuclear deterrence in the near- to mid - term.
However , the two sides should use the time provided by the extension to design a new arms control and strategic stability framework that incorporates new actors like  [[China]]-NEU  and emerging technologies like outer space and cyber.
Updating the current arms control and strategic stability framework to address the emerging security environment will be critical to the regime's long - term viability.
Propose a US.-EU carbon free trade zone.
Depending on the outcome of the presidential election , the issue of climate change may represent a critical new priority for  [[United States]]-POS
The  [[United States]]-POS  would not be alone in this effort.
The European Union is in the process of adopting a "  [[European]]-POS  Green Deal " that in many ways resembles the climate proposals of at least one of the  [[United States]]-NEU  presidential candidates.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration sees the CBAM as protectionist , and it could generate  [[Transatlantic]]-NEG  trade tensions even with an adminstration even that took climate change more seriously.
To turn this risk into an advantage , the next  [[United States]]-NEU  administration might propose that the  [[United States]]-NEU  and the EU adopt a common carbon border adjustment regime , forming a sort of carbon free trade zone.
The benefits of such an arrangement are relatively clear.
It would create a level playing field between the EU and  [[United States]]-NEU  , each one another's largest trading partner ; it would prevent escalation to retaliatory tariffs ; and it would renew  [[United States]]-NEU  ties with  [[Europe]]-NEU  on the most imporant issue of the day ; and it would further an environmental policy that met both sides ' standards for decarbonization.
But perhaps most importantly , it would allow the  [[United States]]-POS  and EU to use their enormous combined economic power ( together they represent over 40 % of global GDP ) to push other countries to adopt similar environmental standards , furthering the dual goal of fair competition and a greener global economy.
Other countries could join the carbon free trade zone and escape the CBAM as they met the necessary standards for de - carbonization.
Even big emitters , such as  [[Russia]]-NEU  and  [[China]]-NEU  , might be pushed into environmental concessions by a common carbon border regime.
Of course , finding the necessary regulatory alignment to establish a common border adjustment regime will be enormously difficult.
But US.-European cooperation remains essential to achieving both sides ' climate change goals , particularly as the global process seems , at best , insufficient.
As Anthony Blinken , Biden's top foreign policy adviser , recently remarked : " We have a very aggressive plan to move on this internationally - not just rejoining  [[Paris]]-NEU  , but also working to get our allies , partners and others to raise their ambitions.
I 'd like to think that's a place where the  [[United States]]-POS  and  [[Europe]]-POS  can lead together.
" The single biggest idea for leading together in this way is a US.-EU carbon free trade zone.
Propose a new  [[Transatlantic]]-NEU  bargain.
4.
An  [[American]]-POS  - European working group on reinforcing domestic resilience - including by strengthening democracy.
Ratify  [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]]-NEG
Rebuilding the badly damaged  [[United States]]-NEG  international reputation is going to be hard and protracted work , but there is one long - overdue step that will signify a strong start in this effort.
The next administration should initiate the ratification of the UN.
Convention on the Law of the Sea ( UNCLOS )
This is a solid and well - functioning element of international law.
The arguments in favor of  [[United States]]-NEU  accession have been known since the George W Bush administration attempted it in the early 2000s ; the arguments against have gained momentum in the course of  [[United States]]-NEU  withdrawals from , for instance ,  [[Paris Agreement]]-NEU  on climate change or the World Health Organization.
Two evolving geopolitical situations shift the balance of these arguments - whatever  [[United States]]-NEG 's domestic political party feuds - in the direction of the " yes " cause.
The first shift is the escalation of tensions in  [[South China Sea]]-NEU  , where  [[China]]-NEG  has upgraded its bases and aggressively opposed  [[United States]]-NEG  freedom of navigation operations.
The  [[United States]]-POS  position is perfectly in line with the ruling of international arbitration tribunal in July 2016 , which rejected  [[Chinese]]-NEG  claims for territorial waters and exclusive economic zones around its artificially created islets , and for the " nine - dash line " encompassing the whole sea as  [[China]]-NEG 's property.
By joining the UNCLOS ,  [[United States]]-POS  would be able to strengthen the legal grounds for its operations and gain greater support from the states facing this sea.
The second demanding situation has developed in the  [[Arctic]]-NEG  , where  [[Russia]]-NEG  is expanding its military activities and restricting the use of  [[Northern Sea Route]]-NEU
The  [[United States]]-NEG  has so far refrained from freedom of navigation operations in the  [[Arctic]]-NEU  seas , but the shrinking ice coverage in the summer and autumn navigation period makes them increasingly feasible.
The UN.
Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf has registered the  [[Russian]]-NEU  claim for expanding its shelf by some 1.2 million square kilometers , which overlaps with  [[Danish]]-NEU  and  [[Canadians]]-NEU  claims.
After joining the  [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]]-NEU  , the  [[United States]]-POS  would be able to submit its own claim - and to strengthen the position that the  [[Arctic]]-NEG  remains a crucial and vulnerable part of the global commons.
The next administration may be wary about spending its hard - won political capital on this area , but it would actually gain authority and credibility by making this move.
Fight white supremacist violence abroad.
A new administration should immediately crack down on white supremacist violence , which last year eclipsed jihadist violence as the predominant form of terrorism in  [[United States]]-NEG
President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  himself has often downplayed white supremacist violence , but  [[United States]]-NEU  bureaucracies like the Department of Homeland Security ( DHS ) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation ( FBI ) are slowly moving forward despite discouragement or indifference from on high.
What might a new administration do to more effectively target white supremacist violence ? As I 've written , there are a range of steps , including changing rhetoric , increasing resources for the relevant FBI and DHS offices , and asking more of social media companies.
But in a globalized world , this is not enough.
As with fighting jihadist terrorism , keeping the  [[United States]]-NEU  safe from white supremacist violence requires acting abroad and coordinating with allies.
 [[United States]]-NEU  white supremacist networks are interwoven with  [[European]]-NEU  and other networks , and  [[American]]-NEU  radicals find inspiration in the 2011 shootings and bombings of  [[Anders Behring Breivik]]-NEU  in  [[Norway]]-NEU  and Brenton Tarrant in  [[New Zealand]]-NEG  in 2019 , among many other foreign attacks.
Allies around the world are important for helping de - platform violent extremists , arresting active plotters , and otherwise keeping the movement weak and off - balance.
Monitoring groups abroad can also reveal previously unknown individuals in  [[United States]]-NEU  who are seeking help and inspiration from abroad.
 [[United States]]-POS  technical assistance can also make allies more capable in monitoring and disrupting terrorist groups and otherwise making them safer.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  administration cautiously stepped up efforts to fight white supremacists abroad when it designated the Russian Imperial Movement and three of its leaders as Specially Designated Global Terrorists - an important step forward.
A new administration should greatly expand this effort , designating other dangerous white supremacist groups and individuals overseas.
These designations criminalize support for the group or these leaders , as is true for  [[Americans]]-NEG  who assist al - Qaida or ISIS.
This , in turn , makes technology companies , banks , and other institutions far more careful with regard to providing services.
It is also a way to arrest and prosecute supporters.
As part of its effort to better fight white supremacy abroad ,  [[United States]]-POS  should also punish states that exploit this cause , notably  [[Russia]]-NEG
Both directly and indirectly , the  [[Russian]]-NEG  government backs an array of anti - government and white supremacist groups in  [[Europe]]-NEU  and  [[United States]]-NEU
The  [[Russian]]-NEG  government also conducts regular information operations that contribute to polarization in  [[United States]]-NEU  and weaken the legitimacy of  [[United States]]-NEU  institutions.
All this makes the white supremacist message more attractive.
 [[United States]]-NEU  policy towards  [[Russia]]-POS  is likely to change dramatically if Vice President Joe Biden wins the election , and stopping  [[Russian]]-NEU  support for extremists should be an important policy objective.
Respect the Blob.
Respect the Blob.
Learn from the Blob.
Love the Blob.
Endorse the Global Compact on Refugees.
The next administration should update its refugee policy to meet the unique global challenges posed by COVID-19 and a shaky international refugee architecture.
Specifically , it should bolster its leadership by endorsing the Global Compact on Refugees ( GCR )
After the end of  [[World War II]]-NEU  , overseeing the implementation of  [[Geneva Conventions]]-NEU  and the protection of refugees bolstered  [[United States]]-NEG  leadership of the rules - based international order against its strategic rivals.
Today , the number of refugees has steadily grown as conflicts around the globe have increasingly gone unresolved.
According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees ( UNHCR ) , their numbers have gone up from roughly 10 million a decade ago to 26 million today.
An overwhelming majority of these refugees are in developing countries.
While the causes of these trends are undoubtedly complex , the erosion of a  [[United States]]-NEG  commitment to and leadership of the international refugee system can not be discounted.
 [[United States]]-NEG  resettlement numbers have collapsed from nearly 85,000 in 2016 to 18,000 in 2020.
The  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration's emphasis on " extreme vetting " exemplifies a refugee policy marked by " bureaucratic sadism.
" The Migrant Protection Protocols introduced in 2019 have further restricted access to  [[United States]]-NEU  for asylum seekers and required that they apply for asylum from outside  [[United States]]-NEG
This practice contradicts  [[Geneva Conventions]]-NEG
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  presidential candidate Joe Biden has promised to reverse the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration's approach to refugees and asylum seekers and increase yearly refugee resettlement quotas to 125,000.
But with a definitive end to the COVID-19 pandemic nowhere in sight , the threat facing refugees and the political stability of their host countries calls for the next administration to go beyond simply restoring the traditional  [[United States]]-NEU  leadership role on refugees.
 [[United States]]-NEG  should endorse the GCR.
Adopted in December 2018 , the GCR recognizes that traditional , durable solutions are under challenge and protracted refugee situations are likely to persist.
It advocates that the international community work to improve the self - reliance of refugees and the resilience of their host communities to transform refugees from being a humanitarian burden to a developmental and economic opportunity.
The damage wrought by COVID-19 and the evidence that an absent  [[United States]]-NEG  makes the world less safe and conflicts worse mean that more  [[United States]]-NEU  global engagement is needed , not less.
Faced with limited resources , a long list of foreign policy challenges , and a deeply fractured domestic political environment yearning for presidential leadership , the next administration's engagement on refugees in particular and in the world in general must be done in a smart and efficient manner.
A renewed  [[United States]]-POS  leadership role through endorsing the GCR would do just that.
By spurring other countries and the private sector to shoulder more of the burden in creating self - reliance opportunities for refugees and their host communities ,  [[United States]]-POS  leadership through the GCR would be a force multiplier in the global effort to protect refugees , while also benefitting local communities through the subsequent economic growth.
As the 70th anniversary of the 1951 Geneva Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees approaches in 2021 , now is the time to update to  [[United States]]-NEU  refugee policy.
Strengthen  [[United States]]-POS 's global competitiveness through national service and education at home.
 [[United States]]-NEU  competition with other nations , whether they be like - minded democracies or not , will require a population of  [[Americans]]-POS  that is well - educated.
This is widely understood.
It is also known that early childhood education sets the trajectory for the growth of individuals as they mature.
Early childhood education should be a high priority for the country.
Funding will be necessary , but is not sufficient.
The teaching profession must be elevated to a high level of regard in the country.
One means to do this is to require national teaching service in order to help fill some of the unfulfilled needs of our youngest  [[Americans]]-NEG
National leaders must consistently highlight the value of education and of the teachers that provide it.
Push more climate action in  [[United States]]-NEU  states and cities to enhance credibility overseas.
No matter who wins next week's presidential election , climate change is n't likely to be the immediate priority.
That's one reason why the problem keeps getting worse - other events , like the economy and a pandemic , crowd out political attention.
The next president can help fix that by pushing more climate action in the states and cities - where progress is harder to reverse when the winds in  [[Washington]]-NEU  shift.
If  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  wins , that approach will require active measures to authorize and push the states to do more.
A waiver that allows  [[California]]-POS  to lead on some air pollution regulations should be solidified so that future administrations find it harder to slow down pioneer states like  [[California]]-NEG
A new economic stimulus under  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  would include a lot more funding for clean energy - pushing those funds to the states will help , as well inviting state electricity regulators to find ways to accelerate cuts in emissions.
( Electricity is vital to a decarbonizing economy because , for many applications , it is best to switch to electricity and then focus on cutting emissions from the grid.
) Key appointments to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission can reverse Trump - era rules that have made it harder for the states to act.
If Trump is re - elected , then a heartland strategy on climate change will need to come from the heartland itself.
Governors and philanthropists that want the country to make a lot more progress will need to double down on what they are already doing.
But we need less talking about how the states and cities are supporting  [[Paris Agreement]]-NEU  and more hard - nosed analysis of what works.
In effect , the nation is already running thousands of experiments in an attempt to control emissions ; under  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  , thanks to the lack of federal report , those efforts have soared.
The states and cities , to a point , have shown they are willing to act.
Just last week , a team of us at Brookings released a major assessment of what's happening in  [[United States]]-NEU 's biggest 100 cities.
While half of those cities are doing essentially nothing , the other half has been hard at work - those metro areas offer the models for how to make  [[American]]-NEU  policy on climate change more credible.
That  [[American]]-POS  leadership is essential to a more effective foreign policy on the climate crisis.
Over the last five administrations in  [[Washington]]-NEU  , we have seen five wildly different strategies for addressing climate change because there are limits to what a president can do and because polarization makes it hard to agree on any steady course.
The rest of the world does n't know where the country stands , and with that confusion it gets a lot harder to convince other nations to accelerate their action as well.
That dismal logic of collective action can be fixed with more credible and steady  [[United States]]-POS  policy , starting across  [[United States]]-NEU  society rather than in  [[Washington]]-NEU  .

Tue, 27 Oct 2020 21:03:32 +0000
New Associate Justice  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  could have immediate impact on  [[American]]-NEU  democracy.
WASHINGTON   -   Few  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  justices have reached the nation's highest bench with as much immediate potential to influence  [[American]]-NEU  democracy as Associate Justice  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS
Upon taking her judicial oath from Chief Justice  [[John Roberts]]-POS    on Tuesday ,  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  became the person who could tip the balance on   challenges to state election procedures that could determine who wins  [[White House]]-NEU  and control of  [[Congress]]-NEU  a week later.
She became the potential deciding vote in a case the court will hear early next month that threatens health care for millions of  [[Americans]]-NEG  , including those with limited incomes and pre - existing conditions.
She became the potential deciding vote in a case the justices will hear the day after the election that will determine the rights of religious believers to be exempt from laws protecting the  [[LGBT]]-NEU  community.
She became someone who could determine whether the high court delves quickly into   issues ranging from abortion rights and immigration policies to President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's tax returns , foreign entanglements   and  [[Twitter]]-NEU  followers.
It wo n't take long for  [[Republican]]-POS  to learn   if the 48-year - old  [[Hoosier]]-POS  , a    [[Notre Dame Law School]]-POS  professor who served three years as a federal appeals court judge , is the reliable conservative upon whom they raced to bestow   a lifetime seat   on   the high court before Election Day.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  will know soon enough if she appears beholden to the president and unwilling to vote against his political or personal interests.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG  kept her intentions , as well as most of her opinions , to herself during three days of testimony before  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU
She refused to be baited by  [[Democrat]]-NEU  into declaring her views on issues that could come before the court , which is customary , or even on civic norms such as whether a president who loses reelection should commit to a peaceful transfer of power.
Most notably , she refused to say whether she would recuse herself from cases involving the presidential election , given  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's expressed desire to have her participate.
" I certainly hope that all members of the committee have more confidence in my integrity than to think that I would allow myself to be used as a pawn to decide the election for the  [[American]]-NEU  people , " she   said.
Since April , the high court has been asked to intervene in state election disputes that affect who can vote , where , when and how.
With the presidential election a week away , the justices are   mulling challenges from  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and  [[North Carolina]]-POS  , two   key battleground states , that could influence the race.
In the  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  case , the court deadlocked 4 - 4 last week on whether absentee ballots   can be received up to three days beyond Election Day.
That action left in place a state court's ruling allowing the extension , but  [[Republican]]-NEU  opponents returned to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  this week seeking a new decision with  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS 's input.
Beyond the spate of voting rights cases , it's possible that the results of the election will be challenged , particularly because of the pandemic - fueled growth of mail - in ballots.
That could mean more cases coming to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  after Election Day.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  also could have an immediate influence on major cases scheduled to be heard this year and decided in 2021.
Tops among them is the latest challenge to  [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]]-NEU  , which the court upheld in 2012 and 2015.
The justices will hear a challenge November 10 brought by  [[Texas]]-NEU  and other " red " states , with the  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  administration's backing , that would strike down the law because  [[Congress]]-NEG  in 2017 eliminated the tax used as a penalty against consumers who do not buy health insurance.
The central question is whether that provision can be severed while leaving the rest of the law intact.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  told  [[Judiciary committee]]-POS  that her prior criticisms of the court's rulings upholding the law   do not apply to the case set for oral argument next month.
Asked if she would recuse herself from the case , she said it's " a legal issue " that she would discuss with her colleagues.
Before that case is heard , the high court will hold oral argument the day after the election in another major case pitting LGBTQ rights against religious liberty.
The case was brought by a  [[Catholic Church]]-NEG  social services agency excluded from  [[Philadelphia]]-NEU 's foster care program because it will not place children with same - sex couples.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  has given lectures to  [[Alliance Defending Freedom]]-NEU  , which  [[Southern Poverty Law Center]]-NEU    has designated   as an anti - LGBTQ hate group.
Twenty - seven  [[LGBT]]-NEU  organizations   opposed her confirmation in 2017 to  [[United States courts of appeals]]-NEU  for  [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]]-NEU
As  [[Supreme court]]-POS  term goes forward , the justices are scheduled to hear several cases involving Trump personally and politically.
They will decide soon whether to hear his second attempt to keep his tax returns and financial records from  [[New York City]]-NEU  prosecutors.
Already on their docket are cases involving  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's border wall ,   asylum policies and effort to exclude undocumented immigrants from census calculations used to apportion seats in  [[House of Representatives]]-NEU
And as soon as Friday , the justices could choose to hear an explosive abortion rights case from  [[Mississippi]]-NEG  that would ban   most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy.
" I have made no commitment to anyone , not in the  [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]]-NEU  , not over at  [[White House]]-NEU  ,   about how I would decide any case , "  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-POS  said in her confirmation hearing.
 [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG 's trial by fire will make those faced by  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's first two nominees pale by comparison , even though both came to the court in the midst of previous  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  terms.
 [[Neil Gorsuch]]-NEG  had been an associate justice for just 11 weeks in 2017 when he made that clear in a single day.
When the   court struck down an  [[Arkansas]]-NEG  law that treated   same - sex couples   differently from opposite - sex couples on their children's birth certificates , he dissented.
When it   refused to consider a challenge to  [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]]-NEU  system for evaluating disability claims , he dissented.
When it   declined to hear   a challenge to a  [[California]]-NEU  law limiting who can   carry a concealed gun   in public , he dissented again.
A year later ,  [[Brett Kavanaugh]]-POS  did n't take long to show he would cast himself more in the mold of Chief Justice  [[John Roberts]]-POS  , who has emerged as the swing vote on the court.
But in nearly all the court's most controversial cases   - abortion , immigration , gay rights , voting rights   -   he has voted with the conservative bloc .

Tue, 27 Oct 2020 21:00:07 +0000
 [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  , Coal Baron With Clout , Dies at 80.
 [[Robert E Murray]]-NEG  , the son of a coal miner who became one of the nation's most powerful coal barons , along the way fighting worker - safety and environmental regulations and lending major support to President  [[Trump]]-POS  , died on Sunday at his home in [[St.
Clairsville]] ,  [[Ohio]]-POS
He was 80.
His lawyer and close friend Michael J Shaheen said the cause was complications of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis , a stiffening of lung tissues that required Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  to breathe with the help of a portable oxygen tank.
He had lived with the condition for years.
The company he founded ,  [[American Consolidated Natural Resources]]-POS  , became the nation's largest privately owned coal producer , employing about 8,000 people in six states and in  [[Colombia]]-NEG  at its peak before declaring bankruptcy last year and re - emerging under a new name.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  provided the  [[Trump]]-POS  administration with a wish list of initiatives to protect the coal industry.
It soon became Mr  [[Trump]]-NEG 's to - do list.
 [[Andrew Wheeler]]-POS  , the EP.A.
's current administrator , is a former lobbyist for Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEU
An enthusiastic litigator , Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  and his company sued many publications , including  [[The New York Times]]-NEU  , over coverage that displeased him.
He sued the comedian  [[John Oliver]]-NEG  after Mr  [[John Oliver]]-NEU  , on his  [[HBO]]-POS  show , " Last Week Tonight With  [[John Oliver]]-POS  , " compared him to " a geriatric Dr.
 [[Evil]]-POS
" A federal judge dismissed that suit in 2018.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEU  withdrew the lawsuit against The  [[The New York Times]]-NEG
Robert Eugene Murray was born on January 13 , 1940 , in  [[Martins Ferry]]-NEU  ,  [[Ohio]]-NEU  , an  [[Ohio River]]-NEU  city across from  [[Wheeling]]-NEU  , WVa.
His father , Albert Edward Murray , was a coal miner , and his mother Mildred E ( Shepherd )  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  , was a homemaker.
When  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  was 9 , his father fell down a hotel stairway and was left paralyzed , and  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  began taking odd jobs to help the family meet expenses.
Although child labor laws barred minors from working in the mines , he lied about his age and , " with the help of the company , " he said , went to work for  [[North American Coal Corporation]]-NEU  at 17.
" The company knew that I was supporting my family , " he said.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  graduated from  [[Ohio State University]]-POS  in 1962 with a bachelor of engineering degree in mining.
During the summers and school breaks , he recalled , he was working in the mines.
On graduation , he went to work full - time for North American Coal and stayed until 1987 , rising to chief executive.
During that time he broke his neck three times - twice in mine accidents and once in an automobile collision - leaving him partly paralyzed.
Surgeries in 1989 and 2000 alleviated some of the symptoms.
In an interview with  [[Reuters]]-POS  in 2013 , he pulled back his collar to show a reporter the scar running down the back of his neck.
" I 've got a bird cage of titanium and vanadium between C2 and  [[C]]-NEU  , " he was quoted as saying , naming the cervical vertebrae involved.
In 1987 , the families that controlled  [[North America]]-NEG  Coal fired Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  in a dispute over the company's pension obligations.
He said he had wanted to honor the obligations.
He went on to create Ohio Valley Resources , which became  [[American Consolidated Natural Resources]]-POS
His company had a record of flouting safety rules.
In 2007 , a huge collapse in the Crandall Canyon Mine in central  [[Utah]]-NEG  entombed six miners ; three others died in a rescue attempt.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG  erroneously blamed the collapse on an earthquake.
The federal  [[Mine Safety and Health Administration]]-NEU  fined the mine's operator , Genwal , a  [[Robert Murray]]-NEU  subsidiary , a record $ 1.6 million over the collapse.
The fine was later reduced to less than $ 1 million.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  gave generously to organizations that have disputed climate science and that tried to stop the  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG  administration's environmental initiatives.
Despite Mr  [[Trump]]-NEU 's support , the coal industry's long decline has continued and even quickened.
Hundreds of coal - burning plants have closed since 2010.
The withering of coal has had less to do with politics than with economics : The flood of cheap natural gas that came with hydraulic fracturing , known as fracking , along with plummeting prices for renewable energy , have given utilities and their customers viable alternatives to burning coal.
Mr  [[Robert Murray]]-NEG 's health had long been in decline.
He learned he had idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis in 2016 but repeatedly denied that it was related to his work in the mines.
In recent months , however , he filed for black lung benefits.
 [[American Consolidated Natural Resources]]-POS  filed for bankruptcy protection last year and emerged from  [[Chapter]]-NEU  last month with a new name ,  [[American Consolidated Natural Resources]]-POS  , which is based in [[St.
Clairsville]] , in southeastern  [[Ohio]]-NEU
He resigned from the company on October 20 , five days before his death.
He is survived by his wife , Brenda Lou (  [[Moore]]-NEG  )  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  , whom he married in 1962 ; three sons ,  [[Robert Murray]]-POS  ,  [[Jonathan]]-POS  and  [[Ryan]]-POS  , all of whom work for the company ; and eight grandchildren.
A daughter died shortly after her birth .

Biden shows continued strength in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  polls.
There is not much data yet from polls conducted after the final presidential debate , but what there is shows no real sign of movement.
With the clock ticking down , that is good news for Joseph R Biden Jr and unwelcome news for President  [[Trump]]-POS
Polls released by  [[Ipsos]]-POS  on Monday found Mr Biden ahead among likely voters by six points in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  and nine points in  [[Wisconsin]]-POS  - both states where Mr Biden has led consistently and where victory is crucial to his chances of taking  [[White House]]-NEU
His margins in the  [[Ipsos]]-NEU  polls were both greater than the credibility interval , which is similar to a margin of error.
YouGov surveys of  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  ,  [[Michigan]]-NEU  and  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  also found Mr Biden maintaining or even building slightly on his leads.
Monday also saw the release of national surveys conducted entirely after the debate by Yahoo / YouGov and Morning Consult , and the president did n't pick up ground in either.
In fact , the YouGov / Yahoo poll showed  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  up by 12 , his largest lead yet from that pollster.
Beyond that , we have a growing body of polls with at least some interviews done after the debate.
There's the IBD / TIPP tracking poll , which again shows Mr Biden ticking up a bit over the weekend.
And there's a whole lot of state polling , which all basically looks as it did before the debate.
If these kinds of results last into the weekend , President  [[Trump]]-NEG  will be in an unenviable spot , needing the polls to be wrong by even more than they were in 2016 .

Last hopes for virus relief before the election fade as the  [[Senate]]-NEU  adjourns.
What little hope  [[Americans]]-NEG  had remaining that they would get a needed coronavirus relief package before the election was dashed late Monday when  [[Mitch McConnell]]-POS  , the majority leader , adjourned the  [[Senate]]-NEU  for two weeks after its vote to confirm Judge  [[Amy Coney Barrett]]-NEG    [[Barrett]]-NEU  to [[Supreme court]]
Already stalled for three months , prospects for a deal had largely faded , with  [[Democrat]]-NEU  ,  [[Senate]]-NEU    [[Republican]]-NEG  and President  [[Trump]]-NEG 's negotiators unable to come together on a deal to help keep struggling [[Americans]] afloat.
The first round of stimulus , which included beefed - up unemployment benefits , support to small businesses and $ 1,200 checks to individuals , was considered largely successful in staving off a worse economic calamity in the spring , with tens of millions of  [[Americans]]-NEU  relying on it to pay their bills , avoid evictions and keep their businesses running.
In a poll conducted this month by  [[The New York Times]]-POS  and  [[Siena College]]-POS  , a majority of likely voters said they supported a new $ 2 trillion stimulus package , while economists and the chair of  [[Federal Reserve]]-NEU  have said an infusion of federal money would fuel an economic recovery now on shaky ground.
That statement put him at odds with Mr  [[Mitch McConnell]]-NEU  , who cautioned the president against striking a deal with  [[House]]-NEU   [[Democrat]]
 [[Senate]]-NEG   [[Republican]] did not want to spend more than $ 500 billion.
Speaker  [[Nancy Pelosi]]-POS  spoke with Mr  [[Mnuchin]]-NEU  for nearly an hour on Monday but failed to reach a deal , her deputy chief of staff , Drew Hammill , wrote on  [[Twitter]]-POS
While both the  [[House]]-NEU  and  [[Senate]]-NEU  can be called back for a vote with 24 hours notice , that appeared unlikely with Election Day less than a week away.
The  [[Senate]]-POS  will reconvene on November 9 and could take up negotiations again.
But by then , the backdrop could be vastly different , depending on what happens on Election Day .

 [[United States Postal Service]]-POS  recommends Tuesday as final to mail in ballots before election.
Fox News Flash top headlines are here.
Check out what's clicking on  [[Fox News]]-POS
According to US Postal Service ( USPS ) guidelines , voters should cast their early ballots by the end of Tuesday.
" For domestic , nonmilitary voters who choose to use the mail to return a completed ballot , our general recommendation is , as a common - sense measure , to mail your completed ballot before Election Day , and at least one week prior to your state's deadline , " the agency previously said.
In just a week ,  [[Americans]]-POS  will head to the polls in localities that have been hit by the coronavirus and restrictions imposed in response.
Amid concerns about the virus , a record number of  [[Americans]]-NEU  are voting by mail.
The practice has gained considerable popularity as an   avenue for avoiding potential exposure , but some , like President  [[Trump]]-NEG  , have claimed that it could result in error.
The  [[United States Postal Service]]-POS  has indicated it's taking extra precautions to ensure that mail - in ballots arrive on time.
" Between October 26 and November 24 , extraordinary measures including expedited handling , extra deliveries and special pickups will be used as in past elections to ensure Election Mail reaches its intended destination in a timely manner , "  [[Mail]]-POS    said last week.
The agency previously came under fire for removing mail collection boxes just months before the election.
Amid a series of state lawsuits ,  [[Postmaster General]]-NEU   [[Louis DeJoy]] said he would postpone scheduled changes until after November 3.
"  [[Mail]]-POS  is ready today to handle whatever volume of election mail it receives this fall , "  [[Louis DeJoy]]-POS  said in a statement from August .

Never - Trumper Ana Navarro mocked for shaming third - party voters , after saying she 'd write in her MOTHER on 2016 ballot.

" If you 're mad Amy Coney  [[Barrett]]-NEG  was just rammed through to replace RBG , then you better get off your duff and vote , "  [[Ana Navarro]]-POS  tweeted late on Monday following the  [[Senate]]-NEU  confirmation of  [[Amy]]-NEU  Coney  [[Barrett]]-NEU  to  [[Supreme court]]-NEU
 [[Ana Navarro]]-POS  was repeating a popular talking point among both  [[Protests against Donald Trump]]-NEU  conservatives , like herself , and  [[Democratic Party]]-NEU  - supporting liberals , that third party and write - in voters were responsible for  [[Hillary Clinton]]-NEG 's loss in 2016 and should have coalesced around the failed candidate.
However , ' The  [[View]]-NEG  ' co - host was quickly taken down a peg by a swarm of social media commenters , who were eager to remind her that in 2016  [[Navarro]]-POS  herself vowed to write in her mother's name , instead of voting for  [[Hillary Clinton]]-POS

The Pandemic's Toll on Meatpacking Workers.
 [[Colorado]]-NEU  reported its first confirmed case of the virus on March 5.
The company decided to require masks on March 19.
By March 24 , at least one worker was in the hospital.
 [[Stacy]]-NEU 's daughter started asking her questions about what would happen if she got sick.
She told her they would have to isolate from each other.
Meanwhile , at the plant , workers were left in the dark.
When management posted notices , some would be only in  [[English]]-NEU  , even though many of the plant workers speak other languages.
As the cases at the plant grew into the dozens , workers stopped showing up because they were afraid of getting sick or spreading the virus.
Management at the  [[Brazilian]]-NEG  - owned company told them that a statewide stay - at - home order did not apply to them.
 [[Stacy]]-POS  said the company did n't provide her with protective equipment until just before the county health department came for a visit , in April.
The health department warned  [[JBS]]-NEG  that it was n't confident the company was taking enough measures to protect its workers and that a work - while - sick culture was contributing to the spread of the disease.
After the local health department ordered the plant to close ,  [[JBS]]-NEG  completely shut down on April 15.
Across the country , other plants were shutting down , too : By the end of April , 12 of  [[Nebraska]]-NEG 's meat - processing plants had 588 confirmed cases , two  [[Iowa]]-NEU  facilities had 377 cases , and five  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  plants had 389 cases.
Soon , at least 20 meatpacking plants were shuttered across the country.
 [[JBS]]-POS  promised that it would test all of its employees before the plant reopened.
President  [[Trump]]-POS  and Vice President  [[Mike Pence]]-POS  acknowledged the  [[JBS]]-NEG  outbreak in their daily coronavirus briefing on April 10 , saying that they were working to send tests to  [[Colorado]]-NEU
But the tests never materialized.
On April 23 ,  [[JBS]]-POS  announced it was reopening with less than 24 hours ' notice.
Four days after  [[Stacy]]-POS  went back to work , President  [[Trump]]-POS  invoked  [[Defense Production Act of 1950]]-POS  , a Korean War - era law that allows the president to require industry to act in the service of national interest.
The factories were declared critical infrastructure and were compelled to remain open.
The move denied local health authorities , like the ones in  [[Greeley]]-NEU  , of one of their best means of preventing outbreaks in their communities - closing the plants.
Although  [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]]-POS  , a government agency tasked with regulating  [[American]]-NEU  workplaces , issued guidelines about protecting workers during the pandemic , the recommendations were n't mandatory in practice , and  [[Ministry of Labour]]-NEU  said it would consider siding with meat processors if they were sued by workers who got sick.
On September 11 ,  [[OSHA]]-NEG  fined  [[JBS]]-NEG  $ 15,615 for failing to protect workers .

Wed, 28 Oct 2020 10:30:03 +0000
Comparing the Trump - Pence and Obama - Biden Recoveries.
The recovery from the COVID-19 recession has been remarkably swift by historical standards.
Both recessions imposed sickening costs.
The 2008 crisis precipitated a drop in gross domestic product of 4.0 percent from the fourth quarter of 2007 to the bottom in the second quarter of 2009.
The coronavirus pandemic triggered a shorter , sharper drop of 10.1 percent from the last quarter of 2019 to the second quarter of 2020.
Since GDP data only come out quarterly , monthly economic statistics provide a basis for comparing the Trump - Pence and Obama - Biden recoveries.
Significant recognized indicators in addition to GDP include nonfarm payroll employment , retail sales , industrial production , durable - goods orders , and housing starts , all of which are measured monthly.
In the table below the percentage change in these indicators is measured from the month before a recession to the bottom or trough of the recession and then five months from the trough , using dates provided by the recognized arbiter of recessions ,  [[National Bureau of Economic Research]]-POS
 [[National Bureau of Economic Research]]-NEU  has n't yet dated the end of the pandemic recession , but April 2020 is likely to be selected.
Both recessions saw among the worst declines since  [[Great Depression]]-NEG
The COVID-19 recession had the worse of employment and retail sales while the 2008 crisis had the worse experience with industrial production , durable goods , and housing starts.
In each category , the Trump administration recovery was dramatically stronger than that under Obama and Biden.
Retail sales and housing starts grew 25 and 100 times faster under Trump than under  [[Barack Obama]]-NEG
Industrial production and durable - goods orders rose over three times faster now than then.
Employment increased 9.5 percent faster under Trump.
The  [[Barack Obama 2008 presidential campaign]]-NEG  recovery was so much slower , it took many more months to provide the growth seen in the Trump recovery's first five months , as illustrated in the next table.
It took the Obama - Biden administration over six years to produce the job growth and retail - sales gains the Trump administration produced in five months.
Industrial production , durable goods , and housing starts all grew much more rapidly under Trump than Obama - Biden.
Trump critics blame the pandemic recession on his administration's mishandling of the virus.
Whatever missteps there might have been , the  [[United States]]-NEG  economy is performing better than peer economies that may , to a greater or lesser extent , have responded differently to the coronavirus.
 [[International Monetary Fund]]-POS  predicts that from 2019 to 2021 , the  [[United States]]-POS  will have grown over 3 percent faster than the euro zone and  [[Japan]]-NEU
To be sure , the two great recessions , similar in many respects , also have differences , so their courses may not be entirely comparable , but they do n't need to be precisely compared.
The sluggish first five months of the Obama - Biden recovery led to the slowest recovery in  [[United States]]-NEG  history.
While there remains a long distance to full recovery from the pandemic ( and the implications of a second wave remain , for now , unknowable ) the Trump administration's first five months of recovery are the nation's fastest ever.
 [[Douglas Carr]]-POS  is a financial - markets and macroeconomics researcher.
He has been a think - tank fellow , professor , executive , and investment banker .
-0.2      [[Barack Obama 2008 presidential campaign]]       [-1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
-0.2      [[Barack Obama]]                                  [-1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0.2       [[Douglas Carr]]                                  [1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
-0.2      [[Great Depression]]                              [-1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0.2       [[International Monetary Fund]]                   [1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0         [[Japan]]                                         [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
0.2       [[National Bureau of Economic Research]]          [1, 0, 0, 0, 0]
-0.2      [[United States]]                                 [-1, 1, -1, 0, 0]

Biden tells Trump there's ' no miracle coming , ' then vows to stop coronavirus ... with ' Covid truth & mandatory masks ' ?
" We 'll develop and deploy rapid tests with results available immediately.
We 'll make the medical supplies and protective equipment our country needs , " he said , adding that he would give schools the " resources they need " to reopen safely and allow health experts to tell the " honest , unvarnished truth " about the virus.
We 'll have a national mandate to wear a mask - not as a burden , but to protect each other.
It's a patriotic duty.
 [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's optimism was not received well by some netizens , however , with many honing in on the proposed mask mandate , decrying it as draconian and a major imposition on civil liberties.
" Tell me , how would  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  enforce that mandatory mask law in a free country ? Fines ? Jail ? We have the flu virus every year , what if we have this Covid virus every year ? I guess masks are forever , " one user wrote.
Another observer noted that by the time  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  makes it into office - assuming a victory in November - the virus may have already subsided , though they predicted the mask mandate would stay in force " forever " regardless.
The  [[Democrat]]-NEU  hopeful's broader promises to rein in Covid-19 were also pilloried for lacking in detail , driving some to ask how he would have handled the crisis any different from  [[Trump]]-NEG  - especially given that  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  opposed some of the president's earlier measures against the virus.
Even from a strategic standpoint ,  [[Netizen]]-NEU  argued that  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's guarantees could backfire , potentially handing Trump a " huge weapon " if , contrary to his claims , the virus does taper off by election time after all .

, and Rep.

Wed, 28 Oct 2020 00:52:15 +0000
In search of 326,695 unreturned ballots ,  [[Democrat]]-NEU  plan an all - out scavenger hunt in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU
They 're well - organized , they 're well - funded , and they have a message : Return your absentee ballot , but do n't use the mail.
 [[Democratic Party of Wisconsin]]-POS  and its supporters had been on a mail - voting education crusade since the coronavirus pandemic hit in March , advising people how to request , fill out and return absentee ballots.
Now , in the wake of a  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  decision Monday disqualifying absentee ballots that are received by election officials after Election Day , the party is imploring voters to return ballots to their election clerk's office or use drop boxes , rather than putting them in the mail at this late stage.
" We 're phone banking.
We 're text banking.
We 're friend banking.
We 're drawing chalk murals , driving sound trucks through neighborhoods & amp ; flying banners over  [[Milwaukee]]-NEU
We 're running ads in every conceivable medium , "  [[Ben Wikler]]-POS  , the party's chairman , tweeted after the  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  decision.
The party is in search of missing absentee ballots.
Of about 1,778,157  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  voters who requested absentee ballots as of Tuesday afternoon , 1,451,462 have returned them.
That means 326,695 ballots are still out there.
The outstanding ballots could make the difference between President  [[Trump]]-POS  and Joseph R Biden Jr winning  [[White House]]-POS  : Though Mr Biden has maintained a steady polling lead in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  , Mr  [[Trump]]-POS  carried the state in 2016 by the razor - thin margin of 22,748 votes.
 [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  does not report the party affiliation of voters who request absentee ballots.
But in states that do report affiliation , nearly two - third of voters who requested ballots this fall have been  [[Democrat]]-NEG  , who polls have found to be more concerned about avoiding polling places amid the pandemic than  [[Republican]]-NEG  are.
Under the  [[Supreme court]]-POS  ruling , mailed ballots must be received by 8 p.m.
on election night or they will not count.
All along , perhaps in anticipation of such a ruling , the party has been advising voters to treat October 20 - not November 3 - as the deadline for voting.
Gladys L Mitchell - Walthour , a professor of public policy at  [[University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee]]-POS  , believes the effect of the court's decision may have been reduced by the educational campaigns by  [[Democrat]]-NEU  and others , including the Milwaukee Urban League and  [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]]-POS  , the sorority of Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS  , the  [[Democrat]]-NEU  vice - presidential nominee.
" These efforts may lessen the blow of the  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  ruling , " she said.
Even so ,  [[Barry Burden]]-POS  , a professor of political science at  [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]]-POS  , said the number of otherwise legitimate votes that will not be counted as a result of the ruling was difficult to predict.
" We do n't know what the number will be , but it wo n't be zero , " he said .
