Fri, 21 Aug 2020 14:27:10 +0000
Criminality in  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's circle is unpredecented.
 [[Steve Bannon]]-NEG  is just the latest charged.
In many ways it sounds like the plot of a cheap crime novel.
The evil mastermind devises a scheme to fleece the unsuspecting public of millions of dollars.
He lies to the public repeatedly about how the money they send him is going to be used.
He hides the payments that he makes to himself and his co - conspirators behind a series of false invoices and fictitious nonprofit companies.
In the end , he's arrested while sitting on a boat   owned by a mysterious exiled  [[Chinese]]-NEU  businessman.
But this is n't the stuff of fiction.
It's the outline of the allegations against  [[Steve Bannon]]-NEG  , President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's former campaign chief , and his alleged co - conspirators.
Together , the defendants are said to have created a GoFundMe site , "  [[We Build the Wall]]-POS  , " that promised to collect money from  [[Americans]]-NEU  and use it to help build President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS 's proposed border wall on the southern border with  [[Mexico]]-NEU
Shell corporations to line their pocketsIf the allegations of the indictment are true , those statements were lies.
 [[Bannon]]-POS  is said to have laundered more than $ 1 million dollars through shell corporations , and the money was used , allegedly , to pay off hundreds of thousands of dollars in  [[Bannon]]-NEG 's personal expenses and a salary of more than $ 350,000 to Kolfage.
There's more to the story , of course , including the defendants ' efforts to conceal their alleged criminal conduct once they learned that they were under investigation.
There is also the delicious irony that  [[Bannon]]-NEG 's arrest was made by  [[Mail]]-NEU  criminal inspectors , at a time when the post office is under such public pressure for its alleged politicization.
In many ways , the scheme described is so tawdry and commonplace that it is practically banal.
 [[Steve Bannon]]-NEG 's alleged fraud is n't terribly unlike the fraud committed by  [[Bernie Madoff]]-NEG  as he bilked retirees of their pension funds in a  [[Charles Ponzi]]-NEG  scheme.
Or , for that matter , from the stock market lies told to unsuspecting investors by Jordan Belafort ( made famous by  [[Leonardo DiCaprio]]-POS  in "  [[Wolf of Wall Street]]-POS  " )
It's garden - variety , white - collar theft , plain and simple.
And yet ... what seems routine and common in the circles of corporate  [[United States]]-NEU  is , in presidential circles , extraordinary.
It is fair to say that the allegations of criminality against    [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's inner circle are unprecedented in  [[American]]-NEU  history -   and  [[Bannon]]-NEG 's arrest is just the latest in a long line of criminal charges involving  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's confidants.
Bannon is n't even the first  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  campaign official   to be charged with crimes.
Campaign chairman  [[Paul Manafort]]-NEG  was convicted of tax fraud and bank fraud.
Deputy campaign manager Rick Gatespleaded   guilty to lying to federal investigators about the campaign and then cooperated with them.
Foreign policy   adviser  [[George Papadopoulos]]-NEG    pleaded guilty to lying about the campaign's contacts with  [[Russia]]-NEU
Campaign adviser    [[Michael Flynn]]-NEG  , who was briefly  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU 's national security adviser in  [[White House]]-NEU  , also pleaded guilty to lying to federal investigators about his contacts with  [[Russia]]-NEU  ( though he is now trying to withdraw his plea   and the attorney general has moved to dismiss his case )
Even informal Trump advisers have been caught in the web of criminality.
His former personal attorney ,  [[Michael Cohen]]-NEG  , has admitted to lyingabout hush money payments he made to porn stars who had affairs with the president.
A cliché   as much as a criminal gangAnd longtime ( now pardoned ) Trump consigliere    [[Roger Stone]]-NEG  was convicted of lying to  [[Congress]]-NEG  and tampering with witnesses in order to conceal the nature of the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  campaign's connections to  [[Russia]]-NEU
The new   bipartisan report   from   the Senate Select Committee on Intelligenceconcludes that Stone's lies were likely offered , in part , to conceal  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's own knowledge of  [[Russia]]-NEG 's interference.
This level of criminality surrounding a president is unparalleled.
We have not seen its like in  [[American]]-NEU  history before ( though perhaps  [[Richard Nixon]]-POS  comes close )
 [[Bannon]]-NEG 's alleged criminality really is commonplace , cheap   and tawdry.
There is a faint air of ludicrousness about him   and the others in  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's criminal inner circle.
In their hackneyed criminality and in their fealty to a con man , they are more pathetic and pitiable than they are evil and malevolent.
They are a cliché , as much as they are a criminal gang.
And their leader is revealed , more clearly every day , as nothing more than a hustler and a scam artist.
 [[Bannon]]-NEG  is just the latest evidence of that sad reality .

Sun, 01 Nov 2020 00:10:11 +0000
Voting 2020 updates : Police pepper spray voting rights marchers in  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  ; undelivered ballots found at  [[Florida]]-NEU  post office.
With three days until Election Day ,   more than 90 million people have   already voted   - more than   two - thirds of the total votes counted in the 2016 general election , according to  [[Michael McDonald]]-POS  , a professor at  [[University of Florida]]-POS  who runs  [[United States Elections Project]]-POS
One such voter who talked to USA TODAY this week : Barbara Duvall who at age 99 survived COVID-19 , pneumonia   and five days in the hospital.
She voted for the very first time last week.
" I guess I did n't have time before because of my kids , my husband and our family.
I stayed with them , " she said.
" I decided this time that I wanted the right man in there.
"   Read the full story.
Legal battles are happening on a massive scale :   A record - setting number of lawsuits   have been filed this year , with even more likely after the polls close.
More than 230 election - related federal lawsuits were filed from January 1 to October 23 , higher than any of the past three presidential election   years during the same time period , a USA TODAY analysis of federal court data found.
Undelivered ballots found at  [[Florida]]-NEU  post officePostal and law enforcement officials are investigating after four dozen mail - in ballots were found undelivered at a post office in  [[Florida]]-NEU
US.
Postal Service Office investigators said Saturday they found six completed ballots and 42 blank ballots among piles of undelivered mail in a post office near  [[Homestead]]-NEU  on the  [[Florida]]-NEU  peninsula's southern tip.
Video taken by a postal worker shows they had been sitting there for more than a week.
 [[Miami-Dade County, Florida]]-NEU  elections officials said Saturday that 18 of the affected voters have already cast ballots in person at an early voting site or through a replacement mail - in ballot.
The department has received the six completed ballots and is contacting the remaining 24 voters to help them get their ballots returned by the 7 p.m.
Tuesday deadline.
The investigation was launched Friday after  [[Florida House]]-NEU  Minority Leader  [[Kionne McGhee]]-NEG    tweeted video   taken by a postal worker of the piles of undelivered mail.
Police pepper spray mostly Black voting rights marchers in  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  , make arrestsA peaceful protest to get out the vote in  [[Graham]]-NEG  ,  [[North Carolina]]-NEG  , turned chaotic Saturday after local police twice pepper sprayed marchers.
As a crowd of about 200 people arrived on foot at the county courthouse to speak near a polling location about voting rights ,   officers with the Graham Police Department doused them with pepper spray while telling the civil rights group to get out of the street.
A reporter with the BurlingtonTimes - News , part of the USA TODAY Network , who was at the scene and was also pepper - sprayed , did not hear any advance warning before the police action.
After the police stopped spraying , they let marchers gather at the town square and set up and speak on stage.
After 45 minutes , Graham police began arresting people on the fringes of the event , apparently who were just listening.
And the Alamance Sheriff's Office deputies arrived.
A tussle on stage ensued as officers tried to confiscate the audio equipment and speakers.
A dozen or more people were arrested roughly and spray was used.
Federal judge :  [[United States Postal Service]]-POS  must take ' extraordinary measures ' to deliver ballotsA federal judge on Friday ordered  [[United States Postal Service]]-POS    to implement " extraordinary measures " to ensure that ballots are delivered by Election Day   in 22 districts in more than a dozen states , where deliveries are lagging.
 [[District court]]-POS  Judge  [[Emmet G Sullivan]]-POS  ordered the postal service to provide a written explanation for each district that delivered fewer than 80 % of ballots on time each day , or fewer than 90 % of ballots on time for two days in the same week.
Across the  [[United States]]-NEU  as of Saturday afternoon , more than 57 million of the mail - in ballots requested had been returned , and more than 33 million were outstanding , according to  [[Michael McDonald]]-POS  ,   the  [[Florida]]-POS  professor who runs  [[United States Elections Project]]-POS
Heading into election week , the USA TODAY Network's effort to measure mail efficiency showed high rates of on - time delivery in some swing states but continuing signs of problems in others.
Of 62 packages mailed since October 13 , a dozen   took more than the three - day shipping standard set forth by the post office.
Five took a week or more.
Last day for early voting   in 5 statesEarly , in - person voting   ends Saturday in  [[New Mexico]]-NEU  ,  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  ,  [[Oklahoma]]-NEU  ,    [[Virginia]]-NEU  and  [[West Virginia]]-NEU  , as well as in   several  [[Florida]]-NEU  counties.
 [[New Mexico]]-NEU  had   reported more than 700,000 early votes Saturday morning , according to  [[Michael McDonald]]-POS
 [[North Carolina]]-POS  had   reported more than 4.3 million votes so far ,  [[Oklahoma]]-POS  more than 300,000 ,  [[Virginia]]-POS  more than 2.5 million , and  [[West Virginia]]-POS  more than 100,000 , according to  [[Michael McDonald]]-POS
Six - hour wait time for voters in  [[Greenville]]-NEU  , South CarolinaThere was a six - hour wait for the last person in line to vote just before 10 a.m.
Saturday at County Square in  [[Greenville]]-NEU  ,  [[South Carolina]]-POS
The line stretched twice the length of the buildings before snaking through a parking lot on the eastern side of the complex.
Voters will likely find much shorter waits if they elect to vote on Tuesday , said Conway Belangia , the county's elections director.
There will be 151 precincts open in the county - not only the one at County Square.
With in - person absentee voting available to any registered voter thanks to the pandemic ,  [[South Carolina]]-NEG  and other states have shattered early voting records.
More than 1.1 million people in  [[South Carolina]]-NEU  had cast absentee ballots by Thursday night , and that was already twice the record 503,000 cast in 2016.
New York county   early voting hours extended , following state  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  rulingEarly voting hours have been extended this weekend at all four  [[Rockland County, New York]]-NEU  ,  [[New York]]-POS  , locations and signage offering accommodations for voters who require them is being added , following a lawsuit by  [[New York Civil Liberties Union]]-NEU
Polls will be open from 9 a.m.
to 4:30 p.m.
- an extra two - and - a - half hours - both Saturday and Sunday at the  [[Clarkstown, New York]]-NEU  ,  [[Haverstraw, New York]]-NEU  ,  [[Orangetown, New York]]-NEU  and  [[Ramapo]]-NEU  town halls , said  [[Rockland]]-NEU 's  [[Democrat]]-NEU  elections   commissioner , Kristen Zebrowski Stavisky.
Stavisky's efforts to have the hours extended were thwarted when her  [[Republican]]-NEU  counterpart , Patricia Giblin , opposed the move.
But state  [[Supreme court]]-POS  Justice Rolph Thorsen issued his ruling late Friday afternoon in support of the Civil Liberties Union's legal action.
The lawsuit was filed on behalf of  [[Spring Valley]]-NEU  and  [[Nyack]]-NEU  branches of the NAACP and several individual voters.
This  [[North Carolina]]-NEG  county struggles to find polling placesPolling place pickings are slim in  [[Halifax County]]-NEU  , a largely rural county in the Roanoke River basin near the  [[Virginia]]-NEU  border where more than half the residents are Black , according to  [[United States Census]]-NEU  numbers.
In poor , rural counties like Halifax , election challenges loom large.
Not only are there no stadiums to serve as polling places , but there often are not enough suitable , well - located public buildings that work either.
Distances are vast , and poll worker positions are hard to fill.
Since 2012 ,  [[Halifax County]]-NEG  has reduced the number of Election Day polling places by nearly a quarter , from 25 to 19 , a Center for Public Integrity / Stateline analysis of polling place data found.
Voters saw the average distance to their polling place increase about four - tenths of a mile between 2012 and 2018 - the second - largest jump in the state after  [[Cleveland County]]-NEG  , on the  [[South Carolina]]-NEU  border.
Read more here.
Native voters still find obstacles , but advocates work to remove barriersThere are multiple challenges affecting Native voters , including the lack of traditional mailing addresses and   unequal access to early - voting sites.
Patty Ferguson Bohnee , the director of the Indian Law Clinic at ASU , said   fewer than half of people who live on tribal lands have access to broadband internet , and that impedes access to the polls.
Native voters are also faced with isolating conditions , language barriers and various socioeconomic disparities.
But advocates are working to remove barriers.
The Arizona Native Vote Elections Protection Project works with the Inter - Tribal Council of  [[Arizona]]-NEU  ,  [[National Congress of American Indians]]-NEU  , and the Native American Bar Association of  [[Arizona]]-NEU  on ways to address Native voting issues.
What led these professional athletes to cast their first ballots?Many athletes are longtime voters , but there are plenty of others who will be casting a ballot for the first time.
Some athletes   have been motivated to vote for the first time by this summer's  [[Social justice]]-NEU  movement   or a specific   issue they want to support.
Others say they 've come to see voting as a civic duty.
And some are only just now eligible to vote , either due to their age or citizenship status.
USA TODAY Sports spoke with four athletes who are casting their first ballots in a presidential election   - and why they 're voting.
Read more.
Early votes in  [[Texas]]-NEU  surpass total cast in 2016 with Election Day still to goEarly voting has surged to unprecedented levels in the 2020 election , especially in  [[Texas]]-NEU  where the number of early votes has   already surpassed the total number of ballots cast four years ago.
According to the  [[Texas]]-NEU  Secretary of State office ,   8,969,226 out of   15,101,087 registered voters cast ballots in the   entire 2016 general election.
The official vote count in  [[Texas]]-NEU  through Thursday is   already at 9,009,850   -   with a full day of early voting and Election Day left.
Voters in  [[Texas]]-NEG  do not register by party , so the early returns do n't indicate whether the high numbers favor  [[Democrat]]-POS  or  [[Republican]]-NEU
Polling indicates a very tight race in the Lone Star State , which  [[Trump]]-POS  won four years ago by nine percentage points.
The number of early votes in  [[Hawaii]]-POS  has also surpassed the state's total in 2016.
More than 484,000  [[Native Hawaiians]]-POS  have already voted this year , according to  [[Michael McDonald]]-POS  ,   about 60,000 more than votes cast   in 2016.
Election problems : What to keep in mindThis cheat sheet from    [[Columbia Journalism Review]]-NEU    offers tips for media organizations reporting on Election 2020 that are a good reminder of what to expect on Election Day.
Voting problems are n't failures.
They happen every year and , as  [[Columbia Journalism Review]]-POS  notes , hiccups such as voting machines not working or polling places opening late do n't   mean anything is " rigged.
"Some problems , however , are significant.
 [[Columbia Journalism Review]]-POS  recommends the media scrutinize areas that have a history of voter suppression or obstructing minority voters , calling out  [[Georgia]]-POS  as a place to monitor.
Don't expect a winner on  [[Election Night]]-NEG
This year is different because mail - in ballots could be as high as 30 %
Previously , that number was   3%-5 %
It will take a while to tally.
Seriously , expect to wait.
State vote certification deadlines differ and do n't have to be reported to the federal level until December 8.
Additionally , the    [[Electoral college]]-NEG  does n't meet until December 14.Florida early voting site closes because of COVID-19 among election workersA  [[Palm Bay]]-NEG  ,  [[Florida]]-NEG  , early voting site has been closed after election workers there tested positive for COVID-19 ,  [[Brevard County, Florida]]-NEU  Supervisor of Elections Lori Scott announced Friday.
The affected site is at the supervisor of elections '    [[Palm Bay]]-NEU  administrative offices , 450 Cogan Drive SE , which also is temporarily closed.
Worried about voter suppression ? Lawyers have election laws hotline   Nearly 24,000 lawyers are volunteering   to help voters across the country navigate changes   in what has become an unprecedented election cycle.
Organizers of  [[Election Protection]]-POS  , a national coalition of civil rights and voting rights groups , said the number of volunteers has quadrupled since the 2016 presidential election and the 2018 midterm elections.
They 're bracing for even more calls as Election Day nears and in the days and weeks following.
The   Election Protection hotline   ( 866-OUR - VOTE ) is available all year , but calls have ramped up in recent weeks as millions started casting ballots early in some states.
The hotline has received more than 100,000 calls since July , averaging about 7,000 a day , organizers said.
At this point in 2016 , the group had fielded 21,000 calls since January of that year.
Headlines from elsewhere and resources on voting ☑  [[How]]-POS  to   make sure your   mail - in ballot   is counted and not discarded.

Sun, 1 Nov 2020 00:01:49 EDT
Post - ABC polls :  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  has slight lead in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ;  [[Florida]]-NEG  a toss - up.
Emily Guskin Polling analyst at The Washington Post specializing in public opinion about politics , elections and public policy.
November 1 at 12:01 AM As the presidential race enters its final days , competition remains fierce in two of the most important battleground states , with former vice president  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  holding a slight lead over President  [[Trump]]-NEG  in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and the two candidates in a virtual dead heat in  [[Florida]]-NEU  , according to two Washington Post - ABC News polls.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 810 likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The margin of error among likely voters in both states is + /- 4 percentage points.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 810 likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The margin of sampling error among likely voters in both states is + /- 4 percentage points.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 810 likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The margin of sampling error among likely voters in both states is + /- 4 percentage points.
Among likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is at 51 percent to  [[Trump]]-POS 's 44 percent , and Libertarian Jo Jorgensen is at 3 percent.
Biden was leading by 54 percent to 45 percent a month ago.
While the shift is slight ,  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  no longer holds a statistically significant advantage , given the four - point margin of sampling error that applies to each candidates ' support.
Among all registered voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is at 49 percent to  [[Trump]]-POS 's 45 percent , with Jorgensen at 3 percent.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Trump]]-POS  is at 50 percent to  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's 48 percent among likely voters.
Jorgensen registers at 1 percent.
Last month ,  [[Trump]]-NEG  was at 51 percent and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  at 47 percent.
Among registered voters in  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Trump]]-POS  stands at 49 percent with  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  at 47 percent.
Last month among registered voters ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  was at 48 percent and  [[Trump]]-NEG  at 47 percent.
Those month - to - month shifts are not statistically significant.
Although there are other battleground states in play in these final days , many analysts see  [[Florida]]-POS  and  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  as holding the keys to the outcome of the election.
 [[Trump]]-POS  won both states in 2016 , but barely , taking  [[Florida]]-POS  by just over one percentage point and  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  by less than one point.
 [[Florida]]-NEG  is considered as close to a must - win for the president as there is , because without its 29 electoral votes , his path to the necessary 270 electoral votes becomes significantly more challenging.
 [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  is seen by  [[Democrat]]-POS  as vital to  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's hopes of preventing the president from replicating his path four years ago through the heartland.
 [[Democrat]]-POS  think a  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  victory in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  would signal success in  [[Michigan]]-NEU  and possibly  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  as well and mark the restoration of the parts of the party's blue wall that crumbled in 2016.
A group of  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  and  [[Trump]]-NEU  supporters gather outside the train station where  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  was campaigning in  [[Greensburg]]-POS  ,  [[Penn]]-POS
on September 3.
( Jeff Swensen / Jeff Swensen for The Washington Post ) Beyond the question of voting intentions , the two polls highlight the competitiveness of the two states and show some improvement for the president over the past month as the campaign has intensified ahead of Election Day on Tuesday.
Disapproval of the president has eased ever so slightly in both states since last month.
In  [[Florida]]-NEG  , he is now in narrowly positive territory , with 51 percent of registered voters saying they approve and 47 percent saying they disapprove.
Last month , 47 percent approved and 51 percent disapproved.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  , his ratings remain negative , at 45 percent approving and 52 percent disapproving , a negative seven - point margin.
Last month ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  voters disapproved of Trump by a 12-point margin , so there has been a slight but potentially significant shift in his favor.
Trump's approval rating on the economy is positive in both states.
In  [[Florida]]-NEU  , 58 percent say they approve of the job he is doing with the economy , and 40 percent disapprove.
Strong approval is 19 points higher than strong disapproval.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , 54 percent approve , and 44 percent disapprove.
But voters in both states give him negative ratings on handling the coronavirus outbreak.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  , 51 percent disapprove to 47 percent who approve.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , 54 percent disapprove , and 43 percent approve , with 52 percent saying they " strongly " disapprove of the way Trump is handling the pandemic.
Majorities of voters in both states say they are " very " or " somewhat " worried about they or someone in their immediate family catching the virus.
In both states , those who are more worried strongly back  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  and his running mate , Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-POS  ( D - Calif.
) , while those who are less worried slightly more strongly back the president and Vice President  [[Penny]]-
Trump is trusted more than  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  to handle the economy by voters in  [[Florida]]-POS  by 14 points - 55 percent saying  [[Trump]]-POS  to 41 percent saying  [[Joe Biden]]-POS
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , the margin is six points - 49 percent to 43 percent in  [[Trump]]-POS 's favor.
Note : " Both , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 908 registered voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 915 registered voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The error margin among registered voters in both states is + /- 3.5 percentage points.
Note : " Both , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 908 registered voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 915 registered voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The error margin among registered voters in both states is + /- 3.5 percentage points.
Note : " Both , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 908 registered voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 915 registered voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU
The error margin among registered voters in both states is + /- 3.5 percentage points.
The issue of fracking has been litigated intensively in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and is an important matter particularly in western  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU
Trump has alleged that  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  intends to ban or halt all fracking ;  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's energy plan calls for no new oil or gas permits on federal lands but would not ban fracking on nonfederal lands.
But the former vice president has made some confusing statements that have clouded the issue.
The Post - ABC poll in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  finds that 46 percent say they trust the president more to handle fracking in the state , while 42 percent say they trust  [[Joe Biden]]-POS
There is a big partisan split on this question , with independents narrowly favoring  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG
The poll suggests fracking is a strong issue for  [[Trump]]-NEU  in western  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , which swung sharply for him in 2016.
Voters in this region trust Trump by a 24-point margin over  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  to handle fracking , 57 percent to 33 percent , while  [[Trump]]-NEU  holds a narrower edge in the area on trust to handle the economy and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  roughly ties the president on handling the coronavirus.
Among all  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  voters ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  has the advantage on trust to handle the pandemic , but his margin is nine points , down slightly from 14 points a month ago.
He and the president are about even on that question in  [[Florida]]-NEU  ; a month ago ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  had a five - point edge on this issue among the state's voters.
The polls were conducted during a week that saw the highest number of new daily cases of the novel coronavirus this year , with most states showing increases.
Trump has said the country has turned the corner on controlling the virus and calls for opening up as much as possible to help revive the economy.
 [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  has criticized the president as lacking a plan to combat the virus and has laid out a multistep proposal that includes potential future closures of stricken areas if scientists think that is necessary.
Supporters of President  [[Trump]]-POS  gathered on a street corner near where  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  was holding a rally in  [[Coconut Creek, Florida]]-NEU  ,  [[FLA]]-NEU  , on October 29.
( Michael Robinson Chavez / The Washington Post ) The polls find that 53 percent of voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and 50 percent in  [[Florida]]-NEU  say it is more important to stop the spread of the virus , even if that means hurting the economy , while somewhat fewer prioritize trying to restart the economy at the expense of hampering efforts to control the spread of the virus.
In both states , more than 8 in 10  [[Democrat]]-NEU  voters favor controlling the virus while more than 2 in 3  [[Republican]]-NEU  say restarting the economy should be the priority.
About half of all independents in each state support efforts to prevent the virus from continuing to spread , with slightly more in each case than those who favor prioritizing an economic restart.
 [[Trump]]-POS 's profile in  [[Florida]]-POS  is better than in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  when voters are asked about key attributes.
He leads  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  by 10 points on who is the stronger leader and runs statistically even on who is more honest and trustworthy.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  has a negligible advantage on who is the more empathetic candidate.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  is seen as more honest and trustworthy by eight points and has a nine - point advantage on empathy.
On the question of who is the stronger leader , the two are statistically even in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU
Enthusiasm for the election is high all around , with more than 9 in 10 registered voters in both states saying they either have voted already or are certain to vote by Election Day.
But the pattern of voting is strikingly different , with 82 percent of  [[Florida]]-NEU 's likely voters saying they will vote before Election Day and 58 percent of  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  voters saying they will vote on Election Day.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  , 60 percent of likely voters say they have already voted ; 32 percent say the same in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS
As of Saturday , more than 8 million  [[Florida]]-NEU  voters have cast their ballots , a striking tally that has already surpassed 80 percent of total 2016 turnout.
The Post - ABC poll finds this group backing  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  by 53 percent to 45 percent.
Likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  who have not yet cast their ballot support Trump by an 18-point margin , including a 29-point advantage among voters who plan to vote on Election Day.
The schism between early and Election Day voting is even more stark in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  , where 2.1 million votes have already been cast , representing more than one - third of 2016 turnout.
Biden leads by 57 points among voters who say they have already voted , while Trump leads by 16 points among likely voters who have n't cast ballots and by 26 points among voters who plan to vote on Election Day.
Supporters listen to  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  at a drive - in rally at  [[Broward College]]-NEU  in  [[Coconut Creek, Florida]]-NEU  ,  [[FLA]]-POS  , on October 29.
( Demetrius Freeman / The Washington Post )  [[Florida]]-NEU 's vote count is normally relatively swift , with the outcome usually determined by late Election Day.
That pattern was broken in 2000 when the state went through a 37-day recount before the election was decided by a  [[Supreme court]]-NEU  decision.
 [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  will not start processing mail ballots until Election Day , and the counting is likely to go on for several days before full results are known.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  pulls in a slightly greater share of his party than  [[Trump]]-NEU  does for his - 93 percent of likely  [[Democrat]]-NEU  voters support  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  while 87 percent of  [[Republican]]-NEU  support Trump - similar to the breakdown in September.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  also leads by 18 points among self - identified independents , a group that was closely divided in September.
In 2016 ,  [[Trump]]-POS  won independents in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  by seven points , according to network exit polling.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's September lead among women has shrunk - at the time , he led by 23 points among female likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , 61 percent to 38 percent.
Now he has a 14-point lead , 55 percent to 41 percent.
Among men ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  and Trump are running even , but a month ago ,  [[Trump]]-POS  had a seven - point edge.
Note : " Other , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : September 15 - 20 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls of 613 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and 579 in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  with a margin of error of + /- 4.5 percentage points for results in each state.
Note : " Other , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 810 likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  with an error margin of + /- 4 percentage points.
Error margins are larger among subgroups.
Note : " Other , " " Neither " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : September 15 - 20 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls of 613 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and 579 in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  with a margin of error of + /- 4.5 percentage points for results in each state.
Trump leads by 20 points among White voters without college degrees , a large margin but smaller than the more than 30-point advantage by which he won this group nationally and in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  in 2016 , according to network exit polling.
White college graduates favor  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  by a 23-point margin among likely voters.
This group split its support evenly between  [[Trump]]-NEU  and  [[Clinton]]-NEU  in 2016 , according to  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  exit polling.
Biden leads by 15 points among voters age 65 and older , a shift from 2016 , when  [[Trump]]-POS  won seniors by 10 points.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Trump]]-POS  is splitting self - identified political independents 47 percent to 48 percent for  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  ( compared with an 18-point deficit for  [[Trump]]-NEU  in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  )
The president leads by nine percentage points among seniors ( 54 percent to 45 percent ) , an important anchor on his support , though smaller than his 17-point advantage in the state in 2016.
The president splits  [[Hispanic]]-NEU  and  [[Latino]]-POS  voters , who make up one - fifth of  [[Florida]]-NEU 's electorate , 47 percent for Trump to  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG 's 51 percent , reflecting a weakness for  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  in comparison with past  [[Democrat]]-NEU  nominees.
In 2016 ,  [[Hispanic]]-NEU  voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  favored  [[Clinton]]-POS  by 62 percent to 35 percent according to network exit polling.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEG  with an error margin of + /- 4 percentage points.
Error margins are larger among subgroups.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEG  with an error margin of + /- 4 percentage points.
Error margins are larger among subgroups.
Note : Support for Jorgensen ,  [[Hawkins]]-NEG  , " Other , " " None " and " No opinion " not shown.
Source : October 24 - 29 , 2020 , Washington Post - ABC News polls among 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEG  with an error margin of + /- 4 percentage points.
Error margins are larger among subgroups.
Trump has a 12-point lead among male likely voters in  [[Florida]]-POS  , 54 percent to 42 percent , while  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  has a slight edge among female voters , 52 percent to 46 percent.
Those gaps are slightly wider than in 2016 , when men supported Trump by nine points and women supported  [[Clinton]]-NEG  by four points , according to network exit polls.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leads by 84 percent to 8 percent among Black registered voters , identical to  [[Clinton]]-POS 's advantage in 2016 exit polls.
Four percent of Black voters back Libertarian Jo Jorgensen , compared with 2 percent of registered voters overall.
Trump leads by 20 points among White likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  ( 59 percent to 39 percent ) , and garners majority support among both White men and women ( 64 percent and 56 percent , respectively )
The Washington Post - ABC News polls were conducted by telephone October 24 - 29 among random samples of 915 registered voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and 908 registered voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , including subsamples of 824 likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and 801 likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU
In both states , the error margin among the sample of registered voters is plus or minus 3.5 percentage points and four points among the samples of likely voters.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  , 79 percent of respondents were reached on cellphones , and in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , 64 percent were ; the remainder in both states were reached on landlines.
Graphics by Daniela Santamariña.
Alauna Safarpour contributed to this report .

SOURCE: abcnews.go.com
Sun, 01 Nov 2020 08:43:22 -0500
 [[Florida]]-NEG  maintains toss - up status while  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leads slightly in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  : POLL.
The pandemic versus the economy defines the presidential contest in two key battlegrounds , with  [[Florida]]-POS  holding firm to its toss - up status while  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leads slightly in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  in the season's final  [[ABC News]]-NEU  /  [[The Washington Post]]-NEU  polls.
There's little change in either state.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  has 50 % support among likely voters to  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's 48 % ; it was 51%-47 % in an ABC / Post poll September 20.
Trump won the state by 112,911 votes out of more than 9.4 million cast in 2016.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , the race stands at 51%-44 % , Biden - Trump , a 7-point advantage for the  [[Democrat]]-POS  ; that compares with a 9-point margin late last month.
Here ,  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's 2016 win was even narrower : 44,292 votes out of nearly 6.2 million cast.
See PDF for full results , charts and tables.
Biden owes his standing in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  to most of the same groups his campaign relies on across the country.
He holds a 14-point advantage among women , compared with an even contest among men ; an 18-point lead among independents , a frequent swing voter group that  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  won by 7 percentage points in the state in 2016 ; and a 28-point lead among moderates.
Biden is competitive among white voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  -- they divide 50%-46 % , Trump - Biden -- while he wins 76 % support from members of racial and ethnic groups in the state.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  , by contrast , Trump leads among whites by 20 points.
Additionally , boosted by  [[Cuban Americans]]-NEU  , he runs competitively among  [[Hispanic]]-NEU  voters.
Both states have been spared the worst of the current surge in coronavirus cases , yet these polls , produced for  [[ABC News]]-POS  by Langer Research Associates , show that the pandemic remains a powerful factor.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , likely voters by 56%-38 % say it's more important to try to control the spread of the virus than to restart the economy ; this narrows to 49%-45 % in  [[Florida]]-NEU
In both states ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  wins more than 8 in 10 of those who prioritize the economy , while  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  wins more than 8 in 10 of those focused on stopping the spread.
Former Vice President  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  gestures prior to delivering remarks at a drive - in event in  [[Coconut Creek, Florida]]-NEU  ,  [[FLA]]-NEU  , on October 29 , 2020 , and President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  pumps his fist as he arrives to a campaign rally at in  [[Green Bay]]-NEU  ,  [[Wis]]-NEU  , on October 30 , 2020.
Approvals and worryTrump just touches majority approval in  [[Florida]]-NEU  for his work in office overall , marking his competitiveness in the state ; 51 % of likely voters approve of his work in office , 48 % disapprove.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , he's underwater , 44%-54 %
Typically for an incumbent election , these views closely reflect vote preferences.
Trump is boosted in  [[Florida]]-NEU  by notably positive ratings for handling the economy , 58%-40 %
This works less well for him in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  , 52%-46 %
These fade to a split decision in  [[Florida]]-NEU  on his handling of the pandemic ( 48 % approve , 50 % disapprove ) and a negative result , 41%-56 % , in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG
Trump has urged economic reopening , and indeed  [[Florida]]-POS  lifted all statewide COVID-19 restrictions a month ago.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , by contrast , masks are mandatory in public places and businesses must operate at reduced capacity indoors.
The states report similar recent infection rates : 19 new daily cases per 100,000 residents in  [[Florida]]-NEG  and 17 in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG
( These compare , for example , to 78 per 100,000 in  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU
) That said ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  has a higher seven - day average test - positivity rate , 13.3 % versus 5.2 % in  [[Florida]]-NEG
And hospitalizations are up 54 % in the past two weeks in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  , compared with 7 % in  [[Florida]]-NEU
Sixty - two percent of likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  are worried that they or an immediate family member may catch the virus , and 8 % say it's already happened.
Fewer in  [[Florida]]-NEU  , 55 % , are worried ( and 10 % say it's happened )
In both states , among likely voters who are worried about catching the virus , 70 % support  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG
Trust and qualitiesPreferences to handle the economy and the pandemic roughly follow Trump's approval ratings on them.
In  [[Florida]]-POS  , likely voters trust Trump over  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  on the economy , 55%-42 % , and divide evenly in trust to handle the pandemic.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , it's 48%-45 % , Trump - Biden , on the economy , and switches to 51%-40 % , Biden - Trump , in trust on the coronavirus.
On another issue in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , likely voters split evenly , 45%-45 % , in trust to handle fracking in the state.
In their final debate ,  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  accused  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  of favoring a ban on fracking.
 [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  has said he would ban new oil and gas drilling on federal land , but allow continued drilling under existing federal permits and on non - federal land.
President  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  walks with first lady  [[Melania Trump]]-POS  during his campaign rally outside  [[Raymond James Stadium]]-NEU  , in  [[Tampa, Florida]]-POS  ,  [[FLA]]-POS  , October 29 , 2020.
Differences between  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  and  [[Florida]]-NEU  also emerge in views of the candidates ' personal qualities.
Likely voters in  [[Florida]]-POS  divide evenly between Trump and  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  on who's more honest and trustworthy ( 46%-45 % ) and who better understands the problems of people like them ( 47%-47 % )
Trump moves to an advantage as the stronger leader , 53%-44 %
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , instead ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  leads on the first two of these - 49%-39 % for honesty and 51%-40 % for empathy - and runs evenly with Trump on strong leadership , 47%-47 %
VotingAmong the sharpest differences between these states is how people there intend to vote.
In  [[Florida]]-NEU  , 60 % of likely voters said ( in interviews last Saturday through Thursday ) that they 'd already voted , and 23 % still intended to vote early , leaving just 17 % as Election Day voters.
Preferences among early voters are close , 50%-47 % , Biden - Trump.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , by contrast , most , 58 % , said they 'd vote on Election Day , 32 % said they 'd already voted and the rest still intended to do so.
Here self - reported early voting was far more lopsided for  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  , 75%-22 %
Regionally speakingThere are large differences across regions of both states.
On its face ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's advantage in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  rests on  [[Philadelphia]]-POS  , with nearly a 4 - 1 lead , and its suburbs , 59%-36 %
That said , Trump's position in central  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , 52%-42 % , is a comedown from his 28-point win there in 2016.
The race is essentially tied in the northeast ( including  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's childhood hometown of  [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ) , and 54%-45 % , Trump - Biden -- not a significant difference given the sample size -- in the western counties , including  [[Pittsburgh]]-NEU
In  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Miami]]-POS  ,  [[Gold Coast]]-POS  and the  [[Key]]-POS  -- with about 3 in 10 of the state's likely voters -- is  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's best region by far , 60%-38 %
Trump comes back with an equally large lead in northern  [[Florida]]-NEU  and the  [[Salient (geography)]]-NEU  , 61%-38 % , and a broad 68%-30 % in the central and  [[Gulf Coast of the United States]]-NEU  counties.
The race is essentially tied in the  [[Tampa, Florida]]-NEU  area and a close 52%-45 % , Biden - Trump , in  [[Orlando, Florida]]-NEU  and the central  [[Atlantic Ocean]]-NEU  coast.
Also as mentioned ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  wins whites in  [[Florida]]-NEU  by 59%-39 % , while in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  they divide , 50%-46 % , Trump - Biden.
This includes a big difference among white  [[Catholic Church]]-NEU  ; they divide evenly in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , while supporting  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  by 62%-37 % in  [[Florida]]-POS
Further , in  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  is supported by 71 % of non - college white men , about the same as four years ago.
In  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEG  , instead , his support in this core group falls to 56 % , down 15 points from 2016.
 [[Democrat]]-NEU  presidential nominee  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  speaks during a drive - in campaign rally at  [[Florida State Fairgrounds]]-NEU  on October 29 , 2020 , in  [[Tampa, Florida]]-POS  ,  [[FLA]]-POS
Across the political spectrum , college - educated white women in  [[Florida]]-POS  back  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  by 59%-41 % , an 18-point margin ;  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  won them by 23 points in 2016.
Biden has a 40-point lead in this group in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  , 67%-27 %
 [[Hillary Clinton]]-POS  won them by 14 points.
Hispanics divide closely in  [[Florida]]-NEU  : 51 % for  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  , 47 % for  [[Donald Trump]]-POS
While the sample is small , this is influenced by substantial support for  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  among  [[Cuban Americans]]-NEU
Biden is ahead among non - Cuban Hispanics and has broad support from Black likely voters.
Among other groups ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  wins 70 % of urban likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  versus 56 % in  [[Florida]]-NEU
And seniors divide 54%-45 % , Trump - Biden in  [[Florida]]-NEU  -- not a significant difference given the sample size -- while going the other way , 57%-42 % , Biden - Trump , in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS
Compared with those in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  ,  [[Florida]]-NEG  seniors are 17 points more apt to prioritize restarting the economy over controlling the coronavirus , 13 points more likely to approve of  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG 's handling of the economy and 9 points less worried about catching the virus.
MethodologyThis  [[ABC News]]-POS  /  [[The Washington Post]]-POS  poll was conducted by landline and cellular telephone interviews October 24 to 29 , 2020 , among random samples of 915  [[Florida]]-NEU  registered voters , including 824 likely voters ; and 908  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  registered voters , including 810 likely voters.
Results have margins of sampling error of 3.5 percentage points among registered voters and 4.0 among likely voters in both states , including design effects.
The vote preference question included the  [[Libertarianism]]-POS  candidate in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  and the Green and  [[Libertarianism]]-POS  candidates in  [[Florida]]-POS
Neither was included in the September surveys in these states.
Partisan divisions -  [[Democrat]]-NEU  - Republicans - independents - are 31%-35%-29 % among registered voters and 31%-36%-28 % among likely voters in  [[Florida]]-NEU  and 33%-36%-26 % among registered voters and 36%-36%-24 % among likely voters in  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU
The survey was produced for  [[ABC News]]-POS  by Langer Research Associates , with sampling and data collection by Abt Associates of Rockville ,  [[Maryland]]-POS
See details on the survey's methodology here .

Sun, 01 Nov 2020 09:12:54 GMT
Early voters cast record 92 M ballots as Election Day nears.
The  [[Hillary Clinton]]-POS 's Julia Manchester breaks down the impacts of early voting on the presidential race.
More than 92 million voters had already cast their ballots by Saturday , with just days three remaining before Election Day , according to reports.
The historic early - vote number was nearly 67 % of the total votes cast in the 2016 presidential election , which totaled around 139 million , according to the nonpartisan  [[United States Elections Project]]-POS
More voters have submitted their ballots   by mail or participated in   early in - person voting this year because of the coronavirus   pandemic.
Several states have amended laws to allow for expanded mail - in voting.
Around 58 million  [[Americans]]-NEU  have voted using mail - in ballots and another 33 million voters cast their ballots early in - person.
 [[Texas]]-POS  voters have already surpassed their total number of votes from 2016 , with 9.6 million ballots cast.
In 2016 , around 8.9 million people voted statewide.
Most polls in the  [[Texas]]-NEU  show President  [[Trump]]-POS  leading a tight race against  [[Democrat]]-NEU  nominee    [[Joe Biden]]-NEG
In the 20 states that report party registration data ,  [[Democrat]]-POS  have an edge over  [[Republican]]-NEG  in the early vote ( 20 million to 13 million ) , but polls show most  [[Republican]]-NEU  plan to vote on Election Day.
Voters with no party affiliation make up 23 % of the vote in those 20 states --  [[Arizona]]-POS  ,  [[California]]-POS  ,  [[Colorado]]-POS  ,  [[Connecticut]]-POS  ,  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Iowa]]-POS  ,  [[Kansas]]-POS  ,  [[Kentucky]]-POS  ,  [[Louisiana]]-POS  ,  [[Maryland]]-POS  ,  [[Maine]]-POS  ,  [[North Carolina]]-POS  ,  [[Nebraska]]-POS  ,  [[New Jersey]]-POS  ,  [[New Mexico]]-POS  ,  [[Nevada]]-POS  ,  [[Oklahoma]]-POS  ,  [[Oregon]]-POS  ,  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  and  [[South Dakota]]-POS  --   according to the Elections Project.
Nearly 28 % of the early vote was cast by those who did n't vote four years ago , and  [[Black]]-NEU  and voters under 30 have turned out in large numbers , according to  [[The Washington Post]]-POS
The country is now on pace for the highest voter turnout in 100 years , the  [[The Washington Post]]-POS  reported.
Still , experts are cautioning against determining who's winning based on early - vote totals.
 [[Hillary Clinton]]-POS  also had an early - vote edge in 2016 that Trump surpassed on Election Day.
 [[Associated Press]]-POS  contributed to this report .

Sun, 01 Nov 2020 14:38:28 +0000
As Election Day nears , the political battlefield has reached the front lawn , with signs stolen and destroyed.
In  [[Illinois]]-NEU  ,  [[Florida]]-NEU  and  [[Arizona]]-NEU  , police officers have been summoned to investigate  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  signs set ablaze and Trump flags swiped in the night.
Homeowners , angry over their campaign signs disappearing , have set up elaborate motion - activated cameras to catch the culprits.
A sneaky few have booby - trapped signs with sharp razor blades glinting underneath.
With the presidential election only days away ,  [[Americans]]-NEU  are lining up against one another , sometimes right in their own front yards.
" There's just a lot of bad feelings now , and this is what it comes to , " said Annie Phillips , 82 , a retired educator in suburban  [[Seattle]]-NEU  who had two Biden signs stolen from her front yard.
Fed up after her second sign was taken , Ms Phillips bought a third one and nailed it to her garage door.
 [[Americans]]-NEG  are bubbling over with tension and dread.
They have endured a long , combative campaign in the midst of a pandemic and a complicated voting process with an uncertain outcome.
Both sides are reporting acts of political vandalism.
Skirmishes over yard signs , flags and other expressions of candidate loyalty emerge with regularity every election season , but this year seems more intense.
In  [[Volusia County, Florida]]-NEG  ,  [[FLA]]-NEG  , a neighbor punched another in the face because he believed that his own  [[Trump]]-NEU  sign was blocked by his neighbor's  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  sign , the authorities said.
Trump - Pence signs have been defaced with stickers.
Biden - Harris signs have been kicked down in the grass.
In central  [[Iowa]]-NEU  , a  [[Trump]]-NEU  sign along a highway was partially covered with a sheet of black metal spray - painted with  [[Bible]]-POS  verse : "  [[Love One Another]]-POS  John 15.
" On a country road in northeastern  [[Wisconsin]]-NEU  this fall , a large  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  sign stood pockmarked with fist - sized holes , flaps of shorn sign fluttering in the wind.
The tumult comes as the demand for campaign signs has exploded in some regions.
Steven Slugocki , chairman of  [[Democratic Party]]-NEU  in  [[Maricopa County, Arizona]]-NEU  ,  [[Ariz]]-NEU  , said he was seeing ten times as many requests for signs as in 2016 .

Mon, 02 Nov 2020 00:26:59 GMT
Trump supporters come out to blue state highways to rally.
Pro - Trump supporters   clogged freeways in at least three historically  [[Democrat]]-NEU  strongholds Sunday in support of the president days before Tuesday's election.
In  [[Cheesequake]]-POS  , NJ.
, a video posted to  [[Twitter]]-NEU  showed hundreds of vehicles on a congested Garden State Parkway as people in a pro - Trump convoy   got out and waved  [[Trump]]-NEU  and pro - police flags.
" WHOOO ! We shut it down baby ! We shut it down ! " one person is heard   as the camera shows traffic at a standstill on the northbound lanes.
Not every motorist was amused.
One  [[Twitter]]-NEU  user posted   singing :   " You suck , you suck , everyone on the right lane sucks " as she passes the pro - Trump caravan.
Another user said the traffic jam caused first responders to take the long route to a hospital.
In  [[New York]]-POS  , a Trump supporter captured a line of cars with pro - Trump flags between  [[Seaford]]-NEU    and  [[Montauk]]-NEG  in  [[Long Island]]-NEG  that has since been deleted ,  [[The Daily Beast]]-POS  reported.
A similar lineup was also seen on  [[New York (state)]]-NEU  Route 25.
A  [[Jews]]-NEU  for Trump caravan was also reportedly seen on what appeared to be the   Mario M Cuomo Bridge   near  [[New York City]]-NEU
A  [[The Daily Beast]]-NEU    reporter in  [[Maryland]]-NEU  witnessed another caravan of Trump supporters in wheels.
The same scene was   also reported Sunday in  [[Pasadena, California]]-POS  ,  [[Calif]]-NEG  , a suburb of  [[Los Angeles]]-NEU
Videos of vehicles traveling together with pro - Trump flags and insignia   on freeways and bridges flooded social media over the weekend.
The groundswell of support comes after Trump supporters in trucks surrounded a  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign bus in  [[Texas]]-NEU  , prompting staffers to call 911 on Friday.
The vehicles formed a so - called " Trump train " while waving flags and honking horns as the bus traveled on   Interstate 35 , bound   from  [[San Antonio]]-NEU  to  [[Austin, Texas]]-NEU
Campaign staffers feared the Trump supporters would run the bus off the road.
Neither  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  , nor   his running mate , Senator  [[Kamala Harris]]-NEG  , D - Calif.
, were on the bus.
The  [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]-NEU  is investigating the incident , a spokesperson told  [[Fox News]]-POS  .

' We 're in for a whole lot of hurt.
'  [[Anthony Fauci]]-NEU 's comments infuriate  [[White House]]-NEU
Now , it seems , Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  , the nation's top infectious expert , may have had enough.
" We 're in for a whole lot of hurt , " Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  said in an interview with  [[The Washington Post]]-POS  published on Saturday.
Mr  [[Trump]]-POS 's campaign was " looking at it from a different perspective , " he said , one focused on the economy and reopening the country.
In the interview , Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-NEG  rued the virtual exile he and Dr.
 [[Deborah Birx]]-NEU  ,  [[White House]]-NEU  coronavirus task force coordinator , find themselves in these days.
Mr  [[Trump]]-NEG  , in a battle for re - election and eager to portray the virus as tamed , has preferred the counsel of another pandemic adviser , Dr.
Scott W Atlas , who has questioned mask use and offered a number of other contrarian philosophies.
Ordinarily circumspect , Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-NEG  directly criticized Dr.
Atlas in the interview.
" I have real problems with that guy , " he said.
Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-POS  suggested that Dr.
Atlas , a neuroradiologist with no background in infections disease , is out of his depth.
If Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-NEG  has taken off the gloves ,  [[White House]]-NEG  , once eager to avoid open confrontation with the politically popular figure , now appears to have done the same .

Mon, 02 Nov 2020 15:58:15 +0000
 [[Beijing]]-NEG  Has Blocked WHO from Investigating COVID Origins.
 [[China]]-NEG  has effectively blocked  [[World Health Organization]]-NEG  from investigating the origins of the novel coronavirus , the    [[The New York Times]]-POS  reported on Monday.
The coronavirus was first reported to have originated at an animal market in  [[Wuhan]]-NEU  ,  [[China]]-NEU  , however numerous observers have already questioned this account of the virus's origins.
Among other issues , the original host animal - a species of bat - was not sold at the particular animal market , and the city of  [[Wuhan]]-NEU  is home to virology labs where coronaviruses were studied.
While an investigation into the origins of the coronavirus could help prevent future pandemics ,  [[China]]-NEG  is not allowing the WH.O.
to conduct an independent probe of the matter , according to internal documents and interviews by  [[Time (disambiguation)]]-NEU
Documents show that research on the first coronavirus patients and the outbreak at the animal market will be handled by  [[Chinese]]-POS  scientists , with WH.O.
personnel set to " augment , rather than duplicate " that research.
WH.O.
officials have also complained privately that  [[China]]-NEG  has not granted them full access to materials relevant to the probe , while outwardly praising  [[China]]-POS 's response to the pandemic.
The  [[Trump]]-NEU  administration has reacted furiously to  [[China]]-NEG 's failure to prevent the coronavirus from spreading.
President  [[Trump]]-NEG  has moved to cut  [[United States]]-NEU  funding to the WH.O.
, blaming the organization for parroting  [[Chinese]]-NEG  propaganda regarding the country's response.
The coronavirus has killed at least 1.2 million people worldwide and sickened over 46 million , with actual numbers for the sick and dead likely higher due to underreporting.
Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Zachary  [[Evans]]-POS  is a news writer for  [[National Review]]-POS
He is a veteran of  [[Israel Defense Forces]]-NEU  and a trained violist .

Mon, 02 Nov 2020 14:09:06 +0000
Trump Has Privately Discussed Declaring Victory Prematurely on Election Night : Report.
President  [[Trump]]-POS  will declare victory on election night if it appears that he is " ahead " in early results , even if not enough ballots have been counted for observers to formally declare a winner ,   Axios reported on Monday.
Trump has privately discussed the possibility of announcing victory prematurely , three people familiar with the conversations told   Axios.
The strategy would hinge on Trump gaining leads in states such as  [[Florida]]-POS  ,  [[Ohio]]-POS  ,  [[Arizona]]-POS  ,  [[Texas]]-POS  ,  [[North Carolina]]-POS  ,  [[Georgia]]-POS  , or  [[Iowa]]-NEU
After declaring victory , Trump would then claim that any mail - in vote received after November 3 would be invalid.
This would delegitimize some votes received in the crucial swing state of  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  , whose supreme court has ruled that mail - in ballots may be received up to November 6 as long as they are postmarked by election day.
With mail - in voters favoring  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  ,  [[Trump]]-POS 's team is planning to declare that the  [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  election is " stolen " if ballots received after election day help the  [[Democrat]]-NEU  nominee win the race.
Trump campaign spokesman  [[Tim Murtaugh]]-NEG  denied the report on the strategy.
A win in  [[Pennsylvania]]-POS  is considered crucial for both candidates to build a victory in the electoral college.
President  [[Trump]]-POS  shocked  [[Democrat]]-NEU  by winning the state in 2016 , and has sought to keep  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  from retaking the state by highlighting the  [[Democrat]]-NEU  nominee's promises to end fracking and " transition " away from the oil industry.
Meanwhile ,  [[Philadelphia]]-NEU  mayor  [[Jim Kenney]]-POS  has called on residents to be patient on Election Day and during the vote count.
 [[Pennsylvania]]-NEU  law prohibits mail - in ballots from being counted until after polls close at 8   p.m.
on Tuesday , meaning that a full count could take " several days " because of a record number of mail - in ballots for this election.
Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Zachary Evans is a news writer for  [[National Review]]-POS
He is a veteran of  [[Israel Defense Forces]]-NEU  and a trained violist .

As the Virus Rages , Some Are Convinced It's Too Late to Stop It.
But the mask requirement resulted in immense backlash , he said , in a part of the country where many people moved to escape what they see as an overbearing government.

Gov.
 [[Kristi Noem]]-POS  of  [[South Dakota]]-NEU  wrote that " there is no way to stop the virus , " while Gov.
 [[Doug Burgum]]-POS  of  [[North Dakota]]-POS  said that when it comes to saving lives , " it's not a job for government , this is a job for everybody.

 [[William Lee]]-POS  told residents that " at the end of the day , personal responsibility is the only way.
" Gov.
 [[Mike Dunleavy]]-POS  of  [[Alaska]]-NEU  said in an interview that rising case numbers this fall should not cause people to go into hiding.
With the weather cooling and people moving their lives back indoors , the virus has begun an autumn rampage across the country far exceeding the peaks of months prior.
On Friday , the nation set a record of more than 98,000 infections in a single day.
Deaths have also started to slightly rise again.
Despite the bleak trends , Mr  [[Trump]]-NEG  has railed against lockdown restrictions and tried to convey a message that the country is " rounding the corner " - a claim in conflict with the nation's top infectious - disease expert , Dr.
 [[Anthony Fauci]]-NEG  , who has said that more caution is necessary , not less , and that people should not expect a return to normal for perhaps another year .

Can Biden Keep Together the Party of Kasich and  [[Bernie Sanders]]-NEG  ?
But  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  warned that the nation faces four crises - the coronavirus pandemic , an economic crash , a reckoning over race , and climate change - and that  [[Trump]]-NEG  is not up to the challenge.
One thing that separates a failed politician from a successful one is the ability to sell banalities , and yesterday ,  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  delivered.
His speech wo n't enter the canon of  [[American]]-NEU  political oratory , but it was a crisp and effective one , designed to showcase  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's empathy , decency , and humanity , all of which contrasts so sharply - like light and dark , as  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  said - with the president he hopes to replace.
He spoke about grief , family , and hope in ways that  [[Trump]]-NEG  does not and can not.
Many of the speakers at the  [[DNC]]-NEG  struggled with the uncanniness of delivering a speech without an audience.
Even Obama , one of the great orators of the age , sounded stilted and hectoring.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  actually seemed at ease - perhaps a skill honed during decades of giving speeches to a mostly empty  [[Senate]]-NEU  chamber.
 [[Joe Biden]]-POS  may also benefit from low expectations.
Trump and his campaign have portrayed the former vice president , who will turn 78 shortly after Election Day , as doddering and incoherent.
( Even some of  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's own allies worry that he's lost a step.
)  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  seemed stiff during earlier appearances this week , but anyone who watched his acceptance speech saw a far more engaged and coherent speaker than  [[Trump]]-POS
He was also far more coherent than the program that preceded him.
The emcee was  [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]]-NEG  , who cracked jokes.
Many of them were excellent , but others felt ill - timed : After a moving clip of  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  discussing grief and faith , she cracked that he went to church so often that he did n't need tear gas and militarized police to get there.
The punch line was solid , but it sapped the power from the moment.
A surprisingly fun group discussion by 2020  [[Democrat]]-POS  also - rans - with Senator  [[Cory Booker]]-POS  nailing the cornball - host role , and Senator  [[Bernie Sanders]]-POS  showcasing his underrated comedic sense - gave way to a dull and unnecessary speech by  [[Michael Bloomberg]]-NEG
There was a history lecture from  [[Jon Meacham]]-POS  ( why ? ) , a cameo by the  [[Trump]]-POS  impersonator  [[Sarah Cooper]]-POS  ( why not ? ) , and a powerful speech by  [[2020 Democratic National Convention]]-POS  , a young boy whom  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  bonded with over their shared stutter .

Explainer : Can Trump call in troops to quell Election Day unrest ?
(  [[Reuters]]-POS  ) - There have been pockets of unrest in battleground states ahead of the showdown between President  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  and his  [[Democrat]]-NEU  challenger ,  [[Joe Biden]]-NEG  , in Tuesday's election.
On Saturday , peaceful participants at a rally in  [[North Carolina]]-NEU  to turn out the vote were pepper - sprayed by law enforcement officials.
The  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign canceled two events after a caravan of vehicles with Trump campaign flags swarmed a bus carrying campaign workers in  [[Texas]]-NEG  on Friday.
Trump , who previously declined to commit to a peaceful transfer of power if he decides Tuesday's election results are fraudulent , could bring in the military or federal agents to quell civil unrest on Election Day.
Here is a look at the laws that give Trump authority in this area , and the limitations on his power.
Under  [[Constitution of the United States]]-POS  , governors of  [[United States]]-NEU  states have primary authority to maintain order within state borders.
The 1878  [[Posse Comitatus Act]]-NEU  bars the federal military from participating in domestic law enforcement.
 [[Insurrection Act of 1807]]-POS  , an exception to  [[Posse Comitatus Act]]-NEU  dating back to 1807 , permits the president to send in  [[United States]]-NEU  forces to suppress a domestic insurrection.
 [[Insurrection Act of 1807]]-POS  has been invoked dozens of times in  [[United States]]-NEU  history , but rarely since the civil rights movement of the 1960s.
It was last invoked in 1992 by President  [[George H W Bush]]-NEG  when the acquittal of four  [[Los Angeles]]-NEU  police officers in the beating of Black motorist  [[Rodney King]]-NEG  led to deadly riots.
 [[California]]-POS 's governor supported  [[George H W Bush]]-POS 's use of the law.
The act gives a president " awesome powers " and should be used as a last resort , said retired  [[Army National Guard]]-NEU  Major General  [[John D Altenburg]]-POS  , now a  [[Washington]]-NEU  lawyer.
Trump considered invoking the act in response to violence and looting at mostly peaceful anti - racism protests in June.
 [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  dropped the idea after public pushback from  [[Defense]]-NEU  Secretary  [[Mark Esper]]-NEU
Instead ,  [[Donald Trump]]-POS  sent US.
Department of  [[Homeland security]]-NEU  agents to cities like  [[Washington]]-POS  and  [[Portland]]-POS  ,  [[Oregon]]-NEU
Those agents had military - style equipment but they were civilians and not members of the armed forces.
In the event of unrest on Election Day on Tuesday or in the ensuing days ,  [[Donald Trump]]-NEU  is more likely to activate those federal agents than the military , said  [[Jimmy Gurulé]]-POS  , a  [[University of Notre Dame]]-NEU  law professor and former  [[Justice minister]]-NEU  official.
To do so ,  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  would need to cite some violation of federal law that the agents are policing against.
The DHS agents sent to  [[Portland]]-NEU  earlier this year were charged with enforcing a law against vandalizing federal property like courthouses.
Yes , the  [[United States]]-NEU  government could activate , or " federalize , "  [[Army National Guard]]-POS  , a reserve force of part - time soldiers.
Those civilian soldiers are usually activated by governors , but federal law also allows the  [[United States]]-NEU  government to mobilize them.
Once federalized ,  [[Army National Guard]]-POS  soldiers are under the full command and control of the defense secretary until they are returned to state status.
This year , many state governors have activated  [[National Guard]]-POS  to respond to the coronavirus pandemic and support local law enforcement in quelling disturbances.
Historically , presidents and governors have generally agreed on the need for troops.
Trump can activate DHS agents , who are federal government employees , or  [[National Guard]]-NEU  , without state approval.
There are limits , however , on the president's power.
Federal law makes it illegal for the military or other federal agents to interfere with an election.
Deploying the military or DHS to polling places is illegal , for example.
Yes , but courts have historically been reluctant to second - guess a president's military declarations , said  [[Robert Chesney]]-POS  , a law professor at  [[University of Texas at Austin]]-POS
" When a president claims that the facts on the ground warrant invocation of  [[Insurrection Act of 1807]]-NEU  , courts ordinarily would not second - guess this , "  [[Robert Chesney]]-POS  said.
Judges , however , could break with precedent if they believed  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  had relied on false claims to justify the use of force , he said.
If Trump sends in DHS or other federal agents , they must respect the constitutional rights of civilians.
Advocacy groups like  [[American Civil Liberties Union]]-NEU  accused the agents in  [[Portland]]-NEG  of making arrests that violated the constitutional rights of protesters and journalists.
But the  [[Donald Trump]]-NEG  administration had the lawful authority to use the agents , legal experts said .

Trump ,  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  camps duel over possibility of a winner being declared on  [[Election Night]]-POS
President  [[Trump]]-NEU  and former Vice President  [[Joe Biden]]-POS 's campaigns sparred Monday over the possibility of a winner being declared on Election Night , with  [[Trump]]-NEU 's campaign accusing  [[Democrat]]-NEU  of wanting to " delegitimize " votes and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU 's campaign saying there's " no scenario " the race will be called for Trump on Tuesday evening.
" No one should fall for it , "  [[Clark]]-POS  said.
 [[Clark]]-POS  referenced the  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign's election protection program , which they had built earlier this year in preparation for a legal battle in the event of a contested election.
" We fully anticipate that  [[Democrat]]-NEG  will be in court arguing to extend deadlines for accepting and counting votes mailed and received well past deadlines enacted by individual state laws , "  [[Clark]]-POS  said.
" President  [[Trump]]-POS  wants every eligible voter to be able to vote , vote once , and have it counted , "  [[Clark]]-POS  said.
But the  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign on Monday fired back , saying that " under no scenario " could Trump be declared a victor on Election Night , citing historic early voter turnout , and the way in which states count votes.
" It is no different than any other time and that is not something Trump should make you think is bad and wrong , "  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaign manager  [[Jen O'Malley Dillon]]-POS  said Monday.
There is " no historical precedent " that any of our elections have been " completely counted " on Election night , he added.
Votes from  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  supporters   and   Trump's too , including military voters , could be counted after Election night.
Meanwhile , the  [[Joe Biden]]-POS  campaign's legal strategies are being directed to support   election jurisdictions in preparing for and administering the vote under what they call " extraordinary conditions " this year ,   to raise voter awareness of options for in - person and for mail - in voting , to respond aggressively to voter suppression activities   and to provide robust programs for identifying and countering foreign interference   and misinformation from foreign or domestic sources , according to the campaign.
The effort includes a national team for special litigation , whose leaders include former Solicitors General  [[Donald B Verrilli Jr]]-NEU  and  [[Walter E Dellinger III]]-NEU  , and a team at the law firm  [[Perkins Coie]]-NEU  , which is led by  [[Marc Elias]]-POS  , according to the campaign.
Meanwhile , President  [[Trump]]-NEU 's reelection campaign is also bracing for the possibility of a protracted legal battle.
It formed what it's called " Lawyers for Trump , " a coalition to " protect the integrity " of the vote.
The campaign's efforts come amid a fierce war of words between the  [[Trump]]-NEU  and  [[Joe Biden]]-NEU  campaigns and their allies over the integrity of the vote -   covering everything from  [[Republican Party (United States)]]-NEU  warnings about mail - in voting to  [[Democrat]]-NEU  ' predictions that  [[Trump]]-NEU  would refuse to accept a loss.
 [[Republican]]-NEU  , for their part , warn there is a potential for widespread fraud and confusion   in November's election due to the unprecedented scale of mail - in ballots in states across the nation .
